name: Coastal birds
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster data intends to show bird density in coastal areas around the Swedish coast. The source data is voluntary observational statistics exported to an excel file from SLU Artdatabanken (species database) via Analysisportal.se and these data have been converted to density data (average numbers of individual birds reported between May and June within 5km of each grid cell over the period 2010-2017). These data are based on voluntary reporting and are therefore subject to observer bias. Areas without sightings are not reported and areas where many reports are made may be visited by multiple observers. As a consequence these data should be treated cautiously. A cell value of zero represents no reported observation of birds a cell value of 100 represents the maximum observed species diversity at the Beijershamn nature reserve in Öland. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only
advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa fågeltäthet i kustområden kring den svenska kusten. Källdata är frivilligt inrapporterad observationsstatistik från SLU:s Artdatabanken via Analysisportal.se som exporterats till en Excel-fil, dessa data har konverterats till täthetsdata (medelvärde av individuella fåglar rapporterade mellan maj och juni inom 5 km från varje gridcell, under perioden 2010- 2017). Denna data är baserat på frivillig rapportering och kan därför variera i kontinuitet. Områden utan observationer rapporteras inte och områden där många rapporter gjorts kan ha besökt av flera observatörer. Följaktligen bör dessa data behandlas med försiktighet. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar inga rapporterade fågelobservationer, ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar den maximala observerade fågeltätheten vid Beijershamns naturreservat på Öland. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: Data is based on reported observations of birds (extract from Artdatabanken, SLU via Analysisportal.se). Species reported in this data are rödspov, tordmule, kärrsnäppa (underarten schinzii), vitkindad gås, skärfläcka, fisktärna, silvertärna, sillgrissla, tobisgrissla, skräntärna, silltrut, svärta, kustlabb, toppskarv, tretåig mås, stjärtand, årta, roskarl, brunand, bergand, brushane, ejder, småtärna, kentsk tärna och gråtrut. Data were extracted for the same period (May 25 to July 20) for all years between 2010 and 2017. The number of observed individuals was summed per grid cell at a resolution of 1 x 1km. The average value per 5 km was then calculated. The values in the screen were normalized against the maximum value of observations in the Beijershamn nature reserve (off the coast of Öland) to reduce the impact of over reporting in certain areas.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The source data in this analysis is based on voluntary observational reporting by individuals and therefore data varies in continuity. It is likely that more observations are reported where more people are present (i.e. near to urban centres) or in well known bird watching areas.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Determine if null data are recorded (i.e. where observations are made but no species are determined) and if observation density data are available. It might be possible to correct observer bias if such data exist (i.e. map survey intensity and divide observation reports by the number of observations).
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Coastal birds" dataset is a derived from source data provided by Lund University. This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states significant limitations due to voluntary reporting and observer bias, which fundamentally affect the data's reliability for assessing bird density. The recommendation to 'correct observer bias if such data exist (i.e. map survey intensity and divide observation reports by the number of observations)' points to a need for a fundamental methodological overhaul to account for data collection effort, which is a major improvement. The current 'density' is not a true density but rather a reporting frequency, heavily influenced by human presence. Addressing this requires a re-conceptualization of how 'density' is derived from biased observational data.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended correction for observer bias would be difficult. It requires determining if 'null data are recorded' and if 'observation density data are available', which implies accessing and integrating additional, potentially unstandardized, datasets from the source (SLU Artdatabanken/Analysisportal.se). If such data are not readily available, it would necessitate a new data collection strategy or a complex statistical modeling approach to infer survey effort, which is a significant undertaking. This goes beyond simple data updates or minor methodological tweaks.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly help generate or improve this layer. The layer is about bird density, which is a biological observation. Satellites cannot directly observe individual birds or bird populations at the resolution and specificity required for this layer. While satellites can provide environmental context (e.g., habitat mapping, water quality), they cannot replace the in-situ biological observations that form the basis of this dataset. The core issue is observer bias in biological reporting, not environmental parameters measurable by satellite.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden's primary datasets (Sentinel-2 Level-2A and national land cover data) are not suitable for directly generating or improving this layer. These datasets are focused on land cover, land use, and some shallow water characteristics. They cannot detect or count birds, nor can they provide information on human observation effort or bias in biological reporting. While coastal habitat mapping might be possible with Sentinel-2, it would not address the fundamental data quality issues related to bird observations and observer bias.

name: Seabird coastal wintering
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show important areas for four seabird species in Swedish coastal waters during the winter period. This raster is a spatial model which shows aggregated species density (relative to the total species population size) of Velvet Scoter, Long tailed duck, Common Scoter and Common Eider. It is based on source data in the form of observational presence & abundance data from a national aerial surveys undertaken in 2015 for the International Waterfowl Census supplied by Lund University. The highest occurring value between the species has been attributed to each individual cell and a linear transformation was applied so that a cell value of 0 is equivalent to zero abundance (or no data) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to the maximum [relative] density for any one of these five species. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa viktiga områden för fyra sjöfågelarter i svenska kustvatten under vinterperioden. Detta rasterskikt är en rumslig modell vilken visar aggregerad artdensitet (relativt till populationens totala storlek) av svärta, alfågel, sjöorre och ejder. Det är baserat på källdata i form av observerad förekomst- och abundansdata från en nationell flygundersökning från 2015 för den nationella sjöfågelinventeringen från Lunds
universitet. Det högsta förekommande värdet mellan arter
har getts till varje enskild cell och en linjär transformation
har applicerats så att ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen
abundans (eller ingen data), och ett cellvärde av 100
motsvarar maximal (relativ) densitet för någon av dessa fyra
arter. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för
’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för
havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV).
Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den
kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska
vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av
denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter
vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: National data on four species of seabirds (Velvet Scoter, Long tailed duck, Common Scoter, Common Eider) were sourced from the national seabird inventory (see: ORNIS SVECICA 26: 3-54, 2016) in the form of aerial line- inventories and point inventory data. These were used to calculate proportional population densities for defined inventory sectoral areas. For each species the observed abundance was divided by the survey area sector to produce areal abundance data. This areal abundance layer was then divided by the species' total population to give a proportional value relative to the species as a whole. The total populations used were: Common Eider: 515 000, Common Scoter: 412 000, Long-Tailed Duck: 1 482 000, Velvet Scoter: 373 000. Finally, data for each of the five species were aggregated into a single layer where the highest proportional value from any of these species was attributed to each sector. In order to capture the full spatial range of the seabirds including areas of peripheral importance this aggregated species density dataset was normalised using a transformation (lin100LogxLin01) and rescaled between 0 and 100 in ArcGIS. Consultation on the methodology has taken place between WSP, Lund University and the Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony:
Note that the model is based on interpolation techniques and it does not predict densities significantly beyond the source data (for example using environmental data to infer distributions to unsurveyed areas). In order to attempt to make the data more conservative (i.e. precautionary) the data has been transformed to emphasise areas which have both core are peripheral importance. This approach might reduce some of the observer bias (by increasing the influence of unsurveyed areas) in the interpolation model but the result
should be considered to be a conservative estimate of species density.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: More advanced modelling could perhaps be undertaken using environmental preference data to predict distribution patterns as per the SOWBAS study from 2011 undertaken for these species offshore.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Seabird coastal wintering" dataset is a derived from source data from the National Seabird Inventory funded by the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency and reported by Leif Nilsson & Frederik Haas from Lund University in ORNIS SVECICA 26:3–54, 2016.. This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states a major limitation: 'it does not predict densities significantly beyond the source data (for example using environmental data to infer distributions to unsurveyed areas)'. The recommendation is to undertake 'More advanced modelling could perhaps be undertaken using environmental preference data to predict distribution patterns'. This indicates a fundamental shift from interpolation of observed data to predictive modeling based on environmental covariates, which is a major methodological overhaul and represents a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing 'advanced modelling using environmental preference data to predict distribution patterns' for multiple seabird species requires significant expertise in ecological modeling, potentially new data collection (environmental parameters), and complex statistical analysis. This is a 'high' difficulty task, moving beyond simple data updates or integration of existing datasets.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The layer focuses on seabird density, which is primarily derived from aerial surveys (observational presence & abundance data). While satellite remote sensing can provide environmental data (e.g., SST, chlorophyll-a) that could be used as covariates in a predictive model, it cannot directly observe seabird populations or their densities at the species level. The core data (seabird presence/abundance) is not directly observable by current satellite technology. Therefore, satellite data cannot 'generate' this layer, nor can it 'effectively replace or supplement' the primary observational data for seabird counts. It could contribute to the 'environmental preference data' for advanced modeling, but it's not the primary data source for the layer itself.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are not suitable for directly observing or counting seabirds in marine environments. While Sentinel-2 can map coastal features, it lacks the resolution and spectral capabilities to detect individual birds or provide data relevant to their offshore distribution. The land cover data is terrestrial. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden data cannot help generate or significantly improve this specific marine seabird density layer.

name: Seabird offshore wintering
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show important areas for four seabird species in Swedish offshore waters during the winter period. This raster is a spatial model which shows aggregated species density (relative to the total species population size) of Velvet Scoter, Long tailed duck, Common Scoter and Common Eider. It is based on modelled population densities which were produced using environmental data to infer species distributions in unsurveyed areas. These models were based on field surveys undertaken in the Baltic Sea between 2007 and 2009. The highest occurring value between the species has been attributed to each individual cell and a linear transformation was applied so that a cell value of 0 is equivalent to zero abundance (or no data) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to the maximum [relative] density for any one of these five species. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa viktiga områden för fyra sjöfågelarter i svenska havsvatten under vinterperioden. Detta rasterskikt är en rumslig modell vilken visar aggregerad artdensitet (relativt till populationens totala storlek) av svärta, alfågel, sjöorre och ejder. Det är baserat på modellerad populationsdensitet vilket producerades med hjälp av miljödata för att ge upphov till artfördelningar i ej
undersökta områden. Dessa modeller baseras på
fältundersökningar gjorda i Östersjön mellan 2007 och
2009. Det högsta förekommande värdet mellan arter har
getts till varje enskild cell och en linjär transformation har
applicerats så att ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen
abundans (eller ingen data), och ett cellvärde av 100
motsvarar maximal (relativ) densitet för någon av dessa fyra
arter. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för
’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för
havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV).
Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den
kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska
vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av
denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter
vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Data for the Baltic Sea on four species of wintering seabirds (Velvet Scoter, Long tailed duck, Common Scoter, Common Eider) were sourced in the form of modelled raster data from the SOWBAS database (Status of wintering Waterbird populations in the Baltic Sea) as detailed in the report: Waterbird Populations and Pressures in the Baltic Sea, Nordic Council of Ministers, Copenhagen, TemaNord 2011:550 ISBN 978-92-893-2249-2). The source data are from aerial, shore and ship based surveys undertaken between 2007 and 2009 and these data were modelled (using a two step General Additive Model) to predict the species distribution both inside and outside surveyed areas based on environmental predictor variables. The modelled area is limited to the Baltic Sea. The modelled densities are expressed in number / km2 and these data were normalized against the species total population to give the value per cell relative to the species population as a whole. The total populations used were: Common Eider: 515 000, Common Scoter: 412 000, Long- Tailed Duck: 1 482 000, Velvet Scoter: 373 000. Finally, the relative occurrence of the four species was aggregated where the value of the species with the highest relative occurrence was attributed to each cell. In order to capture the full spatial range of the seabirds including areas of peripheral importance this aggregated species density dataset was normalised using a transformation (lin100LogxLin01) and rescaled between 0 and 100 in ArcGIS. Consultation on the methodology has been carried out
between the WSP and the Swedish Agency for Water and
Marine Management.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This dataset is based on two years of survey data from 2007 and 2009 and as a consequence it is now fairly outdated.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Investment in updating this product with more new input data is recommended. This may also facilitate insight into temporal trends that may further inform spatial policy decisions.
data_authoring_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Seabird offshore wintering" dataset is a derived from SOWBAS data (Status of wintering Waterbird populations in the Baltic Sea) funded Nordic Council of Ministers and utilising survey data from the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency, WWF Sweden, Nordstream AG and The German Federal Agency for Nature Conservation (BfN) as reported in Waterbird Populations and Pressures in the Baltic Sea TemaNord 2011:550. This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
map_acknowledgement: SEPA, WWF, Nordstream AG, NORDEN SOWBAS, BfN
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer is based on data from 2007-2009 and is explicitly stated as 'fairly outdated'. The recommendation is to update it with 'more new input data' and potentially facilitate insight into 'temporal trends'. This requires new data integration, which is a moderate improvement. While the core methodology (GAM) might remain, the input data needs significant refreshing.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Updating the product with new input data would require new field surveys (aerial, shore, ship-based) for the specified seabird species, followed by modeling. This involves significant coordination, resource investment for surveys, and technical expertise for data processing and modeling, placing it in the 'medium' difficulty category. It's not a simple data update from an existing, continuously collected source.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer models seabird density based on field surveys and environmental data. Seabird distribution and abundance are primarily determined by direct observation (surveys) and their interaction with environmental factors like prey availability, water depth, and ice cover. While some environmental factors (e.g., sea surface temperature, ice cover) can be derived from satellites, the direct observation of seabirds and their specific species-level densities cannot be effectively replaced or directly measured by current satellite remote sensing technologies. Satellite data alone cannot generate or significantly improve the core seabird density information.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical imagery and national land cover data. These datasets are suitable for terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping, land use, and some water quality parameters in clear, shallow waters. They do not provide direct information on seabird populations, their distribution in offshore waters, or the specific environmental variables (e.g., prey fish distribution) that are critical for modeling seabird densities in the open Baltic Sea. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden data cannot directly generate or significantly improve this specific marine planning layer.

name: Anoxia background
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster intends to show the predicted risk of anoxia in marine benthic substrates in Sweden coastal and offshore waters. A value of 1 represents a high risk of anoxia (i.e. substrate with < 2 mg/L O2) and a value 0 represents a low risk of anoxia (i.e. substrate with > 6 mg/L O2). The layer is based on analysis and combination of a number of primary data sources. Sediment sample observational data (binary i.e. anoxic or oxic) from the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU) has been combined with near bottom oxygen concentration measurements from in-water sampling and predicted levels from biochemical modelling from the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI). Open depth data from the Swedish Maritime Administration is used as a spatial predictor, and shoreline complexity from the Swedish Land Survey is used as a predictor variable along the shoreline. Various secondary data sources are also used by SMHI in their biochemical modelling. This data is subject to a range of limitations and should be interpreted as an unvalidated benthic anoxia risk map. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the
formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other
purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data
sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad risk för syrebrist i marina bentiska substrat i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett värde av 1 motsvarar hög risk för syrebrist (substrat med < 2 mg/L O2), och ett värde av 0 motsvarar låg risk för syrebrist (substrat med > 6 mg/ L O2). Lagret är baserat på analys och en kombination av ett antal primära datakällor. Observationsdata från sedimentprover (binärt dvs. anoxiska eller oxiska) från Sveriges geologiska undersökning (SGU) har kombinerats med mätningar av syrgaskoncentration nära botten vid provtagning i vatten och beräknada nivåer från biokemisk modellering från Sveriges meteorologiska och hydrologiska institut (SMHI). Öppen djupdata från Sjöfartsverket har använts som en rumslig prediktor och kustlinjekomplexitet från Lantmäteriet används som en prediktorvariabel längs kustlinjen. Olika sekundära datakällor används också av SMHI i deras biokemiska modellering. Denna data innehar en rad begränsningar, och bör tolkas som en icke validerad riskkarta över bentisk syrebrist. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Lineage SMHIs source data was provided to SGU in various formats. Measured data on oxygen has been interpolated by SMHI into continuous data layers as part of the Swedish contribution to the Emodnet European Marine Data Network and can be downloaded as NetCDF files http://sextant.ifremer.fr/en/web/emodnet_chemistry/catalogue. In addition predictions of oxygen concentrations based on biochemical modelling were also available for the inshore environment and for the offshore environment for the Baltic, More information on SMHIs modelling can be found here: http://www.smhi.se/en/research/research- departments/oceanography/biogeochemical-modelling-1.31327 . SGU data was sourced from their data archive and covers the period 1993 to 2014. Data detailing anoxic or oxic substrate conditions is determined from visual methods, more details of the data collection method can be found in the combined SGU SMHI report from 2008 http://www.smhi.se/polopoly_fs/1.1975!/oceanografi_95%5B1%5D.pdf The data processing followed the following steps: 1. Interpolation of SGU samples using an inverse distance weighting
algorithm
2. Merging of SMHIs inshore model, offshore model for the Baltic and
interpolated measurement data using an overlay approach (mosaic) in
the order mentioned.
3. Combination of the SGU interpolation and the SMHI models where
overlapping using a Mean Average (assuming equal validity in models)
4. Apply a spatial smoothing filter (mean average over 7km)
5. Adjustment of the model to take into account a trend showing very
low anoxia risk in SGU samples in shallow water to 10m (globally) and
an increasing risk to 70m in the Baltic Proper.
The steps above are described in more detail in a data processing log
created by SGU and provided to SWAM. This can be provided on
request.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This dataset is created from models based on water column source data from two different time periods (1993-2014 and 1960-2014) and historical sediment data (1950-2014). There is significant temporal variability (both annual and decadal) in oxygen conditions which are not represented in this data product. We combine all the available data with the intention of showing maximum spatial extent of annual average sediment anoxia over the range of all input data (1950-2014). The modelled data from SMHI lack spatial resolution inshore so depth is used as a proxy based on a observed trend of increasing sediment anoxia with depth in SGU's sediment records. Anoxia is also assumed to increase in areas with complex shorelines (due to decreased currents) but there is no data available to confirm this trend.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: At present there is insufficient data with the descriptive resolution and spatial precision to produce an reliable (i.e. empirically validated) model of current (or even decadal annual average) sediment anoxia conditions. SGU now have an oxygen sensor attached to their camera system which is used to sample water column anoxia. We recommend collection of field sample data detailing oxygen content of the sediment samples along with nutrient and geophysical and geochemical conditions which could lead to a better understanding of the spatial dynamics and therefore enable the production of a spatial models which can use proxies (depth, sediment composition and water column data) to predict benthic conditions and which can be used for model validation. Autonomous field sampling (i.e. data nodes and landers) is a potential solution to better data as technology improves. https://viewintotheblue.com/underwater-science-nodes
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Anoxia background" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI) and the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to the Geological Survey of Sweden and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer is explicitly described as an 'unvalidated benthic anoxia risk map' with significant temporal variability not represented. The recommendations call for 'insufficient data with descriptive resolution and spatial precision to produce a reliable (i.e. empirically validated) model' and suggest 'collection of field sample data detailing oxygen content of the sediment samples along with nutrient and geophysical and geochemical conditions' and 'autonomous field sampling'. This indicates a need for fundamental methodological overhaul and new data collection protocols to achieve a validated and more accurate model, moving beyond a 'risk map' to a predictive model.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, such as extensive new field sampling (sediment oxygen, nutrients, geophysical/geochemical conditions), developing spatial models that use proxies for prediction, and establishing autonomous field sampling, requires significant resources, advanced technical expertise, and extensive coordination. This goes beyond simple data updates or minor methodological refinements.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: While direct measurement of benthic anoxia is not possible from satellites, satellite remote sensing can provide valuable proxy data or contextual information. For instance, satellite-derived bathymetry (SDB) could refine depth data, which is used as a proxy for anoxia. Satellite observations of water column properties (e.g., chlorophyll-a, turbidity, sea surface temperature) could potentially inform biochemical models or identify areas prone to stratification, which can contribute to anoxia. Although not a direct measure, these could contribute to improving the predictive models mentioned in the recommendations.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 data and national land cover, has limited direct applicability to improving this specific marine anoxia layer. Sentinel-2's optical capabilities are limited to shallow, clear waters and are not designed for deep-water marine chemistry or benthic conditions. While shoreline complexity is a predictor variable, Sentinel-2's contribution to this specific aspect would be minor compared to the need for in-situ benthic oxygen data and advanced marine modeling. The core data gaps (sediment oxygen, nutrient data, and validation of benthic conditions) cannot be addressed by DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings.

name: Cod
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: The raster layer intends to show the predicted distribution of Cod in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to zero abundance and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high relative abundance. Underlying data are from three sources and consist of modelled data, catch per unit effort data, and catch data (landings) all covering the period 2010-2015. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad distribution av torsk i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen abundans, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ abundans. Underlagsdata härrör från tre källor och består av modellerad data, fångst per enhet ”effort data”, och fångstdata (landning) vilka täcker perioden 2010-2015. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna. Notera - ett data prcocessingfel varr identifierades under slutstadiet av dataproduktion. Värdena för torskhabitatet kring Stockholm och Nordöstra Gotland (i synnerhet) är något lägre än vad de borde vara. Detta kommer att åtgärdas i nästa datauppdatering.
lineage: Data are Cod modelled data from the Baltic Sea, catch per unit effort data from a survey of the West coast and catch data (landings) from commercial fishing in the Gulf of Bothnia. All datasets cover the period 2010-2015. Data processing took the following steps: 1. Sum catch data from commercial fishing and survey data from the West coast within their respective ICES rectangles. 2. Sum Cod models for large and small cod to encompass all cod sizes. 3. Extrapolate data to the coastline in areas that were not covered by the Cod models 4. Normalise rasters. 5. Combine the rasters from the different methods. 6. Adjust to SYMPHONY requirements.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: Outside of the Baltic proper ICES source data used in the production of this dataset - these data are generally mapped to the ICES rectangle scale (30x60nm) and as a consequence there is very little information about the spatial variability within these areas.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Predictive modelling of cod using relevant environmental variables may be possible for the entire area of interest. If valid this approach would provide a dataset with a higher descriptive resolution ouside the Baltic.
data_authoring_organisation: Sveriges Lantbruksuniversitet Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua)
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions:
This "Cod" dataset is a derived from fisheries monitoring data collected by Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources
(SLU Aqua) and from the unpublished doctoral
dissertation of Alessandro Orio which restricts use
outside of Symphony.
. This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative
Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY
4.0). It is attributed to Swedish University of
Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources
(SLU Aqua) and was produced on behalf of the Swedish
Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM).
This data set and any data derived from it are not to be
used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The recommendations explicitly suggest 'Predictive modelling of cod using relevant environmental variables' for the entire area, which would fundamentally change the data generation approach from primarily observational/catch-based to a more sophisticated modeling approach. This would provide a 'higher descriptive resolution' and address the major limitation of 'very little information about the spatial variability' outside the Baltic proper. This constitutes a major methodological overhaul and a re-conceptualization of how the data is generated.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing 'Predictive modelling of cod using relevant environmental variables' for the entire area would require significant expertise in marine ecological modeling, access to and integration of various environmental datasets (e.g., temperature, salinity, bathymetry, prey distribution), and validation of the models. This is a complex task, especially given the current reliance on ICES rectangle scale data outside the Baltic, implying a need for new data collection or sophisticated downscaling techniques. It represents a new methodology of large complexity.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Cod distribution is primarily influenced by factors like water temperature, salinity, depth, and prey availability. While satellite remote sensing can provide sea surface temperature and potentially some proxies for primary productivity (chlorophyll-a), it cannot directly measure cod abundance, salinity at depth, or detailed bathymetry across the entire water column relevant for cod. Furthermore, key data sources for cod distribution (catch per unit effort, catch data, and modelled data) are inherently non-satellite. Satellite data alone cannot generate or significantly improve this layer's core information, though some environmental variables for predictive modeling might be partially derived from satellite (e.g., SST). However, the primary data for cod distribution remains non-satellite.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are highly relevant for terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping (e.g., land use, coastal development, some shallow water habitats). However, they do not provide direct information on marine fish distribution (like cod), nor do they offer the oceanographic parameters (e.g., deep-water temperature, salinity, currents, prey distribution) necessary for predictive cod modeling in offshore and deeper waters. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden data cannot directly help generate or improve this layer.

name: Herring
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
The raster layer intends to show the predicted distribution of Herring in Swedish marine waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to zero abundance and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high relative abundance. Underlying data are from two sources and consist of acoustic density data (fish/area) and catch data (landings 2010-2015) from commercial fishing. The raster provides a good indication of
fish distribution for each ICES rectangle however
uncertainty is considerably higher for each 250 m cell as the
data provides no information on spatial variation within
ICES rectangles. These data were created as a data input
layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning
unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water
Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess
the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in
Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at
plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is
only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data
sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad distribution av sill i svenska havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen abundans, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ abundans. Underlagsdata härrör från två källor och består av data från akustikstudier (fisk/område) och fångstdata (landning 2010-2015) från kommersiellt fiske. Rastret ger en god indikation på fiskdistribution inom varje ICES- rektangel, men osäkerheten är avsevärt högre för varje 250 m-cell eftersom denna data inte ger någon information om rumslig variation inom ICES-rektanglar. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: Data are Herring acoustic density data (fish/area) from the Baltic International Acoustic Survey (BIAS) and Herring catch data (landings 2010-2015) from commercial fishing. Data processing took the following steps: 1. Sum catch data from commercial fishing into ICES rectangles. 2. Extrapolate acoustic density data (BIAS) to the coastline. 3. Combine the rasters from the different methods. 4. Adjust to SYMPHONY requirements and normalise.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The ICES source data used in the production of this dataset are generally mapped to the ICES rectangle scale (30x60nm) and as a consequence there is very little information about the spatial variability within these areas.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Predictive modelling of herring using relevant environmental variables may be possible. If valid this approach would likely provide a dataset with a higher descriptive resolution.

This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua) and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states that 'uncertainty is considerably higher for each 250 m cell as the data provides no information on spatial variation within ICES rectangles' and recommends 'Predictive modelling of herring using relevant environmental variables may be possible. If valid this approach would likely provide a dataset with a higher descriptive resolution.' This indicates a fundamental limitation in the current data's spatial resolution and a need for a complete shift from aggregated observational data to a predictive modeling approach, which constitutes a major improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing predictive modeling using environmental variables, as recommended, requires significant expertise in ecological modeling, data integration from various sources (environmental variables), and validation. While not 'new methodology of large complexity with no established techniques', it's a substantial undertaking beyond simple data updates or minor methodological tweaks, placing it in the 'medium' difficulty category.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can provide crucial environmental variables for predictive modeling of marine species distribution. Parameters like Sea Surface Temperature (SST), chlorophyll-a (an indicator of primary productivity and thus food availability), and potentially sea surface height anomalies (related to currents and upwelling) are all derivable from satellite observations and are highly relevant for modeling fish distribution. While herring distribution itself isn't directly observable by satellite, the environmental factors influencing it are.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 data and national land cover. Sentinel-2 is an optical sensor primarily for land and shallow coastal waters, and its capabilities are limited for deep-water marine environmental parameters like SST or chlorophyll-a, which are critical for herring distribution modeling. The national land cover data is irrelevant for this marine species layer. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings are not directly applicable to generating or improving this specific marine layer.

name: Rivermouth fish
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: The raster layer intends to show the predicted diversity of river mouth fish species in Swedish marine waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no fish species present and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a high relative number of fish species present. Underlying data are from two sources and consist of presence data (1952-2015) of several river mouth fish species. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad mångfald av älvmynningsfisk i svenska havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen förekomst av fisk, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ förekomst av fisk. Underlagsdata härrör från två källor och består av förekomstdata (1952- 2015) av flera olika älvmynningsfiskarter. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Data are Salmon, Trout, and Eel presence data (1952-2015) in river mouths, from the Swedish Electrofishing Register (Svenskt Elfiskeregister - SERS), as well as Sea Lamprey presence data in rivermouths from the report “Åtgärdsprogram för diadroma arter i Västerhavet med fokus havsnejonöga”. Data processing took the following steps:
1. Aggregate presence data into a single file.
2. Calculate the number of species at each river mouth.
3. Calculate a buffer area around each river mouth.
4. Adjust to SYMPHONY requirements and normalise.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: No limitations identified by SLU
recommendations_for_data_improvement: No recommendations suggested by SLU
data_authoring_organisation: Sveriges Lantbruksuniversitet Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua)
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Rivermouth fish" dataset is a derived from fisheries monitoring data collected by Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua) and recorded in SERS "Svenskt ElfiskeRegiSter". This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua) and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: While 'No limitations identified' and 'No recommendations suggested' are stated by SLU, the lineage reveals that the data are based on presence data from 1952-2015 for only a few specific species (Salmon, Trout, Eel, Sea Lamprey). The layer aims to show 'predicted diversity of river mouth fish species', but the underlying data are limited to presence of only four species. This suggests a significant gap between the layer's stated purpose (diversity) and its actual data basis (presence of a few species). Expanding the species base to truly represent 'diversity' would be a moderate improvement. Additionally, the temporal period ends in 2015, suggesting a need for updating with more recent data.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Expanding the species base to genuinely represent 'diversity' would require integrating new data sources for other river mouth fish species, which could involve new sampling programs or accessing different biological databases. This is more complex than simply updating existing data. Updating the temporal coverage (post-2015) for the current species would be low difficulty, but the broader goal of representing 'diversity' makes it medium difficulty due to the need for new data integration and potentially new methodologies for diversity prediction.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The layer is based on in-situ presence data of specific fish species. Satellite remote sensing cannot directly detect fish species or their diversity. While satellites can provide environmental parameters (e.g., water quality, temperature, coastal habitat) that might influence fish distribution, they cannot generate the core 'presence data' or 'diversity' information for these specific fish species. The data are fundamentally biological and require direct sampling or observation.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical imagery and national land cover data. These datasets are useful for mapping coastal land use, habitat types, and water clarity in shallow areas. However, they cannot directly provide presence data for specific fish species (Salmon, Trout, Eel, Sea Lamprey) or assess their diversity. The core data for this layer are biological observations, which are not within the scope of DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The primary limitation is the lack of spatial variability within ICES rectangles, and the recommendation is to use 'predictive modelling of Sprat using relevant environmental variables' to achieve 'higher descriptive resolution'. This constitutes a fundamental methodological overhaul from aggregating existing survey/catch data to a predictive modeling approach, which is a major improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Predictive modeling using environmental variables is a well-established technique in marine ecology (e.g., Species Distribution Models). While it requires expertise in data science and marine biology, and access to relevant environmental data, it's not an entirely new methodology without established techniques. It falls within the 'moderate technical expertise, coordination, and resource investment' category.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Sprat distribution is primarily driven by biological factors (abundance, behavior) and environmental variables like temperature, salinity, and prey availability. While satellites can measure sea surface temperature and some ocean color parameters, they cannot directly measure fish abundance, acoustic density, or catch data. The key environmental variables for Sprat distribution (e.g., salinity, deeper water temperature, prey) are not directly or sufficiently measured by current satellite remote sensing for this purpose. Acoustic surveys and in-situ sampling remain crucial.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are focused on terrestrial and shallow coastal environments and are not suitable for monitoring pelagic fish like Sprat, which inhabit deeper waters and whose distribution is not directly observable or inferable from land cover or optical imagery. The data sources for Sprat (acoustic surveys, commercial catch) are entirely marine and biological, outside the scope of DigitalEarthSweden's offerings.

summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad distribution av siklöja i svenska havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen abundans, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ abundans. Underlagsdata består av fångstdata (2010- 2015) från kommersiellt fiske. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: Data processing took the following steps: 1. Interpolate catch data using a search window with a radius of 5 km (home range). 2. Compensate the distribution to account for the ratio of land/water within the home range for each cell. 3. Adjust to SYMPHONY requirements and normalise.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: No limitations identified by SLU
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Predictive modelling of Vendace using relevant environmental variables may be possible. If valid this approach would likely provide a dataset with a higher descriptive resolution.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The recommendation explicitly states that 'Predictive modelling of Vendace using relevant environmental variables may be possible. If valid this approach would likely provide a dataset with a higher descriptive resolution.' This suggests a fundamental shift from interpolated catch data to a predictive model, which constitutes a major methodological overhaul and a significant improvement in resolution and potentially accuracy, moving beyond simple interpolation of historical landings.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing predictive modeling, while a significant improvement, is a well-established technique in marine science. It would require identifying relevant environmental variables, potentially integrating new datasets, and developing or applying statistical/machine learning models. This is a 'medium' difficulty task, requiring expertise and resources but not entirely new, unproven methodologies.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The underlying data for this layer is commercial fishing catch data (landings). Vendace distribution is likely influenced by environmental factors such as water temperature, salinity, and prey availability. While satellites can measure some environmental variables (e.g., sea surface temperature, chlorophyll-a), they cannot directly measure Vendace abundance or catch data. Furthermore, the recommendation is for 'predictive modelling of Vendace using relevant environmental variables', and while some of these variables could be satellite-derived, the core data (Vendace presence/abundance) is not directly observable by satellite. The current layer is based on in-situ catch data, which satellites cannot replicate.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are suitable for terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping, land use, and some water quality parameters in clear, shallow waters. Vendace are a marine fish species, and their distribution is not directly observable or inferable from Sentinel-2 or land cover data. DigitalEarthSweden does not provide the oceanographic or biological data necessary to generate or improve a Vendace distribution layer, especially one based on catch data or requiring predictive modeling of marine species.

name: Eel migration
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
The raster layer intends to show the predicted migration routes of Eels in Swedish marine waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to zero abundance and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high relative abundance. Underlying data are coastal catch data (1999-2003). Due to a large lack of
knowledge/information on Eels This raster has high
uncertainty and does not show migration routes outside of
the coastal areas. These data were created as a data input
layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning
unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water
Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess
the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in
Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at
plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is
only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data
sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad ålvandring i svenska havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar noll abundans, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ abundans. Underlagsdata härrör från fångstdata från kustfiske (1999-2003). På grund av stor brist på kunskap/information om ål, har detta rasterskikt hög osäkerhet och påvisar ingen ålvandring utanför kustområden. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: Data are Eel catch data (1999-2003) from coastal areas. Data processing took the following steps: 1. Convert catch data from polygons to rasters. 2. Add to raster together with a cell resolution of 10 km2¬. 3. Interpolate using a search window with a radius of 20 km. 4. Adjust to SYMPHONY requirements and normalise.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: Due to a large lack of knowledge/information on Eels this layer has very high uncertainty and does not show migration routes outside of the coastal areas.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: No recommendations suggested by SLU

This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua) and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states 'very high uncertainty' and 'does not show migration routes outside of the coastal areas' due to a 'large lack of knowledge/information on Eels'. This indicates a fundamental data gap and methodological limitation that requires substantial new data collection (e.g., tracking studies, broader survey efforts) and potentially a complete re-conceptualization of how migration routes are predicted, moving beyond simple interpolated catch data. This goes beyond minor updates or integrating existing data.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Addressing the 'large lack of knowledge/information on Eels' and extending predictions beyond coastal areas would require significant resources for new data collection (e.g., acoustic telemetry, genetic studies, oceanographic modeling for larval transport), advanced biological modeling techniques, and extensive coordination among research institutions. This is a major scientific challenge, not just a data processing task.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Eel migration, particularly the oceanic phase, is primarily a biological phenomenon driven by internal cues and ocean currents. While satellites can provide oceanographic parameters like sea surface temperature and currents, these are indirect and insufficient to map specific migration routes of a highly mobile, subsurface organism like the eel. Direct observation or tracking of eels is not possible with current satellite technology. The underlying data are coastal catch data, which satellites cannot directly observe or improve upon for this specific purpose.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden's primary datasets (Sentinel-2 optical imagery and national land cover) are focused on terrestrial and shallow coastal environments. Eel migration, especially the crucial oceanic phase, occurs in deep waters and involves biological processes not detectable by these optical sensors. The data provided by DigitalEarthSweden would not contribute to understanding or mapping eel migration routes, nor would it improve the underlying coastal catch data.

name: Fish spawning
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: The raster layer intends to show a general picture of important areas for commercial fish spawning in Swedish marine waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no economic value for spawning and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to the highest economic value of spawning species. Underlying data are from two sources and consist of a depth model combined with the spawning area and spawning depth data of commercial fish species. This raster shows a measure of economic value by space based on the ratio between the economic value of each species and its calculated spawning area, summed for all species with an economic value> 100k per year for each marine plan area. The data were normalised on a linear scale for each plan area so a cell value of 100 on the West coast (North Sea) plan area equates to 25 species whereas on the East coast (Baltic) plan area it equates to 12 species and in the Northern plan area (Bottniskaviken) it equates to 5 species. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa en generell bild över viktiga områden för fisklek för kommersiella fiskarter i svenska havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen fisklek, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ fisklek hos kommersiella fiskarter. Underlagsdata härrör från två källor och består av en djupmodell kombinerat med lekområdes- och lekdjupdata över kommersiella fiskarter. Denna data visar ett mått på ekonomiskt värde per ytenhet baserad på kvoten mellan varje arts ekonomiska värde och dess beräknade lekarea, summerad för alla arter med ett ekonomiskt värde > 100 kkr per år för varje havsområde Data normaliseras på en linjär skala för varje område, ett cellvärde av 100 på västkusten (Nordsjön) motsvarar 25 arter, medan samma värde på östkusten (Östersjön) motsvarar 12 arter och i Bottniska viken motsvarar värdet 5 arter. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för
havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV).
Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den
kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska
vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av
denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter
vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
Viktiga lekområden för yrkesfiskets arter. Baserad på kvoten
mellan varje arts ekonomiska värde och dess beräknade
lekarea, summerad för alla arter med ett ekonomiskt värde >
100 kkr per år för varje havsområde
lineage: Data are from SLUs National Spawning Database (Nationella Lektidsdatabasen) and SYMPHONY’s depth raster. The Spawning Database receives information from a large number of sources. Information on each species is collated from available research. Data processing took the following steps: 1. Couple the National Spawning Database with area polygons. 2. Convert the National Spawning Database polygons to rasters. 3. Limit each species spawning area by depth. 4. Create plan area rasters for any commercial species (with an annual value over 100,000kr in that plan areas) 5 Sum rasters and rescale 0-100 for each plan area 6. Mosaic each summed plan area raster to a national product
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: No limitations identified by SLU
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Future versions of this raster can be supplemented with nursery grounds. The nursery database contains information about nursery habitat, which could be linked to the SGU substrate map.

contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua) and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The recommendation explicitly states that 'Future versions of this raster can be supplemented with nursery grounds.' This involves integrating a new dataset (nursery database) and potentially linking it to another (SGU substrate map), which constitutes a moderate improvement requiring new data integration and potentially new analytical steps beyond simple updates.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Integrating the nursery database and linking it to the SGU substrate map requires data processing, spatial analysis, and potentially methodological adjustments to combine these new data with the existing spawning data. This is more involved than a 'low' difficulty update but does not represent a 'high' difficulty overhaul or new methodology without established techniques.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The layer is based on a 'depth model combined with the spawning area and spawning depth data of commercial fish species' and 'economic value'. While satellite remote sensing can provide bathymetry in shallow waters (Satellite-Derived Bathymetry), the core data for this layer (fish spawning areas, species-specific depth preferences, and economic value) are derived from biological databases and economic assessments, which are not directly observable or derivable from satellite imagery. Satellite data cannot directly identify fish spawning grounds or their economic value. The recommendation to add 'nursery grounds' also relies on biological and habitat data not directly from satellites.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These are useful for terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping (e.g., substrate mapping in very clear, shallow waters, or coastal land use), but they do not provide the biological data on fish spawning or nursery grounds, nor the economic valuation data, which are central to this layer. While the SGU substrate map (mentioned in the recommendation) might be related to seabed characteristics, DigitalEarthSweden's capabilities are not directly applicable to generating or significantly improving the core biological and economic aspects of this marine fish spawning layer.

name: Abrasion bottom trawl
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster layer intends to show the predicted abrasion of benthic substrates as a consequence of bottom trawling in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. Underlying data are from two sources and consist of Surface Area Ratio (SAR) of trawling (OSPAR 2009-2013, and HELCOM 2009-2015) data. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no benthic abrasion by bottom trawling and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to abrasion (SAR ≥ 8.196288). The surface area ratios (SAR) of trawling are produced by summing total swept area of trawling within a measurement area and then normalize the swept area to the measurement area. Assuming that within the measurement area the trawling is evenly distributed the surface area ratio is interpreted as the number of times per unit of time the measurement area is trawled over. The swept area for a specific fishing vessel is estimated using modelled trawl door spread (for a specific fishery/gear) multiplied by the vms (vessel monitoring system) speed and vms ping interval for a vms signal/position representing benthic trawling. The total swept area within a measurement area is then the sum of all swept area positions, from all vessels within a measurement area. For these data a logarithmic relationship between trawl intensity SAR and benthic impact due to abrasion is assumed, however habitat specific susceptibility to trawling is not modelled so this is a simplistic assumption. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad störning av bentiska substrat som en konsekvens av bottentrålning i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Underlagsdata kommer från två källor och består av data över Surface Area Ratio (SAR) från trålning (OSPAR 2009-2013, och HELCOM 2009- 2015). Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen bentisk störning från bottentrålning, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar störning (SAR ≥ 8,196288). Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för
bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig
aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
SAR för trålning skapas genom att summera den totala arean
som trålats inom ett mätområde och sedan normaliseras det
trålade området till mätområdet. Det antas att trålningen
inom mätområdet är jämnt fördelad, varvid SAR tolkas som
antalet gånger per tidsenhet som området trålats. Det
trålade området för ett specifikt fiskefartyg beräknas genom
modellerad tråldörrsspridning (för ett specifikt
fiske/redskap) multiplicerat med vms-hastighet (vessel
monitoring system) och vms-pingintervall för en vms-
signal/position som representerar bentisk trålning. Det
totala trålade området inom mätområdet är då summan av
alla trålade områden, från alla fartyg inom mätområdet.
För dessa data antas ett logaritmiskt förhållande mellan
trålningsintensitets-SAR och bentisk påverkan på grund av
störning, dock är habitatspecifik känslighet inte modellerat
så detta är ett förenklat antagande. Denna data skapades
som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat
av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och
vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för
bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig
aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Data are internationally collected data on bottom trawling impact produced by the ICES working group on spatial fisheries data (ICES WGSFD). Standardized products on surface area ratio (SAR) of trawling were downloaded from the working group link on ICES homepage. The method is described in the working group reports (ICES Working Group Spatial Fisheries Data report 2016), but in short the SAR of trawling are produced by summing total swept area of trawling within a measurement area and then normalize the swept area to the measurement area. Assuming that within the measurement area the trawling is evenly distributed the SAR is interpreted as the number of times per unit of time the measurement area is trawled over. The swept area for a specific fishing vessel is estimated using modelled trawl door spread (for a specific fishery/gear) multiplied by the vms speed and vms ping interval for a vms signal/position representing fishery. The total swept area within a measurement area is then the sum of all swept area
positions, from all vessels within a measurement area.
The underlying data has been aggregated yearly on a
geographic grid of resolution 0.05 degree (approximately 1.5
x 3 nm square at 57 N). Yearly data on total SAR are
produced in the HELCOM (the Baltic including Kattegat)
and OSPAR (North East Atlantic incl. Kattegat) region
respectively. Data are available for the years 2009 – 2013 in
the HELCOM region and 2009-2015 in the OSPAR region.
Data are available as spatial polygons.
Each year’s polygon dataset were projected into the
Symphony projection ETRS1989 LAEA. Further the
polygons were rasterized on the symphony grid using mean
values if several polygons overlay the same raster grid cell.
Averages of SAR values are calculated (introducing zero
values in NA raster cells) over the time periods (2009-2015
for OSPAR and 2009-2013 for HELCOM) and the Kattegat
area where masked from the HELCOM data set. Finally the
two data sets were added and save as
'Bottom_trawling_intensity_mean_SAR.tif'
The raster was normalized by dividing the data set by the
maximum SAR value in the Swedish exclusive economic
zone (EEZ): maxEEZ SAR = 8.196288
From this underlying data set, representing swept area of
bottom trawlers, a logarithmic response proxy was derived
representing sedimentation impact from trawling and these
data were rescaled on a 0-1 scale.
Uncertainty of this layer is set to 0.5 representing a “good”
model, in the whole region as the data are almost complete
international data (representing vessels >12 m), they are
averages over several years and thus represent a large part of
the total trawling effort and resource outtake but aggregated
into larger cells (0.05 degree resolution) and partly
validated. Also compared to traditional proxies for bottom
trawling like kW*fishing hours, the SAR values takes into
account typical trawl widths for different fishing fleets.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This bottom impact layer aims to describe the impact of bottom trawling on benthic habitats. This bottom-trawling index is used as a proxy for this impact and a logarithmic relationship between trawl intensity and benthic impact is used. This a is simplified assumption - habitat specific susceptibility to trawling is not modelled.
recommendations_for_data_improvement:
The source data for Symphony should continue to be based on international data. Work should continue to increase the availability of data volumes collected today by ICES within WGSFD. Current available data is not divided into pelagic / demersal species. Official landing statistics per ICES box could be used to weight trawl index for catches per box and,
for example, per demersal / pelagic target species.
New research (Benthis - 7th Framework Program and Trawling - Best Practice Project) is
currently underway to develop indicators for use in, inter alia, the Marine Directive. These
proposed indicators are based on a mechanistic link between trawl intensity and habitat
specific benthic responses. This are therefore different from previous expert-based
sensitivity estimates and the benefits of these kind of data have been highlighted in ICES
advice. The indicator data being created in the Benthis project will have the advantage of
being normalized to the interval [0.1] and will therefore be suitable for future Symphony
updates.
Work is also ongoing to include not only the direct physical impact (abrasion/mechanical
damage) but also sedimentation. Future data products should, if possible, consist of the
internationally produced indicators. In order to improve these indicators, it is primarily
knowledge about habitats and bottom type that should be improved - funding support for
participation in any research and development projects that would help to continue this
development are recommended.
