This derived dataset is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua) and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states that it uses a 'simplified assumption' of a logarithmic relationship between trawl intensity and benthic impact, and 'habitat specific susceptibility to trawling is not modelled'. The recommendations highlight ongoing research (Benthis project) that aims to develop indicators based on a 'mechanistic link between trawl intensity and habitat specific benthic responses', which would be a fundamental shift from the current expert-based sensitivity estimates. Furthermore, the recommendation to include sedimentation impact in addition to direct physical impact, and to improve knowledge about habitats and bottom type, points to a need for substantial methodological overhaul and new data integration beyond simple updates. This indicates a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, such as incorporating habitat-specific susceptibility and mechanistic links, would require significant new research, data collection (e.g., detailed habitat mapping, potentially through in-situ surveys or advanced acoustic methods), and complex modeling. The Benthis project is explicitly mentioned as 'new research' underway, implying that these are not readily available, off-the-shelf solutions. Improving knowledge about habitats and bottom types, and integrating sedimentation impacts, would also be resource-intensive and require advanced technical expertise. This points to a 'high' difficulty level.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The layer focuses on benthic abrasion from bottom trawling, which is a physical impact on the seafloor. While satellites can provide some information relevant to marine planning (e.g., sea surface temperature, chlorophyll), they cannot directly measure or monitor bottom trawling abrasion, trawl door spread, or the physical impact on benthic habitats. These require in-situ measurements, VMS data, and potentially acoustic surveys for habitat mapping. Satellite-derived bathymetry has limitations in deeper waters and for detailed habitat characterization needed for this specific layer. Therefore, satellite remote sensing cannot directly generate or significantly improve this layer's core data.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical imagery and national land cover data. Sentinel-2 is limited to terrestrial and shallow coastal waters, and its optical nature means it cannot penetrate deep enough to monitor benthic habitats or bottom trawling impacts in the offshore and deeper coastal waters where trawling occurs. The national land cover data is also terrestrial/coastal focused and not relevant for deep-sea benthic impact assessment. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings cannot help generate or improve this specific marine layer, which requires detailed sub-surface information and VMS data.

name: Artificial reef
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show presence of artificial reef structures (i.e. bridges, lighthouses at sea, wind power turbines, wrecks etc.) in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. The surface area of artificial reefs has not been determined. Data shows only the occurrence of artificial structures that can form artificial reefs with a resolution of 250 x 250 m. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no presence and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to presence. Underlying data are from several different sources and consist of presence data in the form of shapefiles. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa förekomst av artificiella revstrukturer (dvs. broar, fyrar till havs, vindkraftsverk, vrak etc.) i svenska kust och havsvatten. Den ytmässiga
omfattningen av artificiella rev har inte bestämts. Data visar
endast förekomst av artificiella strukturer som kan skapa
artificiella rev med en upplösning på 250 x 250 m. Ett
cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen förekomst, och ett cellvärde
av 100 motsvarar förekomst. Underlagsdata härrör från ett
flertal källor och består av förekomstdata i form av shape-
filer. Detta data skapades som ett data input layer för
’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för
havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV).
Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den
kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska
vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av
denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter
vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: Vectorised layers of structures at sea/ocean were converted to a raster where presence of structures was represented by a cell value of 100 and absence of structures was represented by a cell value of 0. Checks of the layer showed that distribution of the reef effect was, in general, less than 250m from the structure (i.e. one grid cell). Several data sources were combined: National road database/Bridge and Tunnel management (the Swedish Transport Administration (TRV), NVDB/Batman, shapefile, polyline), light houses, bridges and train bridges (the Swedish mapping, cadastral and land registration authority, Fastighetskartan, shapefile, polyline), ship wreck occurrences around Sweden (Swedish National Heritage Board (RAA), Fornminnesregistret (FMIS), shapefile, point), shipwrecks in Estonia (Estonian National Heritage Board, shapefile, point), shipwrecks in Denmark (the Danish Agency for Culture, shapefile, point), ship wrecks (the Government of Åland, shapefile, point). Discussion of the method occurred between WSP (consultant), TRV (data source) and SWaM (client). More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The surface of the reef can not be read from this substrate. The result of modelling where these data are included should therefore be interpreted with caution.
recommendations_for_data_improvement:
Gather attribution which can be used to predict the surface area and predict impacts or benefits of habitat change. For example data on the type of exposed substrates may be used to predict beneficial effects of artificial habitat (e.g. block form, ph balanced concrete
armouring) vs. low quality substrate (e.g. plastic culvert pipe).

data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: marine environment, abiotic environment, benthic ecosystem

This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states a major limitation: 'The surface of the reef can not be read from this substrate.' and recommends 'Gather attribution which can be used to predict the surface area and predict impacts or benefits of habitat change.' This requires a fundamental shift from simple presence/absence to quantitative spatial extent and qualitative assessment of habitat type/quality, which is a significant conceptual and data collection overhaul.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: While the improvement is large, the recommendation suggests gathering 'attribution' like 'type of exposed substrates' and 'block form, ph balanced concrete armouring' vs. 'plastic culvert pipe'. This implies a need for more detailed in-situ data collection or integration of more granular existing engineering/construction data, which is feasible but requires coordination and potentially new data acquisition protocols. It's not a 'high' difficulty as it doesn't necessarily require entirely new, unproven methodologies, but it's more than just integrating existing data.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The layer focuses on artificial reef structures like bridges, lighthouses, wind turbines, and wrecks. While some large surface structures (bridges, wind turbines) might be visible from high-resolution satellite imagery, the primary limitation is determining the 'surface area of the reef' and the 'type of exposed substrates' or 'quality' of the artificial habitat. Satellite remote sensing, even with high resolution, cannot effectively penetrate water to map the detailed underwater surface area or material composition of these structures, nor can it identify submerged wrecks with the required detail for habitat assessment. This requires in-situ surveys (e.g., acoustic, ROV, diver surveys).
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden's primary offerings (Sentinel-2 and national land cover) are not suitable for addressing the core limitations of this layer. Sentinel-2 is optical and has limited water penetration, making it ineffective for mapping submerged artificial reef surface areas or substrate types. The national land cover data is terrestrial. While large coastal structures might be visible, the critical information needed (underwater surface area, material type, habitat quality) cannot be derived from these datasets. The layer's focus is on marine structures and their underwater 'reef effect', which is beyond the capabilities of DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings.

name: Rough bottom aphotic
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster indicates 'hard bottom' substrate in shallow (<60m) aphotic water areas. It is supplementary to the Symphony 'Hard bottom deep' layer. This raster is modelled using morphology metrics calculated from depth data provided by the Swedish Maritime Administration and expert judgement based on comparison with geological surveys undertaken by the Swedish Geological Survey (in areas surveyed by both agencies). A cell value of 0 is equivilent to zero probability of the prescence of hard bottom and a cell value of 100 is equivilent to a high probability of presence. Underlying data are from 'best available' historical data with variable quality: refer to the associated uncertainty layer for for information on data quality. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt indikerar utbredning av "hård botten" substrat i grunda (>60m) afotisk havsområden. Det kompletterar "Symphony Hard Bottom Deep", men data beräknas med bathymetriska källa data (från Sjöfartsverket). Data var tolkad med expertbedömning jämförelse med geologiska undersökningar som gjorts av den svenska geologiska undersökningen i områdena som kartläggs av båda myndigheterna. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen
sannolikhet för förekomst, och ett cellvärde av 100
motsvarar hög sannolikhet för förekomst. Underliggande
data är från "bästa tillgängliga" historiska data med variabel
kvalitet: hänvisa till det associerade osäkerhetslagret för
information om datakvalitet. Denna data skapades som ett
data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av
enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och
vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för
bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig
aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
This dataset was created by combining a range of seabed complexity metrics which were calculated in ArcGIS (with the spatial analyst extension) on a 10m resolution depth model maintained by the Swedish Maritime Agency (SMA). The indata to this analysis are from a 'best available' 10m resolution depth grid known as DIS (depth information system). Although the data are gridded to 10m the it is important to be aware that the input data are of highly varying quality. Refer to the associated map of spatial uncertainty for this layer to understand where major data gaps exist. DIS contains data which can be categorised into three quality classes. The highest quality data are collected using from modern techniques (for example multibeam echosounder surveys) and provide full coverage depth data (this is mostly restricted to shipping lanes), these data are charted to international standards (IHO S-44). The second category of data are those collected using modern techniques but which do not comply with international charting standards (although are still very high resolution for our intended use), they are data collected after 1987 (and therefore have a good positional accuracy) but they may not provide 100% coverage of the seafloor. The final, lower quality class of data are those collected before 1987 from historical chart archives based on data collected using older methods (e.g. single beam echosounders or lead-line surveys). In all classes of data it should be noted that depths may also be subject to a shoal-bias (reduced depths) which is standard practice for reducing potential collision risk in navigational charting. Due to mixing data resolutions data artefacts are likely to be present in the grid at boundaries between high resolution and low resolution surveys. The procedure used to produce the complexity datasets for Symphony were as follows: A) 6 complexity metrics and a hillshade were calculated:
1. Bathymetric Positioning Index (BPI) with an inner
diameter of 10m & outer diameter of 250m,
2. Bathymetric Positioning Index with ID:10m & OD:50m:
https://coast.noaa.gov/digitalcoast/tools/btm.html
3. Slope using a 10m grid with ArcGIS spatial analyst.
4. Slope using a 250m grid (downsampled from the 10m
grid) with ArcGIS spatial analyst.
5. Standard deviation of depth using a neighborhood size of
5 cells (50m) and the 10m grid with ArcGIS spatial analyst.
6. Standard deviation of depth using a neighborhood size of
25cell (250m) and the 10m grid with ArcGIS spatial analyst.
7. A hillshade layer for visual interpretation
Data were generated using a ArcGIS modelbuilder toolbox
developed by SGU, and executed by SMA.
B) All 6 complexity metrics where resampled to a 50m raster
(mean value) using ArcGIS
C) BPI metrics (1. and 2.) were stretched using an e log (base
2,718) function and rescaled between 0 and 10.
D) Slope and standard deviation metrics were also stretched
using an e log function and rescaled between 0 and 10.
E) A average (MEAN) raster was calcultated by combining
all the stretched and rescaled metrics from (C & D) .
F) Raster values between 2.5 and 7.5 in the raster (E) were
rescaled between 0 and 10 normalising the data to reflect
hardbottom features.
G) The resulting dataset was then downsampled from 50m
to 300m using the maximum value in a 6x6 cell
neighbourhood.
H) The result (G) was standardised to the Symphony grid
250m (nearest neighbour) with no-data set to zero.
I) The result (H) was normalised by substrating the
Symphony hardbottom dataset and the result rescaled
between 0 and 100.
J) The result (I) was split into 3 depth zones photic, and
aphotic below & aphotic above 60m
limitations_for_use_in_symphony:
There are some key limitations to be aware of when using these data: 1) Although this data product is based on the best available depth data - these depth data are of variable quality. In some areas there are even no data available: for example the area around Bratten Bohuslän coast. For further information on depth data uncertainty refer to
the confidence map associated with this dataset.
2) The model is based on data with a minimum mapping unit of 50m. This is not detailed
enough to pick out smaller depth / morphology variations and a consequence the dataset
may not help in the identification of certain geological features (e.g. sparse boulders on a flat
landscape) which may be important or sensitive habitat.
3) This dataset is intended to be used as a proxy for hard bottom bethic habitat (i.e.
identifying areas where SGUs geological survey data are unavailable) however this refers to
morphological complexity (and light penetration) and does not consider geological
substrate. Therefore areas which are 'complex' in terms of morphology may not always be
hard bottom.
4) Normalisation to reflect 'hard bottom' features was undertaken by visual comparison with
Symphony 'hard bottom' data - i.e. derived from SGUs geological maps. However, a perfect
match between complexity and hardbottom is not possible using expert judgement.
5) These data are currently only available for Sweden.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Further data collection is requied in areas with no data or low quality data. Rather than using two separate habitat proxy datasets in Symphony - morphological complexity (modelled from depth) and hardbottom (modelled from geological maps) the data on complexity should instead be used to drive a predictive model of substrate in combination with other physical predictor variables (such as currents & wave exposure) and ground validation data from point obserations. This work is in progress at SGU. This approach demonstrates a great deal of potential for improvement of national geological datasets. It is therefore reccomended that the approach is extended to surrounding countries (perhaps via international collaboration projects like Emodnet).

data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: marine ecosystem, marine biota, benthic ecosystem
other_restrictions:
This "Rough bottom aphotic" dataset is a derived in part from source data provided by the Swedish Maritime Adminstration (SMA). This derived dataset is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to the
Geological Survey of Sweden and was produced on
behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water
Management (SwAM). Data sources should be
acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from
it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The recommendations explicitly state a need for a fundamental shift from using morphological complexity as a proxy to developing a predictive model of substrate, combining morphology with other physical predictor variables (currents, wave exposure) and ground validation. This represents a major methodological overhaul and a move from a proxy to a more direct predictive approach, indicating 'large' improvement potential. Furthermore, there's a clear need for new data collection in areas with no or low-quality data.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing a new predictive model for substrate, integrating multiple physical variables, and requiring ground validation data is a complex undertaking. It involves advanced modeling techniques, potentially new data collection campaigns (as recommended), and significant coordination, especially if extended to surrounding countries. This aligns with 'high' difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: While the primary data for this layer is bathymetry, satellite remote sensing can contribute to improving the predictive model recommended. Satellite-derived bathymetry (SDB) could potentially fill some data gaps in shallow, clear waters, especially in areas where traditional survey data are sparse or low quality. Although SDB has limitations in deeper or turbid waters, it could supplement the existing depth data. Furthermore, satellite data could potentially contribute to understanding wave exposure or surface currents, which are recommended as additional predictor variables for the new substrate model. However, it's important to note that satellite data alone cannot fully generate this layer, as it relies heavily on detailed bathymetry and geological ground-truthing.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 data and national land cover, has limited direct applicability to this specific marine layer. Sentinel-2's capabilities for bathymetry are restricted to very shallow, clear waters, and it cannot provide the detailed morphological metrics derived from high-resolution echosounder data that form the basis of this layer. The layer focuses on aphotic, deeper waters (up to 60m) where optical satellite penetration is insufficient. While coastal land cover data might be relevant for broader coastal zone management, it does not directly contribute to mapping 'rough bottom aphotic' substrate. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings are not directly suitable for generating or significantly improving this specific marine layer.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The recommendations explicitly call for a fundamental methodological overhaul: 'Rather than using two separate habitat proxy datasets in Symphony - morphological complexity (modelled from depth) and hardbottom (modelled from geological maps) the data on complexity should instead be used to drive a predictive model of substrate in combination with other physical predictor variables (such as currents & wave exposure) and ground validation data from point obserations.' This is a shift from a proxy based on morphology to a predictive model of substrate, which constitutes a major improvement. Additionally, there's a need for 'further data collection in areas with no data or low quality data' and extending the approach to surrounding countries, indicating substantial new data collection and expansion.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended predictive model of substrate requires 'combining with other physical predictor variables (such as currents & wave exposure) and ground validation data from point observations', which implies advanced modeling techniques and significant data integration. The work is 'in progress at SGU', suggesting it's not a simple update. Extending the approach to surrounding countries via 'international collaboration projects like Emodnet' also points to extensive coordination and resource investment.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: While the layer focuses on deep aphotic water, satellite remote sensing can contribute to improving the 'predictive model of substrate' recommended. Satellite-derived bathymetry (SDB) could potentially improve the underlying depth data in shallower, clear waters, especially in areas with 'no data available' or 'low quality data' as mentioned in the limitations. Although SDB has depth limitations, it could provide valuable input for the 'best available' depth model, particularly in coastal areas. Additionally, satellite data on sea surface temperature or currents (though not directly for deep bottom) could potentially inform models of water column dynamics that influence substrate, or be used as proxy for wave exposure in coastal areas. However, the primary focus of this layer (deep aphotic hard bottom) is not directly observable by satellite.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover, is not directly applicable to improving this layer. The layer focuses on 'deep (>60m) aphotic water areas' and 'hard bottom' substrate. Sentinel-2's water depth penetration is limited to clear, shallow waters, and it lacks specialized oceanographic sensors for deep-water bathymetry or substrate characterization. The national land cover data is terrestrial/coastal and not relevant for deep marine environments. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings cannot directly help generate or improve this specific deep-water layer.

summary: This raster indicates 'hard bottom' substrate in photic water areas. It is supplementary to the Symphony 'Hard bottom deep' layer. This raster is modelled using morphology metrics calculated from depth data provided by the Swedish Maritime Administration and expert judgement based on comparison with geological surveys undertaken by the Swedish Geological Survey (in areas surveyed by both agencies). Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt indikerar utbredning av "hård botten" substrat i photiska zonen i havsområden. Det kompletterar "Symphony Hard Bottom Deep", men data beräknas med bathymetriska källa data (från Sjöfartsverket). Data var tolkad med expertbedömning jämförelse med geologiska undersökningar som gjorts av den svenska geologiska undersökningen i områdena som kartläggs av båda myndigheterna. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen sannolikhet för förekomst, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög sannolikhet för förekomst. Underliggande data är från "bästa tillgängliga" historiska data med variabel kvalitet: hänvisa till det associerade osäkerhetslagret för information om datakvalitet. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
This dataset was created by combining a range of seabed complexity metrics which were calculated in ArcGIS (with the spatial analyst extension) on a 10m resolution depth
model maintained by the Swedish Maritime Agency (SMA).
The indata to this analysis are from a 'best available' 10m
resolution depth grid known as DIS (depth information
system). Although the data are gridded to 10m the it is
important to be aware that the input data are of highly
varying quality. Refer to the associated map of spatial
uncertainty for this layer to understand where major data
gaps exist.
DIS contains data which can be categorised into three
quality classes. The highest quality data are collected using
from modern techniques (for example multibeam
echosounder surveys) and provide full coverage depth data
(this is mostly restricted to shipping lanes), these data are
charted to international standards (IHO S-44). The second
category of data are those collected using modern techniques
but which do not comply with international charting
standards (although are still very high resolution for our
intended use), they are data collected after 1987 (and
therefore have a good positional accuracy) but they may not
provide 100% coverage of the seafloor. The final, lower
quality class of data are those collected before 1987 from
historical chart archives based on data collected using older
methods (e.g. single beam echosounders or lead-line
surveys). In all classes of data it should be noted that depths
may also be subject to a shoal-bias (reduced depths) which is
standard practice for reducing potential collision risk in
navigational charting. Due to mixing data resolutions data
artefacts are likely to be present in the grid at boundaries
between high resolution and low resolution surveys.
The procedure used to produce the complexity datasets for
Symphony were as follows:
A) 6 complexity metrics and a hillshade were calculated:
1. Bathymetric Positioning Index (BPI) with an inner
diameter of 10m & outer diameter of 250m,
2. Bathymetric Positioning Index with ID:10m & OD:50m:
https://coast.noaa.gov/digitalcoast/tools/btm.html
3. Slope using a 10m grid with ArcGIS spatial analyst.
4. Slope using a 250m grid (downsampled from the 10m
grid) with ArcGIS spatial analyst.
5. Standard deviation of depth using a neighborhood size of
5 cells (50m) and the 10m grid with ArcGIS spatial analyst.
6. Standard deviation of depth using a neighborhood size of
25cell (250m) and the 10m grid with ArcGIS spatial analyst. 7. A hillshade layer for visual interpretation
Data were generated using a ArcGIS modelbuilder toolbox
developed by SGU, and executed by SMA.
B) All 6 complexity metrics where resampled to a 50m raster
(mean value) using ArcGIS
C) BPI metrics (1. and 2.) were stretched using an e log (base
2,718) function and rescaled between 0 and 10.
D) Slope and standard deviation metrics were also stretched
using an e log function and rescaled between 0 and 10.
E) A average (MEAN) raster was calcultated by combining
all the stretched and rescaled metrics from (C & D) .
F) Raster values between 2.5 and 7.5 in the raster (E) were
rescaled between 0 and 10 normalising the data to known
hardbottom features.
G) The resulting dataset was then downsampled from 50m
to 300m using the maximum value in a 6x6 cell
neighbourhood.
H) The result (G) was standardised to the Symphony grid
250m (nearest neighbour) with no-data set to zero.
I) The result (H) was further normalised by substrating the
Symphony hardbottom dataset and rescaling between 0 and
100.
J) The result (I) was split into 3 depth zones photic, and
aphotic below & aphotic above 60m
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: There are some key limitations to be aware of when using these data: 1) Although this data product is based on the best available depth data - these depth data are of variable quality. In some areas there are even no data available: for example the area around Bratten Bohuslän coast. For further information on depth data uncertainty refer to the confidence map associated with this dataset. 2) The model is based on data with a minimum mapping unit of 50m. This is not detailed enough to pick out smaller depth / morphology variations and a consequence the dataset may not help in the identification of certain geological features (e.g. sparse boulders on a flat landscape) which may be important or sensitive habitat. 3) This dataset is intended to be used as a proxy for hard bottom bethic habitat (i.e. identifying areas where SGUs geological survey data are unavailable) however this refers to morphological complexity (and light penetration) and does not consider geological substrate. Therefore areas which are 'complex' in terms of morphology may not always be hard bottom. 4) Normalisation to reflect 'hard bottom' features was undertaken by visual comparison with Symphony 'hard bottom' data - i.e. derived from SGUs geological maps. However, a perfect match between complexity and hardbottom is not possible using expert judgement. 5) These data are currently only available for Sweden.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Further data collection is requied in areas with no data or low quality data. Rather than using two separate habitat proxy datasets in Symphony - morphological complexity (modelled from depth) and hardbottom (modelled from geological maps) the data on complexity should instead be used to drive a predictive model of substrate in combination with other physical predictor variables (such as currents & wave exposure) and ground validation data from point obserations. This work is in progress at SGU. This approach demonstrates a great deal of potential for improvement of national geological datasets. It is therefore reccomended that the approach is extended to surrounding countries (perhaps via international collaboration projects like Emodnet).

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The recommendations explicitly suggest a fundamental methodological overhaul: moving from using morphological complexity as a proxy for hard bottom to developing a predictive model of substrate that combines morphology with other physical predictor variables (currents, wave exposure) and ground validation data. This is a 'work in progress at SGU' and represents a significant shift from the current approach, aiming for a 'great deal of potential for improvement of national geological datasets'. This aligns with the 'large' improvement criteria of 'fundamental methodological overhauls' and 'requiring advanced modeling techniques not currently used'.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: The recommendation involves developing a 'predictive model of substrate' combining multiple physical predictor variables and ground validation, which is described as 'work in progress at SGU'. This implies significant research and development, advanced technical expertise in predictive modeling, and extensive data integration. Extending this approach to 'surrounding countries (perhaps via international collaboration projects like Emodnet)' further indicates a high level of coordination and resource investment. This aligns with the 'high' difficulty criteria of 'requires significant resources, advanced technical expertise, extensive coordination, or major infrastructure' and 'a new methodology of large complexity with no established techniques' (in the context of a fully operational, validated, and extended model).
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can contribute to improving this layer, particularly in generating or enhancing some of the 'other physical predictor variables' mentioned in the recommendations (e.g., currents, wave exposure). While direct 'hard bottom' mapping is challenging, satellite-derived bathymetry (SDB) could potentially improve the underlying depth data in shallow, clear waters, especially in areas with 'no data available' or 'low quality data' as highlighted in the limitations. Satellite data can also provide insights into water clarity, which influences light penetration (photic zone definition). Although not directly mapping hard bottom, these indirect contributions can feed into a more robust predictive model.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, through its Sentinel-2 Level-2A data products, can contribute to improving this layer, particularly in shallow coastal areas. While Sentinel-2 cannot directly map deep hard bottom, it can be used for satellite-derived bathymetry in clear, shallow waters, potentially filling some of the 'no data available' gaps or improving the resolution of depth data in the photic zone. Its capabilities for coastal habitat mapping and land cover can also provide contextual information that might indirectly support the development of a more comprehensive predictive model, especially concerning coastal processes that influence substrate. However, its utility is limited to the photic zone and clear waters, and it cannot provide the full range of physical predictor variables needed for the recommended predictive model.

name: Deep reef
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster is intended to show the distribution of deep water coral reefs and sponge communities in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. This raster is represented with the value 100 where lophelia spp. and / or poriforia spp. communities are predicted to be present and value 0 where there is no information available. It is based on field survey point observation data stored in Gothenburg University's Koster database and the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute's SHARK ("Svenskt HavsARKiv") database. No prediction is made of where these communities might exist in unsurveyed areas. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs marine spatial planning at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes and particularly for local decision support is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data source.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa distribution av djupvattenskorallrev och svampsamhällen i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Detta rasterskikt presenteras med värdet 100 där lophelia spp. och/eller poriforia spp. samhällen förutsägs finnas, och ett värde av 0 där det inte finns någon information tillgänglig. Det baseras på punktdata från fältundersökningar lagrad i Göteborgs universitets Koster- databas och Sveriges meteorologiska och hydrologiska instituts SHARK ("Svenskt Havsarkiv") databas. Ingen förutsägelse görs om dessa samhällen kan finnas i ej undersökta områden. Denna data skapades som ett data
input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för
havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV).
Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den
kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska
vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av
denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter
vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: The observational data used to create this dataset is from Gothenburg University's 'Koster' database, SMHI's 'SHARK' database, "Tomas Lundälv, 2014, Kartläggning yttre havler nordöstra skagerrak" and from internal data held by Aquabiota AB. Various tools and internal developed models were used in ArcMap 10.3 to produce the final data such as Dissolve, Point to Raster, Polygon to Raster, Raster calculator and Water Ways model 1.02 (Aquabiota AB model). The method is a simple GIS-model that aims to extrapolate lophelia and porifera distributions based on presence point density and distance between point through water ways. This model does not take into account any environmental variables The model groups presence samples if they are within 1500 m distance through water ways and therefore the entire buffered grouped area becomes an expected distribution area. Expected distribution area is represented with value 100 in raster file. Another condition is needed to be fulfilled to form an expected lophelia distribution area which is the samples density need to be three or more than three samples and they need to be at least 125 m away from each other. The radius 1500 m is selected based on average sampling spatial distribution across the Swedish water body and therefore it is most likely to group samples in a more considerable way than other radius distances. The second condition distance is selected based on cell size distance which is 250 m. It is set 125 m with the reason of being half of the cell size distance and therefore aims to eliminate points that might be on the same raster cell that could lead to a false creation of expected bivalvia distribution area. The samples density three or more than three is selected based on average sampling spatial distribution within the area with the radius 1500 m. All sampling points that do not fulfil those two conditions are represented as only one cell with the value 100. More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This dataset does not predict or model the possible presence of deep reef or sponge communities it relies on observational data. This data is therefore likely to an underestimate the presence of these habitats (perhaps significantly) because these habitats are hard to detect (they cannot be identified with acoustic data) and there is very little survey effort in deep water offshore areas.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Based on available point data. Sampling efforts directed towards these species could improve the map, and possibly enable a more advanced modelling. If predictive modelling were to be attempted in future, better data on abiotic parameters (depth, water chemistry, currents and geology) data would be required to make reliable predictions - there are significant data gaps in the offshore environments on the West Coast of Sweden where these species are found. .

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states it 'does not predict or model the possible presence' and 'is therefore likely to underestimate the presence'. The recommendations suggest 'sampling efforts directed towards these species could improve the map, and possibly enable a more advanced modelling' and that 'If predictive modelling were to be attempted in future, better data on abiotic parameters... would be required'. This indicates a fundamental shift from a purely observational, potentially under-representative map to a predictive model, which constitutes a major improvement and re-conceptualization.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing predictive modeling for deep-water species requires 'better data on abiotic parameters (depth, water chemistry, currents and geology)' which are noted to have 'significant data gaps in the offshore environments'. This implies substantial new data collection efforts, potentially advanced modeling techniques, and significant resource investment, making it a high difficulty task.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The layer focuses on 'deep water coral reefs and sponge communities'. These habitats are deep-water and cannot be directly observed or mapped by current satellite remote sensing technologies, which are limited to surface or very shallow water parameters. The limitations explicitly state 'they cannot be identified with acoustic data', further indicating the challenge for remote sensing. Satellite data cannot provide the necessary biological or deep-water abiotic parameters (e.g., water chemistry, currents at depth, geology of the seafloor) required for predictive modeling of these specific deep-sea communities.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. Sentinel-2 has limited water penetration (only clear, shallow waters) and cannot 'see' deep-water habitats or provide the necessary abiotic parameters (e.g., deep-water chemistry, currents, geology) for modeling deep-sea coral and sponge communities. The national land cover data is terrestrial. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings are not suitable for generating or significantly improving this deep-water marine layer.

summary: This raster is intended to show the distribution of Haploops reefs in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. This raster is represented with the value 100 where Haploops spp. was present in data and "NoData" where there is no information about Haploops spp.. It is based on data sourced from Helsingborg Municipal Council and the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute's SHARK ("Svenskt HavsARKiv") database. No prediction is made of where these communities might exist in unsurveyed areas. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.

Detta rasterskikt avser att visa distribution av Haploopsrev i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Detta rasterskikt presenteras med värde 100 där Haploops spp. förekom i data, och ”NoData” där det inte finns någon information om Haploops spp.. Det baseras på data från Helsingborgs kommun och Sveriges meteorologiska och hydrologiska instituts SHARK ("Svenskt Havsarkiv") databas. Ingen förutsägelse görs om dessa samhällen kan finnas i ej undersökta områden. Denna
data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’
verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs-
och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV
för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av

The dataset simply shows pixels with an occurrence of Haploops. No distribution modelling is attempted and no environmental variables are considered. Pixels with an observation and given a value of 100 in the data.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This dataset does not predict or model the possible presence of Haploops -it relies on observational data. This data is therefore likely to an underestimate the presence of these habitats (perhaps significantly) .
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Based on available point data. Sampling efforts directed towards these species could improve the map, and possibly enable a more advanced modelling. If predictive modelling were to be attempted in future, better data on abiotic parameters (depth, water chemistry, currents and geology) data would be required to make reliable predictions.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states it's an underestimate due to reliance on observational data and 'no prediction is made'. The recommendation is to improve sampling and 'possibly enable a more advanced modelling' which would require 'better data on abiotic parameters'. This indicates a fundamental shift from purely observational mapping to predictive modeling, which is a major overhaul.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing predictive modeling for a species like Haploops requires significant effort. It involves 'improved sampling efforts' (new data collection), and gathering 'better data on abiotic parameters (depth, water chemistry, currents and geology)' which are complex and resource-intensive. Developing and validating a reliable predictive model is also a high-difficulty task, especially for a benthic species.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Haploops are benthic organisms, meaning they live on the seafloor. Satellite remote sensing primarily captures surface or near-surface phenomena (e.g., SST, chlorophyll, surface currents, turbidity). While satellites can provide some broad environmental context (e.g., water clarity in very shallow areas, which might indirectly relate to benthic habitats), they cannot directly detect or monitor Haploops reefs or the specific abiotic parameters (e.g., seafloor geology, specific water chemistry at depth, bottom currents) required for their predictive modeling. In-situ measurements, biological sampling, and potentially acoustic methods are necessary.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover, is not suitable for directly detecting or modeling Haploops reefs. Sentinel-2 has limited water penetration, especially in coastal and offshore waters where Haploops are found, and cannot provide the necessary abiotic parameters like depth, water chemistry, or bottom currents. Its focus is largely terrestrial and shallow coastal, not deep enough or with the right sensor capabilities for benthic marine life or the specific environmental variables needed for predictive modeling of Haploops.

name: Hard bottom aphotic
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
The raster layer shows the predicted probability of occurrence of hard marine benthic substrates (i.e. rocks, boulders, and bedrock) in aphotic zones shallower than 60 m (generally above the halocline) around Sweden. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to a low probability of occurrence and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a high probability of occurrence. Underlying data consists of benthic substrate data (1975- 2015), depth data (2013, 2015), and photic zone data. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish
Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM).
Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative
environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters
and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area
scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only
advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt visar beräknad sannolikhet för förekomst av hårdbotten (dvs. sten, block och berggrund) i afotiska zonen grundare än 60 m (generellt över haloklinen) runtom Sverige. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg sannolikhet för förekomst, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög sannolikhet för förekomst. Underlagsdata består av bentisk substratdata (1975-2015), djupdata (2013,2015) och fotisk zondata. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: The source data for this product comes from custom made substrate maps (2016 Estimated Proportions of Surface Substrate Classes), a depth model (2016 Geological Survey of Sweden SYMPHONY Depth Grid V2), and a photic depth layer (2016 SYMPHONY Photic Zone). Predictions of hardbottom substrate classes (i.e. cobbles, boulders, and bedrock) were combined and extracted from depth shallower than 60m but below the photic zone using conditional statements in ArcGIS raster calculator.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony:
There are a number of key limitations users should be aware of when using this dataset: 1) Only presence/absence data is available for sediment fractions in SGUs legacy sample inventory. Equal proportionality is assumed between the recorded sediment fractions but this may be invalid. 2) It was assumed that at least 20 replicates would be required to define the proportional makeup of each sediment class (in each sea area / depth / mapscale) . However, a power analysis was not undertaken to ensure sufficient sample availability for each surface substrate class and there is a significant range in replicate numbers between classes. 3) Where insufficient sample replication occurred to enable classification by depth, sea area and map scale data were averaged across depth ranges and between sea areas so certain classes are more reliable than others. 4) Surface substrates which form a veneer cover a smaller area of the seabed and consequently for some classes insufficient replicates were available for analysis. In this event the underlying sediment class was used for reclassification instead. In some classes on larger
scale maps this might cause veneered sediments to be depicted as mixed proportions of the
underlying substrate & veneer sediment fractions.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Apply a sensitivity analysis approach to determine the overall consequence of misclassification. Review the approach to proportionality by validating the model predictions with empirical data (e.g. particle size analysis data). Undertake an expert review. Gather additional source data from surrounding countries to produce better harmonisation.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations highlight fundamental issues with the underlying data (presence/absence, assumed proportionality, insufficient replicates, reclassification of veneered sediments) and the recommendations suggest a sensitivity analysis, validation with empirical data (particle size analysis), expert review, and gathering additional source data from surrounding countries. These point to a need for a substantial methodological overhaul and potentially new data collection/validation efforts, indicating a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations, particularly validating model predictions with empirical data (e.g., particle size analysis), undertaking an expert review, and gathering harmonized data from surrounding countries, requires significant resources, coordination, and potentially advanced technical expertise. Addressing the fundamental data limitations (e.g., moving beyond presence/absence or ensuring sufficient replicates) would be a major undertaking. A power analysis to ensure sufficient sample availability, as implied by the limitations, is also a non-trivial task. This points to a 'high' difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer predicts the probability of occurrence of hard marine benthic substrates (rocks, boulders, bedrock) in aphotic zones shallower than 60m. Satellite remote sensing, particularly optical sensors, has very limited penetration into the water column, typically only a few tens of meters in very clear waters, and cannot penetrate to aphotic zones or distinguish hard bottom types at these depths. Acoustic methods (e.g., multibeam echosounders, side-scan sonar) or in-situ sampling (e.g., grab samples, ROV/AUV surveys) are required for this type of data. Therefore, satellite remote sensing cannot directly help generate or significantly improve this layer.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. As explained for satellite remote sensing, optical data cannot penetrate to the depths (up to 60m) or aphotic conditions relevant for this layer to map benthic substrates. The land cover data is terrestrial and coastal, not relevant for deep-water benthic habitat mapping. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings cannot help generate or improve this specific marine planning layer.

name: Hard bottom deep
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: The raster layer shows the predicted probability of occurrence of hard marine benthic substrates (i.e. rocks, boulders, and bedrock) in aphotic zones deeper than 60 m (generally below the halocline) around Sweden. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to a low probability of occurrence and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a high probability of occurrence. Underlying data consists of benthic substrate data (1975- 2015), depth data (2013, 2015), and photic zone data. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt visar beräknad sannolikhet för förekomst av hårdbotten (dvs. sten, block och berggrund) i afotiska zonen djupare än 60 m (generellt under haloklinen) runtom Sverige. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg sannolikhet för förekomst, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög sannolikhet för förekomst. Underlagsdata består av bentisk substratdata (1975-2015), djupdata (2013,2015) och fotisk zondata. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: The source data for this product comes from custom made substrate maps (2016 Estimated Proportions of Surface Substrate Classes), a depth model (2016 Geological Survey of Sweden SYMPHONY Depth Grid V2), and a photic depth layer (2016 SYMPHONY Photic Zone). Predictions of hardbottom substrate class (i.e. cobbles, boulders, and bedrock) were combined and extracted from areas with depth greater than 60 m using conditional statements in ArcGIS raster calculator.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: There are a number of key limitations users should be aware of when using this dataset: 1) Only presence/absence data is available for sediment fractions in SGUs legacy sample inventory. Equal proportionality is assumed between the recorded sediment fractions but this may be invalid. 2) It was assumed that at least 20 replicates would be required to define the proportional makeup of each sediment class (in each sea area / depth / mapscale) . However, a power analysis was not undertaken to ensure sufficient sample availability for each surface substrate class and there is a significant range in replicate numbers between classes. 3) Where insufficient sample replication occurred to enable classification by depth, sea area and map scale data were averaged across depth ranges and between sea areas so certain classes are more reliable than others. 4) Surface substrates which form a veneer cover a smaller area of the seabed and consequently for some classes insufficient replicates were available for analysis. In this event the underlying sediment class was used for reclassification instead. In some classes on larger scale maps this might cause veneered sediments to be depicted as mixed proportions of the underlying substrate & veneer sediment fractions.
recommendations_for_data_improvement:
Apply a sensitivity analysis approach to determine the overall consequence of misclassification. Review the approach to proportionality by validating the model predictions with empirical
data (e.g. particle size analysis data).
Undertake an expert review.
Gather additional source data from surrounding countries to produce better harmonisation.

This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to the Geological Survey of Sweden and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations highlight fundamental issues with the underlying data (presence/absence, assumed proportionality, insufficient replicates, averaging across areas/depths, veneer cover reclassification). The recommendations suggest a sensitivity analysis, validation with empirical data (particle size analysis), expert review, and gathering additional source data from surrounding countries. These collectively point to a need for a significant overhaul of the data collection and modeling approach, moving beyond simple updates to address systematic biases and data quality issues, which aligns with 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations would be challenging. Validating model predictions with empirical particle size analysis data implies extensive new in-situ data collection. Undertaking a power analysis to ensure sufficient sample availability, as implied by the limitations, would require significant effort. Gathering additional source data from surrounding countries for harmonization is a complex data integration task. Addressing the 'assumed proportionality' and 'insufficient replicates' issues would likely require a new, more robust sampling strategy and potentially a re-evaluation of the modeling approach. These tasks require significant resources, advanced technical expertise, and extensive coordination, fitting the 'high' difficulty criteria.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer focuses on 'hard bottom deep' substrates (deeper than 60m, aphotic zones). Satellite remote sensing, particularly optical sensors, has very limited penetration in water, typically only a few tens of meters in very clear waters, and cannot directly map or characterize benthic substrates at depths greater than 60m. While satellite-derived bathymetry can provide depth information, the core issue of substrate characterization at these depths requires acoustic methods (e.g., multibeam echosounder, side-scan sonar) or in-situ sampling (e.g., grab samples, ROV/AUV observations), not satellite data.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. Sentinel-2, like other optical satellite sensors, cannot penetrate water to depths of 60m or more to characterize benthic substrates. The national land cover data is terrestrial and shallow coastal focused. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings are not suitable for generating or improving a layer focused on deep-water aphotic benthic substrates.

name: Mussel reef
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster is intended to show the distribution of mussel reef habitat in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. The dataset is derived from two input layers. The first is a predictive spatial model of areas with at least 10% cover of blue mussels (Mytilus edulis) which utilises environmental data parameters to predict distribution in unsurveyed areas. The second is a simple spatial model of bivalve distribution based on observational data and proximity information. These two source datasets are binary data. They have been aggregated with a higher weight given to the bivalve dataset. A value of 0 in the combined dataset represents areas where no blue mussels are predicted and where no bivalve observations exist, a value of 100 represents areas where (or in close proximity to where) bivalves have been observed. A value of 30 represents areas where >10% cover of blue mussels are predicted (but where no observational data exists). No prediction is made of where bivalves (other than blue mussels) might exist in unsurveyed areas. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area
scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only
advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa distribution av musselrevshabitat i svenska kust- och havsvatten. rasterskiktet härstammar från två inputs-rasterskikt. Den första är en prediktiv, rumslig modell av områden med minst 10 % täckning av blåmusslor (Mytilus Edulis) som använder miljödataparametrar för att förutsäga distribution i ej undersökta områden. Den andra är en enkel rumslig modell av musseldistribution baserad på observationsdata och proximitet. Dessa två källrasterskikt är binära data. De är aggregerade med större vikt lagd vid musselrasterskiktet. Ett värde av 0 i det kombinerade rasterskiktet motsvarar områden där inga blåmusslor förutspås förekomma och ingen observation av musslor finns, ett värde av 100 motsvarar ett område (eller i närheten av) där musslor har observerats. Ett värde av 30 representerar områden där > 10 % täckning av blåmusslor förväntas (men ingen observationsdata finns). Ingen förutsägelse görs om musslor (förutom blåmusslor) kan finnas i ej undersökta områden. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
This layer was created by combining a predictive model of blue mussel distribution (mytilus edilus) with presence data of bivalves (including Macoma balthica, Cerastoderma glaucum, Arctica islandica, Modiolus modiolus). These data were combined by the SGU at the request of SwAM using a conditional statement in ArcGIS 10.3 Raster Calculator so that sites with observational records are given a value of 100 and sites with a prediction are given a value of 30. The first input layer for mytilus edulis was modelled using epibenthos data from SHARK (source: SMHI), where there are blue mussel observational records detailing % cover ranging from 0 to 100%. Data was divided into cover of <10% (0) and >=10% (1). This binary dataset was set to fit a presence-absence model (GAM, mgcv for R). This model used predictor variables including depth, sourced from biological records where available and completed with depth data from SwAM's Symphony depth dataset (source: Swedish Maritime Administration) where missing; Wave exposure: log(n+1)-transformed; bottom salinity (source: Emodnet Chemistry); benthic substrate from SwAM's
Symphony geology data series: hardbotten_250m for the
east coast and block_250m for the west coast (source:
Geological Survey of Sweden). On the west coast a slope
layer calculated from the depth grid was also included in the
model. The model was predicted using the same layers in
250 m resolution. The cut-off in probability was set to 0.30
for the east coast and 0.10 for the west coast (the cut-off
values are derived from the model and set to maximise the
number of correctly classified presences and absences), so
that the cut-off value or higher is considered a presence and
lower is considered an absence.
The second input layer showing sites with observations of
'Bivalves' was created from ”Miljöövervakning av Knähaken
marina reservat 2011, Stina Bertilsson Vuksan och Peter
Göransson, Miljöförvaltningen i Helsingborgs stad” and
SHARKdata where the point data is represented as "P"
(Presence). It includes all bivalves from the above sources
such as Macoma balthica, Cerastoderma glaucum, Arctica
islandica, Modiolus modiolus etc. Various tools and internal
developed models were used in ArcMap 10.3 to produce the
final data such as Dissolve, Point to Raster, Polygon to
Raster, Raster calculator and Water Ways model 1.02
(Aquabiota AB's internally developed model).
More detailed information on the lineage and methodology
is available and can be supplied on request to the data
owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: For the modelled blue mussel data component model accuracy is limited by the resolution and quality of the environmental predictor variables. Salinity and temperature data are particularly lacking on the west coast.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: For blue mussels the analysis could be improved if more accurate depth, salinity and temperature data were available (i.e. more survey effort). Coverage of sampling data is weak in some parts, especially on the west coast.

This derived dataset is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to Aquabiota AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states limitations in the resolution and quality of environmental predictor variables, particularly salinity and temperature data on the west coast, and weak coverage of sampling data in some parts. The recommendations call for 'more accurate depth, salinity and temperature data' and 'more survey effort'. These are fundamental data gaps that significantly impact the predictive model's accuracy and require substantial new data collection and potentially a re-evaluation of the model itself, indicating a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Addressing the identified limitations requires significant new data collection ('more survey effort' for depth, salinity, temperature, and sampling data), which is resource-intensive and complex. Improving the accuracy and resolution of environmental predictor variables, especially for parameters like salinity and temperature, often involves deploying new sensors, conducting extensive surveys, or integrating advanced oceanographic models. This level of data acquisition and integration, coupled with potential model re-calibration, points to 'high' difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can significantly help. While direct measurement of bottom salinity and temperature is challenging, satellite-derived sea surface temperature (SST) can provide valuable input for oceanographic models that predict bottom conditions. Satellite altimetry can contribute to more accurate depth models (e.g., Satellite-Derived Bathymetry in shallow, clear waters). Furthermore, satellite imagery (e.g., high-resolution optical data) can assist in mapping benthic substrate types in shallow areas, which is a key predictor variable. Although not a direct replacement for in-situ biological sampling, satellite data can provide broad-scale environmental context and potentially identify areas with suitable conditions for mussel reefs, guiding future survey efforts.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 data and national land cover, has limited direct applicability for improving this specific marine layer. Sentinel-2 is optical and has limited penetration in water, making it unsuitable for deep-water bathymetry, bottom salinity, or temperature. While it could potentially contribute to mapping very shallow water substrate types or coastal land use that might indirectly influence coastal habitats, the core limitations of the mussel reef layer (bottom salinity, temperature, and comprehensive biological sampling) are beyond the capabilities of DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings. Its focus is more on terrestrial and very shallow coastal applications, not the deeper marine environment where these mussels reside.

name: Plankton pelagic
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster intends to show the predicted plankton distribution in Swedish coastal and offshore waters via integrated chlorophyll-a concentration ([int chl-a]).
Underlying data consists of modelled chlorophyll-a
concentration data from satellite image analysis. A cell value
of 0 is equivalent to an [int chl-a] of 0 mg/m2 and a cell
value of 100 is equivalent to an [int chl-a] of 151.47 mg/m2.
These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony'
tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish
Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM).
Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative
environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters
and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area
scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only
advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad planktonförekomst i svenska kust- och havsvatten genom integrerad klorofyll a koncentration ([int chl-a]). Underlagsdata består av modellerad klorofyll a koncentrationsdata från satellitbildsanalys. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ([int chl-a]) av 0 mg/m2, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar ([int chl-a]) av 151,47 mg/m2. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: This layer was produced from modelled chlorophyll-a concentration ([Chl-a], (mg/m3)) data (BALTICSEA_ANALYSIS_FORECAST_BIO_003_007) published by marine Copernicus (2014-2016). Data processing took the following steps: 1. Using a script in the program NCO in Linux modelled [Chl-a] data were integrated by multiplying concentrations with respective weighted vectors and summing these to produce integrated chlorophyll-a concentration ([int Chl-a], mg/m2), after which mean [int Chl-a] values were calculated for summer, winter and the whole year. Median values and standard deviations were also calculated. 2. Average [int Chl-a] values were transferred to a SYMPHONY raster 3. Data were then normalised using a sigmoidal function to reduce the impact of extreme values
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: None - data is high quality. It is the latest satellite data and is processed using state of the art algorithms and delivered via international open data archives.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: No current recommendations

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states 'Limitations: None - data is high quality. It is the latest satellite data and is processed using state of the art algorithms and delivered via international open data archives.' and 'Recommendations: No current recommendations'. The only potential for improvement, given the 'small' criteria, is to update the temporal coverage (2014-2016) with more recent data from the same high-quality sources, which is a minor update.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Updating the temporal coverage with newer data from the same established sources (Copernicus Marine) is a straightforward process, requiring minimal technical expertise and coordination, fitting the 'low' difficulty criteria for 'updating temporal coverage with newer data from the same sources'.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The layer is already based on 'modelled chlorophyll-a concentration data from satellite image analysis' (Copernicus Marine). Satellite remote sensing is fundamental to generating and improving this layer, as it provides the core chlorophyll-a data. Continued use of satellite data, specifically ocean color sensors, is essential for temporal updates and potential future refinements.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily provides Sentinel-2 data and national land cover. While Sentinel-2 can provide some water quality parameters in coastal areas, the primary data source for this pelagic plankton layer is Copernicus Marine's modelled chlorophyll-a, which comes from dedicated ocean color sensors (e.g., MODIS, VIIRS, OLCI) that are not part of DigitalEarthSweden's core offerings. DigitalEarthSweden's focus is more on terrestrial and shallow coastal applications, not open ocean pelagic parameters like integrated chlorophyll-a across the water column.

name: Shoreline
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This data set intends to show the complexity of the Swedish coastal zone as an indication of ecological importance. The source data used is Lantmäteriet's terrain map shoreline dataset. A cell value zero is equivalent to a completely flat shoreline and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a shoreline of >1500m length in that cell. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa komplexiteten av den svenska kustzonen som en indikation för ekologisk betydelse. Källdata som använts är kustlinjerasterskikt från Lantmäteriets terrängkarta. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar en helt platt kustlinje, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar en kustlinje på >1500 m längd i den cellen. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
The source data for this product is the Swedish coastline sourced from Terrängkartan from the Swedish mapping, cadastral and land registration authority (Läntmateriet) The symphony grid (250m cell) was used to split the shoreline into individual segments for each cell (using ArcMap 10.3.1) The length of each segment in each cell was calculated (using
ArcMap 10.3.1 geometry)
The shapefile was then transfered into a symphony cell
standard raster with the shapelength as the value.
Normalisation: The data was linear transformed from 0-
1500 m shoreline length/cell to 0-1 scale (outlier values up to
3000 meter existed).
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: Shoreline complexity is a simplistic measure of ecological value, many other factors are influential such as geology, currents and exposure however it is assumed that these factors result in either a complex of simple coastal structure. This relationship is unlikely to be so simple.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Introduce additional predictive factors into a future model such as terrain morphology, coastal geology or exposure,
