improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states that 'Shoreline complexity is a simplistic measure of ecological value' and recommends 'Introduce additional predictive factors into a future model such as terrain morphology, coastal geology or exposure'. This requires a fundamental overhaul of the model's input factors beyond just shoreline complexity, moving towards a more comprehensive ecological assessment. This constitutes a major improvement in the conceptualization of ecological value.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements (terrain morphology, coastal geology, exposure) would involve integrating new, diverse datasets and potentially developing new methodologies to combine these factors into a more robust ecological value assessment. While not requiring entirely new data collection programs from scratch, it would involve significant data acquisition, processing, and model development, placing it in the medium difficulty range.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can significantly help improve this layer. While shoreline complexity itself is derived from existing maps, the recommended 'additional predictive factors' such as terrain morphology (e.g., using Digital Elevation Models derived from satellite data), coastal geology (inferred from spectral properties or geomorphological features visible from space), and exposure (e.g., wave exposure derived from satellite altimetry or wind data) can all be informed or generated by satellite observations. Coastal habitat mapping, which is implicitly linked to ecological value, can also be enhanced by satellite imagery.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden can contribute to improving this layer. Sentinel-2 data can be used for detailed coastal morphology analysis, identifying different types of coastal structures, and potentially inferring aspects of coastal geology through spectral analysis of exposed rock or sediment types. While it doesn't directly provide 'exposure' data, the high-resolution imagery can support the mapping of features that influence exposure. name: Soft bottom aphotic
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: The raster layer shows the predicted probability of occurrence of soft marine benthic substrates (i.e. mud, silt, and clay) in aphotic zones shallower than 60 m (generally above the halocline) around Sweden. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to a low probability of occurrence and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a high probability of occurrence. Underlying data consists of benthic substrate data (1975- 2015), depth data (2013, 2015), and photic zone data. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt visar beräknad sannolikhet för förekomst av mjukbotten (dvs. lera, silt och gyttja) i afotiska zonen grundare än 60 m (generellt över haloklinen) runtom Sverige. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg sannolikhet för förekomst och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög sannolikhet för förekomst. Underlagsdata består av bentisk
substratdata (1975-2015), djupdata (2013,2015) och fotisk
zondata. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för
’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för
havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV).
Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den
kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska
vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av
denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter
vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: The source data for this product comes from custom made substrate maps (2016 Estimated Proportions of Surface Substrate Classes), a depth model (2016 Geological Survey of Sweden SYMPHONY Depth Grid V2), and a photic depth layer (2016 SYMPHONY Photic Zone). Predictions of softbottom substrate classes (i.e. mud, silt, and clay) were combined and extracted from the area shallower than 60 m and below the photic zone using conditional statements in ArcGIS raster calculator.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: There are a number of key limitations users should be aware of when using this dataset: 1) Only presence/absence data is available for sediment fractions in SGUs legacy sample inventory. Equal proportionality is assumed between the recorded sediment fractions but this may be invalid. 2) It was assumed that at least 20 replicates would be required to define the proportional makeup of each sediment class (in each sea area / depth / mapscale) . However, a power analysis was not undertaken to ensure sufficient sample availability for each surface substrate class and there is a significant range in replicate numbers between classes. 3) Where insufficient sample replication occurred to enable classification by depth, sea area and map scale data were averaged across depth ranges and between sea areas so certain classes are more reliable than others. 4) Surface substrates which form a veneer cover a smaller area of the seabed and consequently for some classes insufficient replicates were available for analysis. In this event the underlying sediment class was used for reclassification instead. In some classes on larger scale maps this might cause veneered sediments to be depicted as mixed proportions of the underlying substrate & veneer sediment fractions.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Apply a sensitivity analysis approach to determine the overall consequence of misclassification. Review the approach to proportionality by validating the model predictions with empirical data (e.g. particle size analysis data). Undertake an expert review. Gather additional source data from surrounding countries to produce better harmonisation.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations highlight fundamental issues with the underlying data (presence/absence for sediment fractions, assumed proportionality, insufficient replicates, reclassification of veneered sediments) and the methodology (no power analysis for sample sufficiency). The recommendations suggest a sensitivity analysis, validation with empirical data (particle size analysis), expert review, and gathering additional source data for harmonization. These collectively point to a need for a fundamental re-evaluation of the data collection and modeling approach, moving beyond simple updates to a more robust, potentially predictive, methodology for sediment classification.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations would require significant effort. Validating model predictions with empirical data like particle size analysis implies a need for new, high-quality in-situ data collection or access to extensive existing datasets not currently utilized. Undertaking a power analysis for sample sufficiency and addressing the issues of assumed proportionality and insufficient replicates would necessitate a substantial re-design of the sampling strategy and potentially the modeling approach. Gathering additional source data from surrounding countries for harmonization is a large-scale data integration and standardization task. These tasks require significant resources, advanced technical expertise in marine geology and statistical modeling, and extensive international coordination.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer predicts the probability of occurrence of soft marine benthic substrates (mud, silt, clay) in aphotic zones shallower than 60m. Satellite remote sensing, particularly optical sensors, has very limited penetration depth in water, typically only a few meters in clear waters, and cannot 'see' the seabed at 60m depth, especially in aphotic zones. While satellite-derived bathymetry can provide depth information in very shallow, clear waters, it is not suitable for mapping sediment types at these depths or in aphotic conditions. Acoustic methods (e.g., multibeam echosounders, side-scan sonar) or physical sampling (grabs, cores) are the primary methods for mapping seabed substrates at these depths.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily provides Sentinel-2 data and national land cover data. Sentinel-2 is an optical satellite sensor with similar limitations to other optical sensors regarding water penetration depth and inability to map seabed substrates at 60m in aphotic zones. Its primary utility is for terrestrial and very shallow coastal applications. The national land cover data is also terrestrial. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings are not suitable for generating or significantly improving this specific marine benthic substrate layer, which requires deep-water seabed characterization.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations highlight fundamental issues with the underlying data (presence/absence, assumed proportionality, insufficient replication, veneer cover reclassification) which suggest the current model's predictions may be significantly flawed. The recommendations (sensitivity analysis, validating with empirical data like particle size analysis, expert review, gathering additional source data) point to a need for a substantial overhaul of the data collection, processing, and modeling approach, rather than just minor updates or additions. This indicates a 'large' improvement potential as it requires addressing systematic biases and potentially re-conceptualizing how soft bottom probabilities are derived.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations would be 'high' difficulty. Validating model predictions with empirical particle size analysis data implies a need for extensive new in-situ data collection, which is resource-intensive. Undertaking a power analysis to ensure sufficient sample availability, as implied by the limitations, would require significant statistical expertise and potentially more targeted sampling. Gathering additional source data from surrounding countries for harmonization is a major coordination and data integration effort. Addressing the 'assumed proportionality' and 'insufficient replication' issues would likely require a fundamental re-evaluation of the data collection strategy and potentially new methodologies for handling sparse or biased data, which goes beyond simple updates.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer predicts the probability of soft marine benthic substrates (mud, silt, clay) in aphotic zones deeper than 60m. Satellite remote sensing is generally limited to surface or near-surface water properties and shallow bathymetry. It cannot directly measure or infer seabed sediment composition in deep, aphotic zones. While satellites can provide some indirect proxies for water column properties (e.g., turbidity, chlorophyll-a) that might correlate with sediment deposition, they cannot directly assess the type of benthic substrate at these depths. Therefore, satellite data cannot help generate or significantly improve this specific layer.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily provides Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. Sentinel-2 is limited to optical wavelengths, meaning its penetration depth in water is very shallow (typically a few meters in clear water, much less in turbid coastal waters). It cannot 'see' or infer seabed characteristics in aphotic zones deeper than 60m. The national land cover data is terrestrial. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings are not suitable for generating or improving a layer describing deep-sea benthic substrates.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations highlight fundamental issues with the underlying data (presence/absence, assumed proportionality, insufficient replication, reclassification of veneered sediments) that significantly impact the reliability and accuracy of the probability predictions. The recommendations suggest a sensitivity analysis, validation with empirical data (e.g., particle size analysis), expert review, and gathering additional source data from surrounding countries. These collectively point to a need for a substantial overhaul of the data collection, processing, and validation methodology, moving beyond simple updates to address systematic biases and improve the foundational data quality. This aligns with 'large' improvement potential, as it requires addressing systematic biases in data collection and potentially implementing new data collection protocols or advanced modeling techniques.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, particularly validating with empirical data (particle size analysis), undertaking a sensitivity analysis, and gathering harmonized data from surrounding countries, would require significant resources, advanced technical expertise (e.g., in geostatistics, sedimentology, and data harmonization), and extensive international coordination. The need for a power analysis to ensure sufficient sample availability also implies a complex statistical undertaking. This aligns with 'high' difficulty, as it involves a new methodology of large complexity and extensive coordination.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer predicts the probability of occurrence of soft marine benthic substrates (mud, silt, clay) in the photic zone. While satellite remote sensing can provide information on water depth (satellite-derived bathymetry in very shallow, clear waters) and water clarity (which influences photic depth), it cannot directly measure or infer the specific composition of benthic substrates (mud, silt, clay) at the resolution and accuracy required for this layer. Benthic substrate classification typically relies on in-situ sampling (grab samples, cores) or acoustic methods (multibeam echosounder, side-scan sonar) which provide direct or indirect measurements of sediment type. Satellite data cannot penetrate the water column sufficiently to characterize sub-surface sediment properties or differentiate between fine sediment types like mud, silt, and clay. Therefore, satellite remote sensing cannot directly generate or significantly improve the core data for this layer.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 Level-2A data and national land cover data. Sentinel-2 is an optical sensor with limited water penetration, primarily useful for very shallow water bathymetry in clear conditions and coastal land cover/habitat mapping. It cannot penetrate the water column to identify or differentiate between soft benthic substrates (mud, silt, clay) in the photic zone, especially given the depths involved in the photic zone around Sweden. The national land cover data is terrestrial. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings cannot help generate or improve this specific marine benthic substrate probability layer, which requires direct or acoustic measurements of seabed composition.

improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. Sentinel-2's optical capabilities are limited to shallow, clear waters and cannot penetrate to aphotic zones or depths of 60m to characterize benthic substrates. The national land cover data is terrestrial/coastal focused and not relevant for deep-water benthic substrate mapping. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings cannot directly help generate or improve this specific marine benthic substrate layer.

name: Transport bottom deep
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster intends to show the predicted probability occurrence of soft marine benthic substrates (i.e. sand and gravel) in aphotic zones deeper than 60 m (generally below the halocline) in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. A value of 0 is equivalent to a low probability of occurrence and a value of 1 is equivalent to a high probability of occurrence. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in
Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at
plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is
only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data
sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad sannolikhet för förekomst av mjukbotten (dvs. sand och grus) i afotiska zonen djupare än 60 m (generellt under haloklinen) i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett värde av 0 motsvarar låg sannolikhet för förekomst, och ett värde av 1 motsvarar hög sannolikhet för förekomst. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: The source data for this product comes from custom made substrate maps (2016 Estimated Proportions of Surface Substrate Classes), a depth model (2016 Geological Survey of Sweden SYMPHONY Depth Grid V2), and a photic depth layer (2016 SYMPHONY Photic Zone). Predictions of transport bottom substrate classes (i.e. sand and gravel) were combined and extracted from the region below 60m deep using conditional statements in ArcGIS raster calculator.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: There are a number of key limitations users should be aware of when using this dataset: 1) Only presence/absence data is available for sediment fractions in SGUs legacy sample inventory. Equal proportionality is assumed between the recorded sediment fractions but this may be invalid. 2) It was assumed that at least 20 replicates would be required to define the proportional makeup of each sediment class (in each sea area / depth / mapscale) . However, a power analysis was not undertaken to ensure sufficient sample availability for each surface substrate class and there is a significant range in replicate numbers between classes. 3) Where insufficient sample replication occurred to enable classification by depth, sea area and map scale data were averaged across depth ranges and between sea areas so certain classes are more reliable than others. 4) Surface substrates which form a veneer cover a smaller area of the seabed and consequently for some classes insufficient replicates were available for analysis. In this event the underlying sediment class was used for reclassification instead. In some classes on larger scale maps this might cause veneered sediments to be depicted as mixed proportions of the underlying substrate & veneer sediment fractions.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Apply a sensitivity analysis approach to determine the overall consequence of misclassification. Review the approach to proportionality by validating the model predictions with empirical data (e.g. particle size analysis data). Undertake an expert review. Gather additional source data from surrounding countries to produce better harmonisation.

This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations highlight fundamental issues with the source data's representativeness (presence/absence only, assumed proportionality, insufficient replicates, averaging across areas/depths, veneer issues) and the lack of power analysis. The recommendations suggest sensitivity analysis, validation with empirical data (particle size analysis), expert review, and gathering additional source data from surrounding countries. These collectively point to a need for a substantial overhaul of the data collection and modeling approach, moving beyond simple updates to address systematic biases and improve the foundational data quality and model reliability. This aligns with 'large' improvement potential, requiring fundamental methodological overhauls and potentially new data collection protocols.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations would be challenging. Validating with empirical particle size analysis data implies a need for new, high-quality in-situ data collection or access to extensive existing datasets not currently utilized. Undertaking a power analysis and addressing insufficient replication would require significant statistical expertise and potentially new sampling campaigns. Harmonizing data from surrounding countries is a complex task involving data standardization and cross-border collaboration. These efforts require significant resources, advanced technical expertise, and extensive coordination, fitting the 'high' difficulty criteria.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer predicts the probability of soft marine benthic substrates (sand and gravel) in aphotic zones deeper than 60m. Satellite remote sensing, particularly optical sensors, has very limited penetration depth in water, typically only a few tens of meters in very clear waters, and cannot 'see' the seabed at 60m+ depths, especially in potentially turbid coastal waters. Acoustic methods (e.g., multibeam echosounders, side-scan sonar) or physical sampling (e.g., grab samples, cores) are the primary methods for mapping deep-water benthic substrates. Therefore, satellite data cannot directly generate or significantly improve this specific layer.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. As explained for satellite remote sensing, optical data cannot penetrate to 60m+ depths to map benthic substrates. The land cover data is terrestrial/coastal and not relevant for deep marine benthic environments. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings cannot directly generate or improve this specific layer, which focuses on deep-water marine sediment types.

It also cannot provide the detailed particle size analysis needed for validation. In-situ sampling (e.g., grab samples, cores) is required for ground-truthing sediment composition.

name: Grey seal
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: The raster layer intends to show the predicted distribution of Grey seals in Swedish marine waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to zero abundance and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high relative abundance. Underlying data are inventory data from national monitoring (2010-2015) that have been modelled. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad distribution av gråsäl i svenska havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen abundans, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ abundans. Underlagsdata är inventeringsdata från nationell övervakning (2010-2015) som modellerats. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Data are inventory point data (2010-2015) collected as part of national monitoring of Grey Seals from The Swedish Museum of Natural History (Naturhistoriska riksmuseet). Data processing took the following steps: 1. Interpolate point data using a search window with a radius of 60 km (home range) 2. Compensate the distribution to account for longer
migration behaviour and the ratio of land/water within the
home range for each cell.
3. Adjust to SYMPHONY requirements and normalise.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: No limitations identified by SLU
recommendations_for_data_improvement: No recommendations suggested by SLU

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: Although 'No limitations identified' and 'No recommendations suggested' are stated by SLU, the layer's lineage describes a modeling approach (interpolation, compensation for migration/land-water ratio, normalization) based on inventory point data from 2010-2015. The 'Maintenance: Not Planned' status and the age of the data (2010-2015) suggest a 'medium' improvement potential. Updating the temporal period with more recent inventory data would be a moderate improvement. Furthermore, the modeling approach could potentially be refined or validated with more recent or comprehensive in-situ data, or by incorporating environmental covariates if available, moving beyond simple interpolation and compensation. The 're-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources' also hints at potential limitations in its broader applicability without further refinement or validation.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Updating the temporal coverage would require acquiring new inventory data from the Swedish Museum of Natural History, which implies coordination and data transfer. If the modeling approach itself were to be refined (e.g., incorporating environmental covariates or more sophisticated spatial modeling techniques), this would require moderate technical expertise and potentially new data sources, placing it in the 'medium' difficulty category. The current methodology involves a 60km search window and compensation for migration, which suggests a degree of complexity that would make any significant methodological refinement a 'medium' difficulty task.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Grey seal distribution is primarily determined by factors such as prey availability, breeding sites (haul-out sites on land or ice), and migration patterns. Satellite remote sensing, while excellent for environmental parameters like SST, chlorophyll, or land cover, cannot directly detect or monitor seal populations or their abundance with the resolution and specificity required for this layer. While satellite imagery could potentially identify suitable haul-out sites (e.g., specific islands or ice floes), it cannot quantify seal abundance or their predicted distribution across marine waters, especially considering their underwater foraging and migratory behaviors. This layer is based on inventory data, likely from aerial surveys or direct observations, which are not satellite-derived.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are not suitable for directly monitoring or modeling marine mammal distribution in open waters. While Sentinel-2 could potentially identify coastal features or land cover types that might serve as haul-out sites, it cannot provide information on seal abundance in the marine environment, nor can it track their movements or foraging patterns. The layer's underlying data are inventory point data from national monitoring, which are in-situ observations, not satellite-derived. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings cannot directly generate or significantly improve this specific marine mammal distribution layer.

summary: The raster layer intends to show the predicted distribution of Harbour seals in Swedish marine waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to zero abundance and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a high relative abundance. Underlying data are inventory data from national monitoring (2010-2015) that have been modelled. summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad distribution av knubbsäl i svenska havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen abundans, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ abundans. Underlagsdata är inventeringsdata från nationell övervakning (2010- 2015), som modellerats. lineage: Data are inventory point data (2010-2015) collected as part of national monitoring of Harbour Seals from the Swedish Ocean Archive (Svenska Hav Arkiv - SHARK) at the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI). Data processing took the following steps: 1. Interpolate point data using a search window with a radius of 40 km (home range) 2. Compensate the distribution to account for the ratio of land/water within the home range for each cell. 3. Adjust to SYMPHONY requirements and normalise.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: Despite 'No limitations identified' and 'No recommendations suggested' by SLU, the layer's underlying data are from 2010-2015, making it temporally outdated for current marine planning. The methodology uses a fixed 40km search window for interpolation, which might not fully capture the dynamic nature of seal distribution or account for varying habitat use. The 'compensate the distribution to account for the ratio of land/water within the home range' step is a good start but could be refined with more sophisticated habitat modeling. The 'Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources' suggests a lack of robustness for broader application without expert consultation, indicating potential for methodological improvements to increase its general applicability. Updating the temporal coverage and potentially refining the interpolation/modeling approach would be a moderate improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Updating the temporal coverage would require accessing newer national monitoring data (if available) and re-running the existing processing steps, which is a medium difficulty task due to data acquisition and processing. Refining the interpolation or modeling to account for more dynamic factors or better habitat representation would require methodological development and validation, also a medium difficulty task. It's not a simple data refresh but involves re-processing and potential methodological adjustments.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Harbour seal distribution is primarily determined by factors like prey availability, haul-out sites, and human disturbance, which are not directly observable or quantifiable by current satellite remote sensing capabilities. While satellites can provide data on sea surface temperature or chlorophyll-a (indirectly related to prey), they cannot directly monitor seal abundance or fine-scale distribution. Haul-out sites are typically coastal features, but direct seal counting from space is not feasible at the resolution and frequency required. Therefore, satellite remote sensing cannot directly generate or significantly improve this specific layer, which relies on inventory data and predictive modeling based on those inventories.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These are useful for mapping coastal land use, habitat types (e.g., wetlands, rocky shores), and changes in coastal infrastructure. While haul-out sites for seals are coastal, DigitalEarthSweden's data cannot directly detect or count seals, nor can it provide the marine environmental data (e.g., prey distribution, underwater acoustics) that would be crucial for modeling seal abundance. The layer is about marine distribution and abundance, which is beyond the scope of DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden data cannot directly generate or significantly improve this layer.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations highlight fundamental issues with the underlying data (presence/absence, assumed proportionality, insufficient replication, use of underlying sediment class for veneers) and the methodology (no power analysis). The recommendations suggest a sensitivity analysis, validation with empirical data (particle size analysis), expert review, and gathering additional source data. These point to a need for substantial new data collection (e.g., particle size analysis for validation), fundamental methodological overhauls (revisiting proportionality assumptions, ensuring sufficient replication), and potentially a complete re-conceptualization of how substrate classes are defined and mapped, moving beyond simple presence/absence. This goes beyond minor updates or simple integration of existing data.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, particularly validating proportionality with empirical data like particle size analysis, undertaking a power analysis for replication, and potentially re-classifying surface substrates, would require significant resources for new data collection (e.g., extensive field sampling for particle size analysis), advanced technical expertise for statistical analysis (power analysis, spatial modeling), and extensive coordination to harmonize data from surrounding countries. Addressing the 'veneer' issue might also require more sophisticated spatial modeling. This is not a simple update but a major re-evaluation and potential re-engineering of the underlying data and model.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing, specifically Satellite-Derived Bathymetry (SDB) from optical sensors, could potentially help improve the depth data component, especially in shallow, clear waters, which is relevant for the photic zone. While SDB cannot directly identify hard bottom substrates, it can provide more detailed and up-to-date bathymetry, which is a key input. Additionally, high-resolution optical imagery (e.g., from Sentinel-2 or commercial satellites) could potentially be used in very shallow, clear waters to infer substrate types or identify areas of high rugosity indicative of hard bottoms, though direct classification of 'rocks, boulders, and bedrock' from space is challenging and often requires ground truthing. It could also aid in mapping coastal geomorphology that might correlate with hard bottom presence. Therefore, satellite data can enhance or validate input layers, even if not directly generating the hard bottom probability.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, through its Sentinel-2 Level-2A data products, offers high-resolution optical imagery (10-60m) that could contribute to improving this layer. Specifically, Sentinel-2 data can be used for: 1) Enhancing or validating the depth model in shallow, clear coastal waters through Satellite-Derived Bathymetry (SDB) techniques. 2) Potentially identifying areas of high rugosity or distinct spectral signatures in very shallow, clear waters that might correlate with hard bottom presence, though direct classification of specific substrate types (rocks, boulders) is challenging and requires extensive ground truthing. 3) Monitoring coastal changes that might influence substrate distribution. While DigitalEarthSweden does not provide direct substrate data, its optical imagery can improve or validate key input layers (depth) and potentially offer indirect insights into substrate characteristics in shallow areas, especially in conjunction with the national land cover data for coastal context.

name: Porpoise baltic sea
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show marine areas utilised by porpoises in coastal and offshore waters in the Baltic Sea proper. This raster is derived from acoustic monitoring data collected between 2011 to 2013 These data represent the Baltic Sea Porpoise population (a distinct group) over an annual period. A cell value of 0 shows areas where no porpoises are predicted and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to the maximum predicted average annual population density. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa marina områden vilka används av tumlare i kust- och havsvatten i Egentliga Östersjön. rasterskiktet är baseras på akustiska övervakningsdata som samlats in mellan 2011 och 2013. Dessa data representerar Östersjöviktspopulationen (en distinkt grupp) över en årlig tidsperiod. Ett cellvärde av 0 visar områden där inga tumlare förväntas förekomma, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar maximala beräknada, genomsnittlig årlig populationsdensitet. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för
bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig
aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: These data were prepared primarily from acoustic monitoring data collected during the SAMBAH project between 2011 and 2013. The probability of encountering porpoises was calculated from measurements of sounds emitted from the animals. The study included animals in the Baltic Sea between Åland and the Belt Sea (see method description in Static Acoustic Monitoring of the Baltic Harbor porpoise, SAMBAH, non-technical report http://www.sambah.org/Non-technical-report-v.-1.8.1.pdf). Summer and winter data were provided and these were combined (mean average) to produce an annual dataset for Symphony. The SAMBAH project (See SAMBAH Non- technical report) suggests a limit of the Baltic porpoise population. At this suggested demarcation line was therefore used to isolate the Baltic Population for separate treatment in Symphony. Data were extrapolated using an inverse distance weighting algorithmn to avoid a sharp break. Values were normalized between 0 - 100 using a linear transformation (where 100 represents the maximum value in the data). The were then resampled to a 250mx250m grid. More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: In avoid a sharp boundary the area between the Belt Sea population and the Baltic Sea population have been interpolated from the maximum value along the population limit proposed in the project SAMBAH (See SAMBAH Non-technical report) down to zero along an arbitrary limit at Bornholm. The demarcation generates a fictitious decline in the Baltic population in the west-southwest direction, which does not correspond to real conditions.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The primary limitation explicitly states a 'fictitious decline' in porpoise population due to interpolation, which 'does not correspond to real conditions'. This indicates a fundamental methodological flaw in representing the actual distribution, requiring a significant overhaul of the spatial modeling approach rather than just minor updates. Additionally, the data is from 2011-2013, making it temporally outdated for current policy formulation.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Addressing the 'fictitious decline' requires re-evaluating and potentially re-modeling the spatial distribution of porpoises, especially at the population boundary. This would likely involve advanced spatial statistics or ecological modeling techniques beyond simple interpolation, potentially requiring new data integration or a re-analysis of the original acoustic data with a different spatial approach. Updating the temporal period would also require new acoustic monitoring data, which is resource-intensive.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The layer is based on acoustic monitoring data of porpoises, which are marine mammals. Satellite remote sensing cannot directly detect porpoises or their acoustic signals. While satellites can provide environmental parameters (e.g., SST, chlorophyll) that might correlate with porpoise distribution, they cannot generate or directly improve the core porpoise density data itself, which relies on in-situ acoustic measurements.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are focused on terrestrial and shallow coastal environments and are not suitable for monitoring marine mammal populations in offshore waters or for processing acoustic data. The capabilities of DigitalEarthSweden do not align with the data type or the specific challenges of this porpoise distribution layer.

name: Porpoise belt sea
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show marine areas utilised by porpoises in the Belt Sea (Danish Straights). Underlying data are modelled population density data generated from tracking of 78 satellite-tagged porpoises during two periods between 1997 and 2016 by Aarhus University. These modelled data were then normalized and log transformed for use in Symphony. A cell value of 0 shows areas where no porpoises are predicted and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to the maximum average annual population density (within the Swedish EEZ). These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa marina områden som används av tumlare i Bältsjön. Underlaget härrör från modellerad populationsdensitetsdata beräknad från spårningsdata som samlats in från 78 satellitmärkta tumlare. Spårningsdata samlades in under två perioder mellan åren 1997 och 2016 av Århus Universitet. Dessa modellerade data normaliserades och log-transformerades sedan för att användas i Symphony. Ett cellvärde av 0 visar områden där inga tumlare förväntas förekomma, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar den maximala beräknade genomsnittliga årliga populationsdensiteten (inom Svensk EEZ). Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Since 1997, Aarhus University (AU) has been attaching satellite transmitters on harbour porpoises incidentally caught in pound nets in the inner Danish waters (Kattegat, Belt Seas, the Sound and the western Baltic). For detailed description of tagging methodology see Sveegaard et al. (2011a). The telemetry tracking data allows for a detailed view of movement of the individual porpoises. However, by combining data from several porpoises, a good overview of the entire porpoise population distribution may be obtained. Such a study was published in 2011 containing the data from 64 porpoises tagged from 1997 – 2007 (Sveegaard et al. 2011). From 2007 to 2016, Aarhus University have tagged an additional 56 individuals i.e. 120 harbour porpoises in total. Data from 18 individuals were removed prior to further
analysis by Aarhus due to data quality issues.
The data from 78 animals (located in the Belt Sea area) were
analysed by Aarhus univeristity using kernel density
estimation (KDE) generating summer, winter and annual
datasets. A detail description of the KDE method can be
found in Sveegaard et al 2011 data were filtered using a DAR
filter (Distance, Angle, Rate, Douglas Argos filter v7.03) to 1
location per porpoise per day. KDE were performed using
the ArcToolbox in ArcGIS v. 10.3. Grid size = 1x1 km,
smoothing factor = 20.000 and each animal were weighted
equally in the analysis.
In preparation for use in Symphony only the annual data
were used and these data were logarithmically transformed
and normalised. The data were transformed using a (Log10
(cell value + 1) calculation in ArcGIS. Values were then
normalized (linear rescale in ArcGIS) between 0 - 100 with
100 representing the maximum value within the Swedish
EEZ.
The were then resampled to the 250mx250m Symphony
grid.
More detailed information on the lineage and methodology
is available and can be supplied on request to the data
owner.
Method reference:
Sveegaard, S., Teilmann, J., Tougaard, J., Dietz, R.,
Mouritsen, K.N., Desportes, G., Siebert, U., 2011. High-
density areas for harbour porpoises (Phocoena phocoena)
identified by satellite tracking. Mar. Mam. Sci. 27, 230–246.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: These data are based on porpoises which were caught in Danish waters, this may lead to sampling bias (when intending to represent populations in Swedish waters). The porpoise population data were log transformed before being used in Symphony – this ‘smooths’ the data providing a more general data trend. It is intended to ensure the data is conservatively interpreted. Smoothing the data does however decrease the spatial specificity and the relative importance of specific spatial ‘hotspots’ which could be linked for example to seabed features.
recommendations_for_data_improvement:
The effect of pressures on the different populations (i.e. Belt-sea, Baltic and North Sea population) should be evaluated separately as sensitivity may vary due to the large difference in total population size. Collection of additional data from animals in Swedish waters would enhance data quality. Further work to test for spatial relationships between the porpoise population and predictor
variables (e.g. seabed/water column features) might provide additional insight relevant to
spatial planning.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has significant limitations, including sampling bias due to porpoises being caught in Danish waters for a layer intended to represent Swedish waters, and the log transformation 'smoothing' the data, which decreases spatial specificity and the importance of hotspots. The recommendations explicitly call for collecting additional data from animals in Swedish waters and evaluating the effect of pressures on different porpoise populations separately, which implies a need for more nuanced and spatially specific data. These are fundamental issues requiring new data collection and potentially a re-evaluation of the modeling approach to capture spatial hotspots, indicating a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, particularly collecting additional data from animals in Swedish waters, is a 'high' difficulty task. It involves significant resources for animal tagging, tracking, and data processing. Furthermore, testing for spatial relationships with predictor variables (e.g., seabed/water column features) and potentially re-evaluating the smoothing approach would require advanced analytical expertise and potentially new modeling techniques. Addressing sampling bias fundamentally requires new data collection, which is resource-intensive.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly generate or significantly improve this layer. The layer is based on tracking individual porpoises using satellite tags, which is a form of in-situ biological sampling and telemetry, not remote sensing of environmental parameters. While satellite remote sensing can provide environmental context (e.g., SST, chlorophyll), it cannot directly measure porpoise distribution or population density. The core data for this layer comes from animal tracking, which is distinct from satellite remote sensing of the marine environment.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden's primary offerings (Sentinel-2 Level-2A data and national land cover data) are not directly applicable to generating or improving this porpoise distribution layer. These datasets are focused on optical imagery for land and shallow coastal waters, land cover, and coastal development. They do not provide information on marine mammal distribution, population density, or the specific environmental parameters (e.g., deep-water features, prey distribution) that might influence porpoise movements. The data required for improvement (animal tracking in Swedish waters) is outside the scope of DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations explicitly state a significant sampling bias due to porpoises being caught only in Danish waters, which may not represent populations in Swedish waters. The recommendation is to collect additional data from animals in Swedish waters, which is a fundamental data collection overhaul. Furthermore, the log transformation 'smooths' the data, decreasing spatial specificity and the relative importance of hotspots, which is a methodological issue that could be addressed by a different approach or by providing both smoothed and unsmoothed data. These issues point to a need for substantial new data collection and potential methodological re-evaluation.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Collecting additional data from satellite-tagged porpoises in Swedish waters is a highly resource-intensive and complex undertaking. It involves catching, tagging, and tracking animals, requiring significant expertise, funding, and logistical coordination. Addressing the smoothing issue might involve re-evaluating the transformation or presenting raw data, but the primary limitation (sampling bias) requires a major new data collection program, which is inherently high difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing, as typically understood for marine applications (e.g., SST, chlorophyll, ocean color), cannot directly track individual porpoises or assess their population density. The data collection method described (satellite-tagged porpoises) uses satellites for data transmission from tags, but the core data generation relies on in-situ animal tagging and tracking, not remote sensing of the marine environment itself. Therefore, satellite remote sensing cannot help generate or improve this layer in the context of its primary data source.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, with its focus on Sentinel-2 optical imagery and national land cover data, is primarily suited for terrestrial and shallow coastal applications. It does not provide capabilities for tracking marine mammals, assessing their population densities, or collecting the type of biological data (animal movements) that forms the basis of this porpoise layer. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden data cannot help generate or improve this layer.

summary: The raster layer intends to show the predicted distribution of Ringed seals in Swedish marine waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to zero abundance and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high relative abundance. Underlying data are inventory data from national monitoring (2010-2015) that have been modelled. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen abundans, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög relativ abundans. Underlagsdata är inventeringsdata från nationell övervakning (2010-2015), som modellerats. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna. lineage: Data are inventory point data (2010-2015) collected as part of national monitoring of Ringed Seals from the Swedish Ocean Archive (Svenska Hav Arkiv - SHARK) at the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI). Data processing took the following steps: 1. Interpolate point data using a search window with a radius of 60 km (home range). 2. Compensate the distribution to account for the ratio of land/water within the home range for each cell. 3. Adjust to SYMPHONY requirements and normalise.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: No limitations identified by SLU
recommendations_for_data_improvement: No recommendations suggested by SLU

other_restrictions: This "Ringed Seal" dataset is a derived from monitoring data collected by Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua) and the Museum of Natural History in Stockholm (NRM). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences Department of Aquatic Resources (SLU Aqua) and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: While no limitations or recommendations were explicitly identified by SLU, the temporal period (2010-2015) is outdated for a layer intended for current marine spatial planning. Updating this layer with more recent inventory data would be a moderate improvement. Additionally, the interpolation method (60km search window) and normalization to Symphony requirements could potentially be refined or validated with more recent data or advanced modeling techniques, moving beyond simple updates.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Updating the layer with newer inventory data from SHARK would require data acquisition, processing, and re-running the existing modeling steps (interpolation, land/water compensation, normalization). This is a moderate effort, requiring coordination with data providers and technical expertise in data processing and GIS. If methodological refinements were also pursued (e.g., exploring alternative interpolation methods or incorporating environmental covariates), the difficulty would lean towards medium.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Ringed seals are marine mammals that are typically observed at the surface or in ice-covered areas. While satellites can monitor sea ice extent and concentration, directly detecting or monitoring ringed seal abundance or distribution from satellite imagery is not feasible. Their small size, subsurface behavior, and the resolution/spectral capabilities of current operational satellites make direct detection impossible. The layer is based on inventory point data, which are collected through in-situ surveys (e.g., aerial surveys, ice surveys).
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily provides Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are not suitable for directly monitoring marine mammal populations like ringed seals. Sentinel-2's capabilities are focused on land and shallow, clear coastal waters, and it lacks the resolution or specialized sensors needed for marine mammal detection or for providing environmental parameters directly relevant to seal distribution in deeper or ice-covered waters. The land cover data is terrestrial and not directly applicable to marine species distribution modeling.

name: Angiosperms
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster layer intends to show the predicted increase in sea surface water acidity (i.e. decrease in pH) due to global climate change by the year 2050. Source data are from the North American Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and are based on the Representative Concentration Pathway climate forecast model - RCP8.5 which is a baseline climate scenario ( with comparatively high greenhouse gas emissions) . A cell value of zero is equivalent to no change in ocean acidity by the year 2050 and a cell value of 100 equates to a pH decrease of 0.2 by 2050. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad ökad havsförsurning (dvs. minskat pH) på grund av globala klimatförändringar vid år 2050. Källdata kommer från North American Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) och baseras på the Representative Concentration Pathway climate forecast model - RCP8.5 vilken är ett baseline klimatscenario
(med jämförelsevis höga utsläpp av växthusgaser). Ett cellvärde av 0
motsvarar ingen förändring i aciditet vid år 2050, och ett cellvärde av 100
motsvarar en minskning i pH med 0,2 vid år 2050. Denna data skapades
som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten
för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony
används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av
mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt
efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: The raster shows sea acidification by 2050, modelled by NOAA with scenario RCP8.5 (note - RCP stands for representative concentration pathway which is a set of socio-economic assumptions which are used to build a climate scenario. In this scenario there is a rising radiative forcing pathway leading with human emissions resulting in a 8.5 watts per square meter output by 2100. This is a high global anthropogenic radiative forcing scenario. Details about the scenario can be found here: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10584-011-0149-y Two datasets from NOAAs geophysical fluid dynamics laboratory were downloaded from https://esg-dn1.nsc.liu.se/search/cmip5/ Data ID = cmip5.output1.NOAA-GFDL.GFDL- ESM2G.rcp85.yr.ocnBgchem.Oyr.r1i1p1.v20110601|esgdata.gfdl.noaa.gov Data ID = cmip5.output1.NOAA-GFDL.GFDL- ESM2M.rcp85.yr.ocnBgchem.Oyr.r1i1p1.v20110601|esgdata.gfdl.noaa.go v Ocean acidity data were extracted from the NetCDF files for the baseline (a mean of the 2006-2010) and for the 2050 prediction (mean of the 2046-2050 period) The coordinate system was transformed from tripole grid to ETRS89 and these point data were interpolated to create raster data layers. The rasters were resample to the standard 250m symphony grid. For each model the difference between the baseline dataset and the modelled 2050 future was calculated and a single pH change dataset was created. The average of the ESM2G / ESM2M ocean oriented earth system model runs was used for the final product. The raster was then normalized (linear stretch) to values between 0 - 100 where maximum value 100 = 0.2 pH increase (the maximum average predicted increase).
limitations_for_use_in_symphony:
NOAAs ocean acidification data is modelled at a global scale and as a consequence it does
not have a high spatial resolution (50km grid) and local hydrological and biophysical
conditions are not factored into this model prediction (due to the high cost in computing
power). This will significantly increase the model uncertainty.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: SMHIs work on climate model downscaling based on the combination of global modelled data and their regional climate model (RCO) has been useful tool for the development of higher resolution prediction in Sweden. At present ocean acifidification is not included as a parameter in any regional models - it would be a useful addition.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Climate change acidification" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the United States National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer's primary limitation is its low spatial resolution (50km grid) and the lack of local hydrological and biophysical conditions, leading to significant model uncertainty. The recommendation explicitly points to the need for 'climate model downscaling' and the inclusion of 'ocean acidification as a parameter in regional models'. This requires a fundamental methodological overhaul, integrating global models with regional climate models (like SMHI's RCO) and developing new regional ocean acidification models, which constitutes a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, specifically downscaling global ocean acidification models and integrating them with regional climate models (like SMHI's RCO) to account for local conditions, is a complex task. It would require significant computational resources, advanced modeling expertise, and extensive coordination between different modeling groups (e.g., NOAA, SMHI). This falls under 'high' difficulty as it involves developing new methodologies for a parameter not currently included in regional models.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly measure ocean pH or acidity. While satellites can provide data on sea surface temperature, salinity (to some extent), and other parameters that influence ocean chemistry, they do not directly measure the concentration of dissolved CO2 or pH. The core issue here is a chemical parameter that requires in-situ measurements or complex biogeochemical models, not direct satellite observation.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are valuable for terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping (e.g., land use, vegetation, coastal development) but do not provide direct measurements or proxies for ocean acidification. The limitations of the layer are related to ocean chemistry modeling at a regional scale, which is outside the scope of DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings.

name: Climate change temperature
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster layer intends to show the predicted increase in sea surface temperature due to global climate change by the year 2050 in Swedish inshore and offshore waters. The source data for this product are from the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI) and are based on their RCO -SCOBI emission scenario A2 ( which is predicts comparatively high greenhouse gas emissions). A cell value of zero is equivalent to no sea surface temperature increase by the year 2050 and a cell value of 100 equates to a temperature increase of 2 degrees Celsius by 2050 (the highest increase predicted in the Symphony study area. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad ökning av ytvattenstemperatur på grund av globala klimatförändringar vid år 2050, i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Källdata för denna produkt kommer från Sveriges
meteorologiska och hydrologiska institut (SMHI) och är
baserat på deras RCO-SCOBI emission scenario A2 (vilken
förutsäger jämförelsevis höga utsläpp av växthusgaser). Ett
cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen ökning av
ytvattenstemperatur vid år 2050, och ett cellvärde av 100
motsvarar en temperaturökning med 2 grader Celsius vid år
2050 (den högsta beräknada ökningen inom Symphonys
studieområde). Denna data skapades som ett data input
layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för
havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV).
Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den
kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska
vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av
denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter
vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: This dataset shows the temperature change (difference between baseline mean 2010-2029 and future mean value for 2035-2064 was calculated based on the regional climate predictions produced by SMHI with their RCO-SCOBI coupled biogeochemical model using forcing data based on the IPCC's A2 scenario (high global emissions). A more detailed description of SMHIs modelling and the results can be found here: https://www.diva- portal.org/smash/get/diva2:947527/FULLTEXT01.pdf More detail on the A2 global emission scenario described by IPCC https://ipcc.ch/pdf/special-reports/spm/sres-en.pdf SMHI's RCO-SCOBI model does not cover the entire Symphony area (missing the Kattegat) so a blanking value is used here. The model has a spatial resolution of 3.7km. Summer mean sea surface temperature predictions were extracted from the SMHI dataset for 2010-2029 and 2035- 2064 and mean values calculated. The difference between these values was used to create a predicted temperature increase dataset. Grids have been normalized to values between 0 - 100 where maximum value 100 = 2 degrees Celsius increase (the maximum predicted change).
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: Only data for the Baltic and the Kattegat were available and therefore a uniform temperature increase level was used for the Skagerrak.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Data are required for the whole of Swedish waters and therefore new data should be requested from SMHI - perhaps the data from RCO-SCOBI could be combined with lower resolution data from EURO-CORDEX to provide a prediction for the Kattegat area. http://www.euro-cordex.net/ The RCO-SCOBI model is 4D so it would also be useful to understand the changes in deep water conditions as this may be more useful for understanding impacts on benthic species and ecosystems.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: global temperature increase, climate change impact
other_restrictions: This "Climate change temperature" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states limitations regarding missing data for the Skagerrak (uniform temperature increase used) and the Kattegat (blanking value used). The recommendations suggest requesting new data from SMHI for the whole of Swedish waters and combining RCO-SCOBI data with EURO-CORDEX for the Kattegat. This requires integrating additional data sources and expanding geographic coverage, which falls under 'medium' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations involves requesting new data from SMHI, potentially combining different model outputs (RCO-SCOBI and EURO-CORDEX), and integrating these into the existing layer. This requires coordination with SMHI, data processing, and potentially some methodological adjustments for data integration, placing it in the 'medium' difficulty category.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer predicts future sea surface temperature increases based on climate models (SMHI's RCO-SCOBI and potentially EURO-CORDEX). While current sea surface temperature can be measured by satellites, predicting future changes requires climate modeling, not direct satellite observation. Satellites cannot directly generate or improve future climate model outputs for temperature increase predictions.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily provides Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. These datasets are suitable for terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping, land use, and vegetation analysis. They do not provide sea surface temperature data, climate model outputs, or capabilities to predict future oceanographic conditions. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden data cannot help generate or improve this specific layer.

name: Habitat loss coastal exploitation
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: The raster layer intends to show the predicted coastal exploitation within a zone 300 m from the water line along the Swedish coast. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no exploitation and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high exploitation. Underlying data are from two sources and consist of presence data, in the form of shape files, for houses and building (2013), harbours and marinas (2010) , and jetties/docks/piers (2010) that have been modelled and combined. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad kustexploatering inom en zon av 300 m från vattenlinjen längs den svenska kusten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen exploatering, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög grad av exploatering. Underlagsdata härrör från två källor och består av förekomstdata i form av shape-filer för hus och byggnader (2013), hamnar och marinor (2010) och bryggor/kajer/pirar (2010) som har modellerats och kombinerats. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: This layer was produced by converting three layers “beach exploitation (strandexploatering)” (from the County Administrative Board of Norrland, shapefile, polygon), “jetties/docks/piers (bryggor)” and “harbours/marinas (hamn/marina)” (from the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency, shapefiles, polygon and point) to a raster with Symphony standard raster resolution (i.e. 250 m grid cells). Layers were then weighted according to agreed upon values (1 beach exploitation, 3 jetties/docks/piers, 10 harbours), and mosaicked to a single layer and normalised.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: These data are weighted to give emphasis to marine development (harbours and docks). This product assumes that habitat change due to development equates to loss. In some circumstances habitat may be created due to development. This is not considered in these data.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Provide justification for weighting: for example is there some evidence to justify why harbours are given a 10 times higher impact score? Update with latest data (currently under production by METRIA). Determine if there is a requirement to extract certain development types for addition to an artificial reef dataset.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: coastal development, habitat loss, environmental impact
other_restrictions:
This "Habitat loss coastal exploitation" dataset is a derived in part from source data provided by Country Administrative Board of Norrland and the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency. This derived dataset is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0
International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to
Medins Havs och Vattenkonsulter AB and was produced
on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water
Management (SwAM). Data sources should be
acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from
it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has fundamental methodological issues and data gaps. The 'Limitations' explicitly state that the product assumes habitat change due to development equates to loss and does not consider habitat creation, which is a significant conceptual flaw. The 'Recommendations' suggest justifying the weighting (implying a need for evidence-based impact scoring rather than 'agreed upon values'), updating with latest data, and potentially extracting development types for an artificial reef dataset. Addressing the assumption of 'loss only' and providing evidence-based weighting would require a fundamental re-evaluation of the impact model, moving beyond simple presence data and 'agreed upon' weights to a more nuanced understanding of ecological impact. Updating data and potentially extracting new datasets also points to a need for substantial data integration and processing.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: While updating data (from METRIA) might be straightforward, justifying the weighting with evidence and potentially re-conceptualizing the 'impact' to account for habitat creation would require significant research, ecological modeling expertise, and potentially new data collection or analysis. This moves beyond simple data updates to a more complex methodological overhaul. Integrating new data sources and potentially creating new datasets (e.g., for artificial reefs) also adds to the complexity, requiring moderate technical expertise and coordination.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can significantly help improve this layer. High-resolution optical satellite imagery (e.g., from Sentinel-2, or commercial providers) can be used to: 1) Update and verify the presence of houses, buildings, harbours, marinas, jetties/docks/piers, and other coastal infrastructure more frequently and systematically than relying on disparate shapefiles from different years. 2) Monitor coastal land use change and development over time, providing more current data than 2010-2013. 3) Potentially identify areas of habitat change (both loss and creation) by observing changes in coastal morphology, vegetation, and water quality indicators, although direct 'habitat creation' assessment would be challenging without ground truth. 4) Provide a consistent and repeatable method for mapping coastal exploitation indicators.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, specifically through its Sentinel-2 Level-2A data products and national land cover data, can directly contribute to generating and improving this layer. Sentinel-2 imagery can be used for: 1) Updating the spatial extent and presence of coastal infrastructure (houses, buildings, harbours, marinas, jetties/docks/piers) more frequently and consistently. 2) Monitoring coastal land use and land cover changes associated with exploitation. 3) The national land cover data can provide a baseline for identifying developed areas and changes over time. This allows for more current and consistent data input for the 'exploitation' layer, addressing the temporal limitation and potentially providing a more robust basis for identifying developed areas than the current disparate shapefiles.
