name: Habitat loss dumping
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster intends to show areas where potential habitat loss can occur from dredge spoil dumping in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. Underlying data are from two sources of data which consist of a point vector dataset detailing the location of licensed dredge disposal sites (from 2014) and benthic substrate data (from 2006). The dataset is binary and a cell value of 0 is equivalent to no risk of habitat loss due dredge spoil dumping and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a risk of habitat loss due to dredge spoil dumping. Note that no specific information were available in a national data archive detailing the source, type and volume of sediment being dumped. This has been approximated
through analysis of surrounding sediment types. These data
were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool
developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish
Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM).
Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative
environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters
and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area
scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only
advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa områden där habitatförlust potentiellt kan förekomma på grund av dumpning av muddermassor i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Underlagsdata härrör från två datakällor bestående av ett rasterskikt med punktvektorer som specificerar plats för licensierade muddringsanläggningar (från 2014), och bentisk substratdata (från 2006). Detta rasterskikt är binärt och ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen risk för habitatförlust på grund av dumpning av muddermassor, ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar risk för habitatförlust på grund av dumpning av muddermassor. Observera att ingen specifik information fanns tillgänglig i nationella dataarkiv angående källa, typ och volym av dumpade sediment istället har detta skattats utifrån analys av omgivningens sediment. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
This data was created based on the assumption that dumping spoils with a different grain size will lead to habitat loss in the short term (although this is likely reversible). Two source datasets were used in the model. The location of licenced dredge disposal sites was provided by the Geological Survey of Sweden and this was in turn derived from data supplied by the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). The second dataset used was dominant sediment type derived from Helcom's 2006 Balance project. Each point location record was allocated the bottom substrate type derived from the sediment dataset using a spatial join and then each site was buffered by 200m. A comparison of the sediment type at each site and the nearest port was undertaken and differences between sediment types were used to guide a spatial selection of sites which are
likely to result in habitat loss.
These vector data were then translated to a binary raster file
matching the Symphony grid specification.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: Metadata indicates that substrate data from HELCOM's 2006 Balance project was used rather than the updated substrate data produced by SGU for this project. The sites are buffered by 200m (note that this means some sites cover 1 cell and others 3 depending on the location of the point).
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Data detailing the location sites licenced for dredge dumping sites is not well managed. The locations of dumpsites were updated to 2015 by SGU based on information provided by SwAM but no attribution for example detailing the quantities of sediment were available so it was not possible to model the relative impact at different sites. This could be improved in a future model iteration. There are currently some data on HELCOM's portal (HOLAS 2) and EMODNET human activities portal detailing dumping sites but little metadata is available.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: coastal development, ocean dumping, habitat loss, environmental impact
other_restrictions:
This "Habitat loss dumping" dataset is a derived from source data provided by Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM) and the Swedish County Administration Boards (LS) and the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to DHI Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or
navigation purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has significant limitations, including outdated benthic substrate data (2006 vs. updated SGU data), lack of specific information on source, type, and volume of dumped sediment, and a simplified binary risk assessment. The recommendation explicitly states that 'it was not possible to model the relative impact at different sites' due to data gaps, suggesting a need for a more nuanced and quantitative impact assessment. Approximating sediment type through surrounding areas is a major simplification. Addressing these issues would require integrating new, more detailed data (sediment quantities, types, and sources) and potentially a more sophisticated modeling approach beyond a simple binary classification, moving towards a 'large' improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: While the improvements are substantial, they don't necessarily require entirely new, unproven methodologies. The core challenge lies in data acquisition and integration, specifically obtaining better managed and more detailed dredge dumping site data (quantities, types, sources) and updating benthic substrate information. This would involve significant coordination with data providers (SwAM, SGU, HELCOM, EMODNET) and potentially developing a more complex spatial model for impact assessment, but it's within the realm of established data management and spatial analysis techniques. This falls under 'medium' difficulty, as it requires moderate technical expertise, coordination, and resource investment.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing is unlikely to directly help generate or significantly improve this layer. The layer focuses on habitat loss due to dredge spoil dumping, which requires detailed information on the dumped material (type, volume, source) and the benthic substrate. Satellites can provide information on water column turbidity or suspended sediments, which might indicate dumping events, but they cannot directly characterize the dumped material's properties or the long-term benthic habitat changes at the resolution and depth required. Benthic substrate mapping from satellites is generally limited to very shallow, clear waters, and the primary data gaps here are related to the specifics of the dumping operations and the underlying benthic habitat, which are best assessed through in-situ sampling or detailed bathymetric surveys.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover, is not suitable for improving this layer. The layer's core data needs are related to sub-surface benthic habitats, specific dredge spoil characteristics (grain size, volume), and precise locations of dumping sites, none of which can be directly derived or significantly enhanced by Sentinel-2 imagery or terrestrial land cover data. Sentinel-2's capabilities are limited to shallow, clear waters for bathymetry or habitat mapping, and it cannot provide the detailed information on sediment properties or the impact of dumping on the seabed that this layer requires.

name: Habitat loss Infrastructure
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show the loss of habitat due to physical infrastructure on the seabed in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. The source data includes coastal features (road and rail bridges, lighthouses) and the nordstream pipeline. The data were derived primarily from Lantmateriets open data (terrain map and road map). A cell value of zero is equivalent to no habitat loss and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a complete replacement of habitat. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa habitatförlust på grund av fysisk infrastruktur på havsbotten i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Källdata inkluderar kustområden (väg- och järnvägsbroar, fyrar) och Nord Streams rörledning. Data kommer huvudsakligen från Lantmäteriets öppna data (Terrängkartan och Vägkartan). Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen habitatförlust, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar fullständig habitatförändring. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: Source data for this layer are: Lighthouses from Lantmäteriet's Terrain map (tk_riks_Sweref_99_TM_shape.zip) downloaded 20160816 Railway bridges from Lantmäteriet's Road Map (vk_riks_Sweref_99_TM_shape.zip) downloaded 20160816 Road bridges from Lantmäteriet's Road map (vk_riks_Sweref_99_TM_shape.zip) downloaded 20160816 Pipelines (Nord stream) provided by the Swedish Agency for Water Management These data were processed as follows: Clip lighthouses in the sea, remove lighthouses on land and create a polygon with buffer (25m), manual position corrections with aerial photography. Clip roads in the sea, remove roads that are on land and create polygon with buffer (25m), manual position corrections with aerial photography. Clip railways in the sea, remove railways on land and create polygon with buffer (25m), manual position corrections with aerial photography. Create polygon with buffer (25m) around the Nord Stream pipeline Copy and paste each layer to a single layer. Scale so presence = 100 and absence = 0.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The model is limited in source data for example coastal features such as docks and piers and anchored offshore navigational features such as buoys or markers and offshore windfarm turbines are not included. The assumption the habitat is lost within 25m is very simplistic.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Add additional features. Wind turbine data are available from the Swedish National Grid, aids to navigation are available from the Swedish Maritime Authority and docks and piers are available from the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency. Gather attribution on feature dimensions that could be used to refine the model.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: coastal development, habitat loss, environmental impact
other_restrictions: This "Habitat loss Infrastructure" dataset is a derived from data provided by the Swedish transport authority (STA) and the Swedish mapping, cadastral and land registration authority (LM). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to Medins Havs och Vattenkonsulter AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly lists several missing features (docks, piers, buoys, markers, offshore windfarm turbines) and recommends adding them. It also suggests gathering attribution on feature dimensions to refine the model, moving beyond the simplistic 25m buffer. These additions and refinements represent a moderate expansion of data sources and methodological improvements, but not a complete overhaul.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations involves integrating data from multiple new sources (Swedish National Grid for wind turbines, Swedish Maritime Authority for aids to navigation, Swedish Environmental Protection Agency for docks/piers). This requires data acquisition, processing, and integration, potentially with varying formats and spatial accuracies. Refining the model based on feature dimensions would also require more sophisticated spatial analysis than simple buffering. This level of integration and refinement falls into the 'medium' difficulty category, requiring moderate technical expertise and coordination.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can contribute to improving this layer. High-resolution optical satellite imagery (e.g., from commercial providers or even Sentinel-2 in clear coastal waters) can assist in identifying and mapping coastal infrastructure like docks, piers, and potentially even larger buoys or offshore wind turbine foundations, especially in shallow, clear waters. While not directly providing 'habitat loss' values, it can help in the accurate spatial delineation and verification of the physical infrastructure that causes the loss. Satellite-derived bathymetry could also indirectly inform the context of these structures in shallow areas.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, specifically through its Sentinel-2 Level-2A data products and national land cover data, can help improve this layer. Sentinel-2 imagery can be used to identify and map coastal infrastructure such as docks, piers, and potentially the footprints of larger lighthouses or bridges, especially where they extend into the water. The national land cover data could provide a baseline for coastal land use and help in distinguishing land-based infrastructure from marine infrastructure. While it won't directly identify all offshore features like buoys or pipelines, it can significantly aid in the mapping and verification of near-shore and coastal structures, addressing some of the identified limitations.

name: Synthetic toxins treatment plant
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show areas with potential synthetic toxin contamination associated with wastewater treatment plants in Swedish coastal waters (≤ 500 m from coast). Underlying data consists of wastewater treatment plant presence data in the form of shapefiles. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to low potential water contamination (> 1000 m from wastewater treatment plant) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to potential water contamination (≤ 1000 m from wastewater treatment plant). These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa områden med avloppsreningsverk i svenska kustvatten (≤ 500 m från kust) som potentiellt är förorenade med syntetiska miljögifter. Underlagsdata består av avloppsreningsverksdata i form av shape-filer. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg potentiell vattenförorening (> 1000 m från avloppsreningsverk), och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar potentiell vattenförorening (≤ 1000 m från avloppsreningsverk). Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: This dataset is based on vector data sourced from the Swedish County Administration Boards known as "SE.US Miljöförvaltningsanläggningar" which is published as an open INSPIRE compliant dataset on Sweden's INSPIRE geodata portal: www.geodata.se. This data shows permitted environmentally hazardous activities. This data includes wastewater treatment plants and other industrial activities and their operational status. This dataset was last compiled in 2013. All wastewater treatment plant sites within 500m of the coast (identified with a spatial query) were extracted and these selected point records were buffered with a 1000m buffer. This buffered dataset was then converted to a raster format.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The 1000 buffer is a simplistic risk estimate. The data includes only sites within 500m of the coast and does not therefore include the influence of upstream effluent releases.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Develop a clear rationale for applying any buffer. Ideally use a spatially graduated reduction in impact risk with distance (rather than a binary high/no impact. Model the influence of upstream effluent release locations (for example by scaling river mouth locations depending on number of upstream sites). Gather empirical data and information (e.g. from SEPA/County Admin monitoring) which can be used to develop and validate a better model of spatial risk of organic/synthetic toxin pollution. Water quality monitoring data can be downloaded from http://viss.lansstyrelsen.se and sediment pollution data is available from SGU https://www.sgu.se/produkter/geologiska-data/oppna-data/maringeologi-oppna- data/marina-data-i-atomfloden/ Gather attribute information on for example from the county admin boards that could be used to modify risk levels (based on data such as volumes permitted to be released) and environmental criteria (such as data on currents / sediments). The frequency of emergency discharges might also be a factor for scaling impact risk - for example: http://www.nsva.se/var-verksamhet/spillvatten/braddning-och-nodavlopp/
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: coastal development, waste water treatment, chemical pollution, environmental impact
other_restrictions: This "Synthetic toxins treatment plant" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish County Administration Boards (Länsstyrelse). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to DHI Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer's limitations highlight fundamental issues with its current methodology, specifically the simplistic 1000m buffer and the exclusion of upstream effluent releases. The recommendations suggest a complete overhaul of the risk assessment, moving from a binary high/no impact to a spatially graduated reduction, incorporating upstream influences, gathering empirical validation data, and integrating attribute information like discharge volumes and environmental criteria (currents/sediments). This requires a fundamental re-conceptualization of the risk model, moving beyond simple spatial proximity to a more complex, data-driven predictive approach, which constitutes a 'large' improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements would be 'high' difficulty. It requires developing a new, spatially graduated risk model (rather than a simple buffer), integrating diverse new data sources (empirical monitoring data from VISS/SGU, attribute information on discharge volumes, environmental criteria like currents/sediments, emergency discharge frequency), and potentially modeling upstream influences. This involves significant data integration challenges, advanced spatial modeling techniques, and extensive coordination with multiple data providers (SEPA, County Admin, SGU, NSVA). It moves beyond simple data updates to a complex, multi-variate modeling approach.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can significantly help improve this layer. While direct 'synthetic toxin' detection is not feasible, satellite data can provide crucial environmental criteria for a more nuanced risk model. For example, ocean color sensors can provide data on water quality parameters like turbidity and suspended sediments, which are relevant to pollutant dispersion and accumulation. Sea surface temperature and altimetry can inform current patterns, which are critical for modeling pollutant transport. Coastal land use and development, detectable by high-resolution optical satellites, can indicate areas of higher human activity and potential pollution sources. Satellite-derived bathymetry could refine understanding of shallow water environments influencing pollutant pathways. While not directly measuring toxins, these parameters are essential inputs for a more sophisticated spatial risk model.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden can contribute to improving this layer, primarily through its Sentinel-2 Level-2A data and national land cover data. Sentinel-2 can be used to map coastal land use and infrastructure, identify impervious surfaces, and monitor changes in coastal development, which are indirect indicators of potential pollution sources or pathways. While its water penetration is limited to clear, shallow waters, it can still provide insights into coastal morphology and land-sea interface characteristics. The national land cover data can provide detailed information on land use around wastewater treatment plants, which could be used to infer potential upstream influences or the nature of the surrounding environment. However, DigitalEarthSweden's capabilities are primarily terrestrial/coastal and optical, meaning it cannot directly provide oceanographic parameters like currents or detailed water quality chemistry, which would still require other satellite or in-situ sources.

name: Explosions peak
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show predicted time integrated peak overpressure (kPa) after detonations equivalent to 236 kg of TNT from defence detonation practice areas in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to 70 kPa peak overpressure or less and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to 2500 kPa peak overpressure or more at 52 occasions per year. Underlying data consists of presence data in the form of shapefiles that have then been modelled. This raster refers to pressure waves (which may impact all marine life), these spread less efficiently through the water than sound so sound / noise from explosions are represented separately in a layer named 'Explosion SEL'. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa det beräknada tidsintegrerade trycket (peak overpressure kPa) till följd av sprängning motsvarande 236 kg TNT inom försvarets sprängövningsområden i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ett tryck av 70 kPa eller mindre (vid dessa nivåer eller under har ingen påverkan på tumlare observerats), och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar ett tryck av 2500 kPa eller mer under 52 tillfälle per år. Underlagsdata består av förekomstdata i form av shape-filer som har modellerats. Detta skikt avser tryckvågor (som kan påverka allt marint liv), dessa sprids mindre effektivt via vattnet än ljudet så ljud / buller från explosioner representeras separat i ett skikt med namnet "Explosion SEL". Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
A link between peak over pressure (kPA) and distance from detonation from Benda-Beckmann et al., 2015 (Assessing the Impact of Underwater Clearance of Unexploded Ordnance on Harbour Porpoises) was used. kPA from an explosion with a force equivalent to 263 kg TNT was then modelled from the Swedish Armed Forces’ detonation practice areas.
Values above the highest value (i.e. 2500 kPa) measured by
Benda-Beckman et al., 2015 were used as the maximum
value in the raster (i.e. cell value of 100). The resulting raster
was linearly normalised with the minimum value (i.e. cell
value of 0) representing the threshold where detrimental
effects are unlikely (i.e. 70 kPa).
Results were time integrated using reports of historical
(2015) number of explosions in permitted areas and
assuming a weekly recovery time (thus 52 explosions per
year genereates maximum score).
There is insufficient information available from the Swedish
Armed Forces to assess whether the scale of the detonations
is reasonable with respect to the Armed Forces’ activities
within respective detonation areas. Discussion on the
method did not occur between WSP (consultant) and the
Swedish Armed Forces (data source).
More detailed information on the lineage and methodology
is available and can be supplied on request to the data
owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The data available for modelling consists of the location of the practice areas used by the military and not the specific location, type or frequency of explosions and as a consequence the impact levels can only be assumed.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Gather additional attribution from the Armed Forces detailing typical loading weights in each area, in order to adjust the modelling to the appropriate type of detonation. Gather positional data on the specific locations of explosion detonations in order to improve the spatial data resolution of the predicted impacts.

This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to the Geological Survey of Sweden and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states that the data available for modeling consists only of practice area locations, not specific detonation locations, types, or frequencies. This leads to assumed impact levels. The recommendations call for gathering detailed attribution on loading weights and positional data on specific detonations. This requires fundamental new data collection and a significant overhaul of the underlying modeling, moving from assumed impacts based on broad areas to more precise, location-specific predictions. This constitutes a major improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations requires significant coordination with the Swedish Armed Forces to obtain highly sensitive and detailed operational data (loading weights, specific detonation locations and frequencies). This involves overcoming data access barriers, potentially establishing new data sharing protocols, and then integrating this new, granular data into a revised modeling framework. The current methodology is based on broad assumptions due to lack of data, so acquiring and utilizing this detailed information would be a complex and resource-intensive undertaking, requiring advanced technical expertise and extensive coordination.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer models peak overpressure from underwater explosions. Satellite remote sensing cannot directly measure underwater pressure waves or the specific characteristics of underwater detonations (e.g., TNT equivalent, depth, frequency). While satellites can monitor surface phenomena, the core data needed for this layer (underwater explosion characteristics and their resulting pressure waves) is not observable from space. Therefore, satellite data cannot help generate or improve this layer.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily provides Sentinel-2 optical imagery and national land cover data. These datasets are useful for terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping, land use, and some water quality parameters (e.g., turbidity). However, they do not provide information relevant to underwater acoustic or pressure phenomena, nor can they detect or characterize underwater explosions or their impacts. The data needed for this layer (detonation specifics, pressure wave propagation) is entirely outside the scope of DigitalEarthSweden's capabilities.

name: Explosions SEL
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
The raster layer intends to show predicted time integrated sound exposure levels (SEL) after detonations equivalent to 236 kg of TNT from defence detonation practice areas in Swedish inshore and offshore waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to 164 dB re 1 uPa SEL or less (at this level or below no effects on porpoises are observed) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to 216 dB re 1 uPa SEL or more at 52 occasions per year. Underlying data consists of presence data
in the form of shapefiles that have then been modelled.
These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony'
tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish
Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM).
Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative
environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters
and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area
scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only
advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad tidsintegrerad ljudexponeringsnivå (SEL) till följd av sprängning motsvarande 236 kg TNT inom försvarets sprängövningsområden i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar 164 dB re 1 uPa eller lägre (vid dessa nivåer eller lägre har ingen påverkan på tumlare observerats), och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar 216 dB re 1 uPa SEL eller högre vid 52 tillfällen per år. Underlagsdata består av förekomstdata i form av shape-filer som modellerats. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
A link between sound exposure level (SEL) and distance from detonation from Benda-Beckmann et al., 2015 (Assessing the Impact of Underwater Clearance of Unexploded Ordnance on Harbour Porpoises) was used. SEL from an explosion with a force equivalent to 263 kg TNT was then modelled from the Swedish Armed Forces’ detonation practice areas. As information on the localisation of individual detonations was not available it was assumed that a detonation could occur at least once per year anywhere within the detonation practice areas. Values above the highest value (i.e. 216 dB re 1 uPa SEL) measured by Benda- Beckman et al., 2015 were used as the maximum value in the raster (i.e. cell value of 100). The resulting raster was linearly normalised with the minimum value (i.e. cell value 0) representing the threshold where injuries to porpoises are first observed (TTS of 164 dB re 1 uPa SEL) (Benda-Beckman et al., 2015). Results were time integrated using reports of historical (2015) number of explosions in permitted areas and assuming a weekly recovery time (thus 52 explosions per year genereates maximum score). There is insufficient information available from the Swedish
Armed Forces to assess whether the scale of the detonations
is reasonable with respect to the Armed Forces’ activities
within respective detonation areas. Discussion on the
method did not occur between WSP (consultant) and the
Swedish Armed Forces (data source).
More detailed information on the lineage and methodology
is available and can be supplied on request to the data
owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The data available for modelling consists of the location of the practice areas used by the military and not the specific location, type or frequency of explosions and as a consequence the impact levels can only be assumed.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Gather additional attribution from the Armed Forces detailing typical loading weights in each area, in order to adjust the modelling to the appropriate type of detonation. Gather positional data on the specific locations of explosion detonations in order to improve the spatial data resolution of the predicted impacts.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer's limitations explicitly state that the underlying data consists only of practice area locations, not specific explosion locations, types, or frequencies. This leads to assumed impact levels and a lack of spatial resolution for predicted impacts. The recommendations call for gathering additional attribution on typical loading weights and positional data on specific detonation locations. This requires fundamental new data collection and a re-evaluation of the modeling approach, moving from an assumption of 'anywhere within the area' to specific points, which constitutes a major improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements requires significant effort. Gathering detailed attribution on loading weights and precise positional data for military detonations involves extensive coordination with the Armed Forces, who currently do not provide this level of detail (as evidenced by the 'insufficient information' and 'discussion on the method did not occur' statements). This is a data acquisition challenge requiring high-level collaboration and potentially new data collection protocols, making it a high difficulty task.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly generate or improve this layer. The layer models sound exposure levels from underwater explosions, which are acoustic phenomena. Satellites cannot detect underwater sound, nor can they directly observe the specific location, type, or frequency of underwater detonations or the resulting sound propagation. While satellites can monitor some surface activities, they cannot provide the core data needed (detonation specifics, sound levels) for this layer.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden's primary datasets (Sentinel-2 Level-2A and national land cover data) are not relevant for generating or improving this layer. Sentinel-2 is an optical sensor primarily for land and shallow water surface analysis, and cannot detect underwater acoustic events or provide information on military detonation practices. The national land cover data is also terrestrial/coastal and does not relate to underwater sound modeling or military activities in marine waters.

name: Heavy metals military area
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show the predicted risk of inorganic toxin contamination in marine sediments as a consequence of firing in military practice areas in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. The data is a simplistic model which makes the assumption that the sediment contamination from firing ranges is higher towards the centre of practice areas. A value of 100 represents a high risk for high levels of inorganic toxins in sediments and a value of 0 represents toxins at background level. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad risk för oorganiska miljögifter i marina sediment som en följd av skjutningar i militära övningsområden i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Detta data är en förenklad modell vilken gör antagandet att sedimenten är mer förorenade på grund av skjutning närmre centrum av övningsområdet. Ett värde av 100 motsvarar hög risk för höga nivåer av oorganiska miljögifter i sediment, och ett värde av 0 motsvarar bakgrundsnivåer av miljögifter. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
This dataset was created using the national interest (riksinteressen) data from the Swedish Armed Forces detailing 'exercise areas and firing ranges at sea' and military 'areas with an impact on the surroundings' - the data was provided by the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management. Processing was as follows: 1) Firing ranges were imported. 2) Coastal intersection points were calculated 3) Ranges split into 3 layers based on scale and shape - funnel shaped areas were assumed to be ranges that deploy artillery and were split into large - areas over 20,000m2, medium - between 20 and10,000km2 and small - under 5000km2. It was assumed that larger artillery are used in larger firing ranges. 3) Concentric ring buffers were generated from the centroid of the coastal intersection points. 4) Allocate a stepwise score with distance for large ranges 10 - 5km, 30 - 10km, 30 - 15km, 80 - 20km, 60 - 25km, 50 - 30km, 40 - 35km, 30 - 40km, 20 - 45km, 10 > 50km 5) Allocate a stepwise score with distance for medium ranges 10 - 2km, 30 - 4km, 30 - 6km, 80 - 8km, 60 - 10km, 50 - 12km, 40 - 14km, 30 - 16km, 20 - 18km, 10 > 20km 6) Allocate a stepwise score with distance for small ranges 10 - 0.5km, 30 - 1km, 30 - 1.5km, 80 - 2km, 60 - 2.5km, 50 - 3km, 40 - 3.5km, 30 - 4km, 20 - 4.5km, 10 > 5km Note - the spread of fire was assumed to be in an arc with the
dominant area of impact fairly close but diminishing with
distance.
7) All remaining areas (non funnel shaped) were assumed to
be areas with only small arms fire and therefore were
allocated an impact score of 10
8) All data layers were combined into a single raster layer
9) A spatial filter was applied to blur the data (focal
statistics, 5km mean)
10) Data were rescaled on a 0-100 scale and clipped to the
Symphony Grid.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This data is a simplistic model which is based on a number of unverified assumptions. It should therefore be treated as a risk layer which should be validated. In particular the pattern of pressure is an assumption and the level of toxicity due to metals is unknown and assumed based on unverified assumptions. These data should therefore be used with caution.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: The Swedish Armed Forces could provide additional data which can be used to produce an accurate model. Details of the type of firing range, how long they have been operational, the kinds of munitions used now and historically and their metal content, likely firing patterns etc could all be used to produce better models, however it is recognised that these kinds of data might be of a sensitive nature. Any environmental data however should be made available if this exists. A more reliable model with empirical validation would be highly recommended.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: chemical pollution , military activities , environmental impact
other_restrictions: This "Heavy metals military area" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish Armed Forces (Försvarsmakten). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to the Geological Survey of Sweden and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer is based on 'simplistic model' and 'unverified assumptions' regarding the pattern of pressure and level of toxicity. The recommendations explicitly call for a 'more reliable model with empirical validation' and suggest obtaining detailed data from the Swedish Armed Forces (type of firing range, operational history, munitions used, metal content, firing patterns). This indicates a need for a fundamental overhaul of the model and data inputs, moving beyond simple updates or minor methodological refinements.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements would require significant effort. Obtaining sensitive data from the Swedish Armed Forces, which is explicitly mentioned as potentially sensitive, would involve extensive coordination. Developing a 'more reliable model with empirical validation' would likely require advanced modeling techniques and potentially new data collection (e.g., sediment sampling for validation), which is a high resource and expertise undertaking. The current model is based on assumptions, so moving to an empirically validated model is a major shift.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly measure inorganic toxin contamination in marine sediments or the historical use of firing ranges and munitions. While satellites can monitor some aspects of marine environments (e.g., water quality, bathymetry in shallow areas), they do not provide direct measurements of heavy metal concentrations in sediments, which is the core subject of this layer. The data needed for improvement (munitions, firing patterns, actual sediment contamination) are not observable from space.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 data and national land cover, is not suitable for generating or improving this layer. Sentinel-2 is an optical sensor and cannot detect heavy metal contamination in marine sediments. Its capabilities are focused on land and very shallow, clear coastal waters for features like land cover, vegetation, and coastal development. The core data required for improving this layer (details on military activities, types of munitions, and direct sediment contamination measurements) are outside the scope of DigitalEarthSweden's offerings.

name: Disturbance windpower
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
The raster layer intends to show predicted areas surrounding wind power turbines in Swedish coastal and offshore waters where seabirds display avoidance behaviour. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no avoidance behaviour (> 3000 m from wind power turbine) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high relative avoidance behaviour (< 500 m from wind power turbines). Underlying data consists of presence data in the form of a shapefile that has been modelled. Note: The model accuracy is approximately 3 km however there
are no documented general "avoidance distances" for multiple
species or even multiple sites so that data should be used with
some caution. These data were created as a data input layer for
'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the
Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM).
Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative
environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and
this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use
of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the
guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa områden kring vindkraftverk i svenska kust- och havsvatten där sjöfåglar uppvisar undvikande beteende runt vindkraftturbiner. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar inget undvikande beteende (> 3000 m från vindkraftsverk), och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar högt relativt undvikande beteende (< 500 m från vindkraftverk). Underlagsdata består av förekomstdata i form av en shape-fil som har modellerats. Observera att modellnoggrannheten är cirka 3 km, det finns dock inga dokumenterade allmänna ”undvikandeavstånd” för olika arter eller olika områden så denna data bör användas med viss försiktighet. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Data were from the Swedish National Grid (SVK) and included a shape file of offshore wind farms. Data processing was as follows: The distance from the nearest wind power turbines was calculated using a buffer with a fixed distance (500, 1000, 1500, 2250 and 3000 m). The values were aggregated where “the highest value wins”. There is no general rule that dictates distance for avoidance of wind power turbines by seabirds but is instead species and location specific. The lower limit of 3000 m is a theoretical impact distance for avoidance behaviour by seabirds that has been mentioned in environmental impact assessments (Ramböll, 2015). However, the literature does not demonstrate that a known avoidance occurs down to this distance (e.g. the so called synthesis report from Vindval, Green et al., 2011 specifies, as a rule, avoidance at less than 500 m and typically at approx. 100-200 m, with the exception of loons where reduced density has been demonstrated down to approx. 2km). Normalisation was linear
with respect to the areal impact, where areas outside of the
theoretical impact areas (i.e. > 3000 m) were assigned a cell value
of 0 and areas within 500 m of wind power turbines were assigned
a cell value of 100. Discussion of the method occurred between
WSP (consultant) and SWaM (client).
More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is
available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The model accuracy is approximately 3 km however there are no documented general "avoidance distances" for multiple species or even multiple sites so that data should be used with some caution. It may also be important to note that avoidance studies often fail to describe the spatial scale of avoidance and they affected by weather and other behavioural factors. The height of the wind turbines are not included in this model. Mitigation of windfarm construction includes building higher turbines which can theoretically reduce the risk of collision (for some species) - see https://www.bto.org/sites/default/files/u28/downloads/Projects/Final_Report_SOSS02 _BTOReview.pdf.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Commission research or gather evidence on avoidance distances (including scales) and flight heights of species within offshore windfarms. Gather attribution on wind farm turbine dimensions that can be used to modify risk based on turbine size.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions:
This "Disturbance windpower" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish National Grid (SVK). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
(SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set
and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or
navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states that the model accuracy is approximately 3 km and that there are no documented general 'avoidance distances' for multiple species or sites. The recommendations call for commissioning research or gathering evidence on avoidance distances (including scales) and flight heights, and gathering attribution on wind farm turbine dimensions to modify risk based on size. This indicates a fundamental lack of robust empirical data and a need for a complete re-evaluation of the underlying model, moving beyond simple buffer distances to more nuanced, species- and site-specific behavioral models. This constitutes a major improvement requiring substantial new data collection and potentially fundamental methodological overhauls.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements would require significant resources, advanced technical expertise, and extensive coordination. Commissioning new research on avoidance distances and flight heights for multiple species across various sites is a substantial undertaking. Integrating turbine dimensions into a risk model would also require new data and potentially complex modeling. This goes beyond simple data updates or minor methodological refinements, necessitating a new methodology of large complexity with no established general techniques for all species/sites.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing, while excellent for broad-scale environmental parameters (SST, chlorophyll, land cover), cannot directly measure seabird avoidance behavior, flight heights, or species-specific responses to wind turbines. These phenomena require in-situ observations, tracking data (e.g., GPS tagging), and behavioral studies, which are not within the capabilities of current satellite sensors. While satellites can map the location of wind farms, they cannot provide the biological data needed to improve this specific layer.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 data and national land cover, is not suitable for generating or improving this layer. Its capabilities are focused on terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping (land use, vegetation, coastal development). It lacks the ability to monitor seabird behavior, flight paths, or avoidance responses to offshore wind turbines. The data needed for improvement (species-specific avoidance distances, flight heights, turbine dimensions) are not available through DigitalEarthSweden's offerings.

name: Electromagnetic field
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show presence of electromagnetic fields (i.e. presence of high voltage power cables) in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no presence and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to presence. Underlying data are from several different sources and consist of presence data in the form of shapefiles. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa förekomst av elektromagnetiska fält (dvs. förekomst av högspänning kraftledningar) i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen förekomst, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar förekomst. Underlagsdata härrör från flera olika källor och består av förekomstdata i form av shape-filer. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: A compilation of data on underwater cables from the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM) was converted to a raster where grid cells in which sea cables were present were assigned a value of 100 and cells where sea cables were absent were assigned a value of 0. It was assumed that only high voltage power transmission cables produce biologically relevant electromagnetic fields so these were selected from the dataset supplied by SwAM. A review of the literature suggested that areas impacted by electromagnetic fields were well below 250 m (i.e. one grid cell) from the source. Original data on sea cables within Swedish waters were from the Swedish national grid (SVK), E-ON and HELCOM. Discussion on the method occurred between WSP (consultant) and SwAM (client). More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The mapping accuracy varies between the objects in the database. There is a difference in the position of the SwePol cable reported by Svenska Kraftnät and data from 4COffshore. The degree of accuracy within the Swedish EEZ has been estimated to be higher in the SVK data. An extensive inventory of the design of the cables and site-specific conditions is required to determine the surface propagation of the electromagnetic fields. Currently, only where power lines are present, and where electromagnetic fields may occur, are indicated. Modelling of impact on ecosystem components should therefore be performed with caution.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Gather additional attribution detailing the type of cable and design and method of deployment / installation. Determine the positional accuracy of the data and gather references and empirical evidence that can be used to validate assumptions made about the spatial impact of EMF from cables.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Electromagnetic field" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish National Grid (SK), EON and HELCOM. This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The limitations explicitly state that 'Currently, only where power lines are present, and where electromagnetic fields may occur, are indicated. Modelling of impact on ecosystem components should therefore be performed with caution.' and 'An extensive inventory of the design of the cables and site-specific conditions is required to determine the surface propagation of the electromagnetic fields.' The recommendations further suggest to 'Gather additional attribution detailing the type of cable and design and method of deployment / installation' and 'Determine the positional accuracy of the data and gather references and empirical evidence that can be used to validate assumptions made about the spatial impact of EMF from cables.' This indicates a fundamental gap in the layer's ability to represent the actual spatial impact of EMF, moving beyond simple presence/absence to a more nuanced understanding of field propagation and intensity. This requires substantial new data collection (cable design, deployment, site-specific conditions) and potentially a fundamental methodological overhaul to model EMF propagation, which aligns with 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, particularly gathering 'additional attribution detailing the type of cable and design and method of deployment / installation' and conducting an 'extensive inventory' to determine EMF propagation, would require significant resources, advanced technical expertise (e.g., in electromagnetic modeling), and extensive coordination with cable operators and potentially new data collection efforts. Validating assumptions about spatial impact would also involve empirical evidence, which can be costly and complex to acquire. This aligns with 'high' difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly detect or measure electromagnetic fields from underwater cables. While satellites can map some aspects of the marine environment (e.g., bathymetry in shallow waters, sea surface temperature, chlorophyll), they do not have the capability to sense sub-surface infrastructure like power cables or the electromagnetic fields they generate. The data required for improvement (cable design, deployment, site-specific conditions, and EMF propagation) are not observable from space.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden's primary datasets (Sentinel-2 Level-2A and national land cover data) are optical and primarily focused on terrestrial and shallow coastal environments. They are not capable of detecting underwater power cables or their electromagnetic fields. The data needed for improvement, such as detailed cable specifications, deployment methods, and empirical measurements of EMF, are entirely outside the scope and capabilities of DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings.

name: Noise 125Hz wind power
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show predicted sound level exposure at a frequency of 125 Hertz from wind power in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to low exposure (<100dB re 1 uPa) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high exposure (>150 dB re 1 uPa). The maximum noise level is based on values recorded during during strong winds at Lillegrund windfarm (7km from Oresund Bridge) and these maximum values are used as proxy for yearly average noise emissions. The modelled noise pressure should therefore be considered to be a very conservative (loud) estimation of the noise pollution from wind power. Underlying data are from several sources and consist of offshore wind farm data, bottom substrate data, and depth data that have been combined and modelled. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad ljudexponering från vindkraft i frekvensområdet 125 Hertz i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg exponering (<100 dB re 1 uPa), och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög exponering (>150 dB re 1 uPa). Den maximala ljudnivån baseras på värden som registrerats under starka vindar vid Lillegrunds vindkraftpark (7 km från Oresundsbron) och dessa maximala värden används som proxy för årliga genomsnittliga bullerutsläpp. Det modellerade bullertrycket bör därför anses vara en mycket konservativ (hög) uppskattning av bullerföroreningen från vindkraft. Underlagsdata härrör från flera olika källor och består av havsbaserad vindkraftsparksdata, bottensubstratsdata och djupdata som kombinerats och modellerats. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: With the assistance of a generalised spreading model (RL = SL – TL) the Received Level (RL) of sound was calculated for all cells in the SYMPHONY at a frequency of 125 Hz. SL = Source level. Transmission loss (TL) was calculated as a function of the distance from the source (distance) as well as bottom substrate character at the source. For shallow (<30M) bottom with hard sediment character the function 15 × log(distance) was used and for other conditions the function 20 × log(distance) was used. Bottom substrate classification was based on maps of bottom substrate purpose produced by the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU) for SYMPHONY. Bottom substrates where the proportion of soft bottom was > 50% were defined as having soft sediment character. The aggregated sound from all wind power turbines over a year were combined and converted to sound intensity. The yearly average was calculated and then converted to sound volume expressed in average decibels (dBavg), which was calculated as follows: dBavg =10 × log10(∑∆t/T×(10)^((RL intensity/10)) summed over all ∆t under the whole time period T (1 year alternatively 6 months). The source sound volume that was applied was 136 dB at a frequency of 127 Hz (integrated over the frequency range 123 – 132 Hz), which was measured at Lillgrund as a conservative ‘worst case’ in the upper range for existing wind power turbines. The values for the wind power park at Middelgrunden, Bockstigen and Vindeby demonstrate source volumes < 136 dB (Miller, 2009, Underwater noise from three types of offshore wind turbines, Andersson et al, 2011, Vindval rapport 6436). A value of 114 dB at a one-third octave band centered on 125 Hz has been specified for Middelgrunden which further emphasises that the proposed value of 136 dB constitutes a conservative assumption for wind power turbine. Data were linear normalized between 100 and 150 dB yearly average. More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony:
Attention should be paid to the underlying quality and accuracy of the sediment substrate data. In particular the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU) provided data on the probability of occurrence of soft sediment substrates for these modelling, these data are based on both on dominant grain size and categorical maps based on hydroacoustic data. The model does not include information on sediment compaction and morphology which will certainly affect sound propagation. This model should therefore be used with caution and should not be
used for detailed studies of smaller areas.
The model should be used with caution outside Sweden within HavExtend, because there
are modelled positions for the wind power plant and because the confidence in the substrate
data is lower.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: s. Sound propagation models can be made considerably more complicated and "heavy". Modulated data has been checked against validated model for Lillgrund and there is a slight difference due to the use of generalized sound propagation factors. In the case of wind turbines, noise levels are low, which may mean that this minor error is not considered to be so important for the analysis in Symphony. Note that the noise relates only to wind turbines without masking or other effects. In reality, many other sounds occur in the ocean. If you want to develop the data set, you can develop a site-specific sound spread factor and turbine- specific source noise for each wind farm, but this is much more time-consuming and costly.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: merchant shipping , environmental impact , noise pollutant
other_restrictions: This "Noise 125Hz wind power" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish National Grid (SK). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has significant limitations regarding the underlying data quality (sediment substrate, lack of compaction/morphology), the conservative 'worst-case' noise estimation, and the generalized sound propagation factors. The recommendations suggest developing site-specific sound spread factors and turbine-specific source noise, which would be a fundamental methodological overhaul and require new data collection, moving beyond the current generalized model. This constitutes a major improvement in accuracy and realism.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing site-specific sound spread factors and turbine-specific source noise for each wind farm, as recommended, is explicitly stated as 'much more time-consuming and costly'. It would require extensive new data collection (e.g., in-situ acoustic measurements, detailed sediment surveys including compaction/morphology), advanced modeling techniques beyond generalized spreading models, and significant expert involvement. This aligns with a 'high' difficulty level.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly measure underwater sound propagation, sediment compaction, or morphology. While satellite-derived bathymetry could provide depth data, the core issues of sound propagation modeling, source levels, and detailed substrate characteristics (beyond broad classification) are not addressable by current satellite capabilities. Acoustic data and in-situ measurements are required.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover, is not suitable for generating or improving this layer. It cannot provide information on underwater sound levels, sound propagation through water and sediment, detailed sediment properties (compaction, morphology), or specific wind turbine noise emissions. Its focus is terrestrial and shallow coastal, not deep-water acoustic modeling.

name: Nitrogen background
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster dataset intends to show the predicted background nitrogen concentrations in Swedish inshore and offshore coastal surface waters. The source data consist of modelled water column nitrogen data in the form of NetCDF files for offshore areas and polygon shapefiles for inshore areas. Data were supplied by the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute. A cell value of zero is equivalent to zero nitrogen in surface waters and 100 is equivalent to 112mg/l of nitrogen (the highest recorded level). These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad bakgrundsnivå av kvävekoncentrationer i ytvatten i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Källdata består av modellerad vattenkolumnsdata med kväve i form av NetCDF-filer för havsvattenområden och polygonshape-filer för kustområden. Data tillhandahölls av
Sveriges meteorologiska och hydrologiska institut (SMHI).
Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar inget kväve i ytvattnet, och ett
cellvärde av 100 motsvarar 112 mg/l kväve (högsta uppmätta
nivå). Resultatet normalisrades efter värdet för God
ekologisk status från EU:s havsmiljödirektiv. Denna data
skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget
utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och
vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för
bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig
aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
The source data for this data product consist of three datasets supplied by SMHI. The first two were surface Nitrogen concentrations were extracted from two NetCDF files provided by SMHI: BalticSea_Water_body_total_nitrogen_year.nc and NorthSea_Water_body_total_nitrogen_year.nc. These are modelled water column data created using the DIVA interpolation tool (https://github.com/gher- ulg/DIVA) and which can be downloaded from emodnet- chemstry.eu Average annual P values for the period 2005 to 2014 were extracted from the NetCDF files for surface waters. These data were reprojected from WGS84 to ETR89 and clipped to the Symphony standard grid. Data for the Baltic and North Sea regions were merged using a transitional mask around the Oresund area. These interpolated data are inaccurate in the coastal zone and therefore a third dataset detailing modelled nitrogen levels in the coastal zone were provided by SMHI (Swedish Costal zone Model version 1.0.4, revision 512, model data 1999-2008), these data were provided with a coarse spatial resolution - mapped to polygons matching the transitional waters of the water framework directive. Data are published here: https://vattenweb.smhi.se Mean average total nitrogen concentrations were extracted from the coastal zone model data. This annual average inshore data were then merged with the offshore datalayers using a mosiac function. The data were then normalised on a 0-100 scale using a linear rescale function. The highest value (100) equating to 121.32mg/l of Nitrogen - the highest recorded average
concentration in any of the 3 source datalayers.
The result was then normalized to Good env. Status EU´s
Marine strategy framework Directive.
>0 = eutrophycation.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This 'annual average' dataset was created by merging data from two different temporal periods (offshore 2005-2014 and inshore 1999-2008). The inshore dataset is based on large polygon areas with very low spatial resolution yet spatial variance in nitrogen values are perhaps more likely inshore due to water column mixing caused by more complex land water interactions. For the offshore model SMHI recommend not using data with an error threshold higher than 50 percent however all data are included in this product.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: The SMHI coastal zone model is strongly influenced by the prediction of driving mechanisms and uncertainties in this. In many aquatic environments, eutrophication is crucial - improvement in this would improve the quality of the model. Development of the biogeochemical components of the inshore model (as per the SCOBI model) would also be of great value - the inclusion of spatial data on drivers might also allow for improved spatial resolution in the inshore data. Any such modelling should include error levels and model validation. In general, the production of 'combined' national geodata products at source (i.e. by SMHI) would be highly valuable for national marine management objectives in Sweden. The inclusion of interpolated data with high error levels should be taken into account through the production of associated quality maps that are based on the error values presented by SMHI in their NetCDF data.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has significant limitations, including merging data from different temporal periods (1999-2008 and 2005-2014), very low spatial resolution for inshore areas where variance is expected to be high, and inclusion of offshore data with error thresholds up to 50%. Recommendations include developing biogeochemical components for the inshore model, including spatial data on drivers for improved resolution, and producing associated quality maps based on error values. These require fundamental methodological overhauls and potentially new data collection/modeling approaches.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations would require significant effort. Developing biogeochemical components for the inshore model and incorporating spatial drivers for improved resolution implies advanced modeling techniques and potentially new data integration. Producing combined national geodata products at source (SMHI) and creating quality maps based on error values would require extensive coordination, advanced technical expertise in data fusion and error propagation, and potentially new infrastructure or agreements between agencies. This goes beyond simple updates or integration of existing data.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can contribute to improving this layer, particularly for water quality parameters. Ocean color sensors can provide data on chlorophyll-a (a proxy for eutrophication), suspended particulate matter, and potentially colored dissolved organic matter, which are all related to water quality and nutrient levels. While direct nitrogen concentration is not typically measured by satellite, proxies and related parameters can be derived, helping to validate models or provide spatial context, especially in coastal zones where in-situ data might be sparse. However, direct measurement of nitrogen background levels is not a primary satellite capability.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 data and national land cover, has limited direct applicability to improving this specific marine layer. Sentinel-2 is optical and has limited penetration in water, making it less suitable for deep offshore water column data. While it can assist with coastal land use and development (which might indirectly influence coastal nitrogen), it does not provide direct measurements or models for water column nitrogen concentrations or biogeochemical processes in marine environments. Its capabilities are more focused on terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping, not the marine water column chemistry that forms the core of this layer.

The source data for this data product consist of three datasets supplied by SMHI. The first two were surface Phosphorus concentrations were extracted from two NetCDF files provided by SMHI: BalticSea_Water_body_Total_Phosphorus_year.nc and NorthSea_Water_body_Total_Phosphorus_year.nc. These are modelled water column data created using the DIVA interpolation tool (https://github.com/gher- ulg/DIVA) and which can be downloaded from emodnet- chemstry.eu Average annual P values for the period 2005 to 2014 were extracted from the NetCDF files for surface waters.
