name: Toxic munition dump
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster intends to show the predicted risk of organic and inorganic toxin contamination in marine sediments as a result of the dumping of munitions in areas in and surrounding Swedish coastal and offshore waters at the end of the second world war. The underlying data was sourced from HELCOM in the form of point, line and polygon shapefiles detailing the location of dumping grounds, risk areas and dredged munitions. The dataset is modelled using a simplistic assumption of decreasing risk with distance from the dump sites. value of 100 represents a high risk for high levels of organic and inorganic toxins in sediments and a value of 0 represents toxins at background level. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only
advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad risk för organiska och oorganiska miljögifter i marina sediment som ett resultat av dumpning av krigsmateriel i slutet av andra världskriget. Underlagsdata kommer från HELCOM i form av punkter, linjer och polygonshape-filer vilka specificerar dumpningsområden, riskområden och områden med dumpat kemiska stridsmedal. rasterskiktet är modellerat och gör ett förenklat antagande att risk för förorening minskar med avståndet från dumpningsområde. Ett värde av 100 motsvarar hög risk för höga nivåer av organiska och oorganiska miljögifter i sediment, och ett värde av 0 motsvarar bakgrundsnivåer av miljögifter. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: This dataset was created using polygon, line and point data delineating the position of chemical munitions. The data were provided by Helcom and consisted of: Ammunition dumping sites (polygons) Reported encounters with chemical munitions (points) Chemical munition transport routes (lines) 1) All data Import polygons into ArcGIS 2) Buffer points with a 10km concentric ring buffer 3) Allocate a stepwise score with distance 100 for 2km, 80 for 4km, 60 for 6km, 40 for 8km, 20 for 10km for points 4) Allocate a 100 impact for all dumpsites 5) Buffer lines with a 10km concentric ring buffer 6) Allocate a stepwise score with distance 50 for 2km, 40 for 4km, 30 for 6km, 20 for 8km, 10 for 10km for points (assuming some but less risk during transport) 7) Combine all datasets into a single raster 8) A spatial smoothing filter (mean average over 5km) 9) Clip the raster output to the Symphony Grid
limitations_for_use_in_symphony:
This data is a simplistic model which is based on a number of unverified assumptions. It
should therefore be treated as a risk layer which should be validated.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: A number of research papers and studies have been published which detail the concentrations of toxins in the sediments in and surrounding chemical weapons dumpsites. The raw data from these studies has not been incorporated into SGUIs or ICES DOME database. It would be highly recommended to gather these data and to update the SGU interpolation models with these updates. The production of a more reliable model with empirical validation would be highly recommended.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states it is a 'simplistic model based on unverified assumptions' and 'should therefore be treated as a risk layer which should be validated'. The recommendation is to 'gather raw data from research papers and studies' detailing toxin concentrations and 'update the SGUIs or ICES DOME database' and 'SGU interpolation models'. This implies a fundamental overhaul from a simplistic, assumption-based model to an empirically validated, data-driven model, which constitutes a major improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Gathering raw data from numerous research papers, integrating it into existing databases (SGUIs, ICES DOME), and then updating and validating interpolation models is a significant undertaking. It requires extensive data collection, data harmonization, advanced data analysis, and potentially new modeling approaches, which would be resource-intensive and require high technical expertise and coordination.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer models the risk of organic and inorganic toxin contamination in marine sediments. Satellite remote sensing, while excellent for surface phenomena (e.g., chlorophyll, SST, suspended sediments), cannot directly measure or infer the concentration of specific organic and inorganic toxins within marine sediments. These measurements require in-situ sampling and laboratory analysis.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily provides Sentinel-2 optical imagery and national land cover data. While useful for coastal land use or shallow water habitat mapping, it does not offer capabilities to directly detect or quantify toxic munition contamination in marine sediments. The data needed for this layer (sediment toxin concentrations) are not available through DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings.

name: Synthetic toxins background
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show the predicted mean concentration of 32 organic toxins in marine benthic substrates in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. A value of 0 is equivalent to a mean concentration of 0 for the 32 organic toxins and a value of 1 is equivalent to mean very high concentrations (Class 5, Naturvårdsverket rapport 4914). The data has been normalised to the likelihood of mud content in surrounding sediments based on the assumption that organic toxins will bind with organic matter in sediment. Outliers have been modelled separately and reintroduced into the dataset. These areas all have recorded organic toxin concentrations at levels significantly above the very-high level and are mapped with a buffer of approximately 15km based on the assumption that proximity to these sites equates to a higher risk of organic toxin pollution. This raster is based on historical sediment data from the Geological Survey of Sweden and International Council for the Exploration of the Sea. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad medelkoncentration av trettiotvå organiska miljögifter i marina bentiska substrat i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett värde av 0 motsvarar en medelkoncentration på 0 för de
trettiotvå organiska miljögifterna och ett värde av 1
motsvarar mycket höga medelkoncentrationer (Klass 5,
Naturvårdsverket rapport 4914). Data har normaliserats till
sannolikhet av lerinnehåll i intilliggande sediment baserat på
antagandet att organiska miljögifter binder till organiskt
material i sediment. Outliers har modellerats separat och
återinförts till rasterskiktet. Dessa områden har alla uppvisat
signifikant högre koncentrationer av organiska miljögifter än
mycket höga nivåer och är kartlagda med en buffertzon på
ungefär 15 km, baserat på antagandet att närhet till dessa
områden motsvarar högre risk för organiska miljögifter.
Lagret är baserat på historisk sedimentdata från Sveriges
geologiska undersökning och ICES (International Council for
the Exploration of the Sea). Denna data skapades som ett
data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av
enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och
vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för
bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig
aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
SGU data was sourced from their data archive and covers the period 1984 to 2014. The data processing followed the following steps: 1. Data downloaded from ICES dome monitoring database and imported into a MS access database for processing 2. Data exported to ArcGIS and a spatial query undertaken to select data within the Symphony area of interest and reimported to Access 3. SGU data imported from the national sediment data archive (including data from national monitoring by SGU, regional and local monitoring by County Administrations, the Swedish EPA and SWAM and from historical ad-hoc surveys undertaken by SGU (including some commercial data). All data reformatted to fit the ICES data specification. 4. ICES and SGU data combined into a single data table using append queries in MS Access. 5. All data units standardised to mg per kg. 6. All data exported to ArcGIS and reprojected into ETRS 1989 LAEA from WGS84 7. Only data points coinciding with the marine area
represented in the Symphony Grid maintained in the
dataset.
8. Data reimported to MS Access and cross-tab queries
undertaken to select the maximum value from the latest
records at each site for each toxin parameter.
9. Outliers winsorized above the 99th percentile after which
data checked for normality and log transformed when
required.
10. Variograms modelled individually for each synthetic
toxin, best fit model chosen using cross validation.
11. Data interpolated (gridded) to a 5km grid for each
synthetic toxin using ordinary kriging algorithm (Surfer -
Golden Software). Associated standard deviation layers
created.
12. All data layers transformed to the same scale using the
high (1) values from the Swedish Environment protection
agency report No. 4914.
13. Transformed data layers combined into mean data layer
using grid mosaic in Surfer.
14. Mean data layer normalised to the estimated predicted
frequency of organic mud (gyttja) in marine sediments by
using a multiplication function in ArcGIS raster calculator.
15. Final data layer rescaled to 0-1 risk layers in ArcGIS
using raster calculator so that values above 1 are reset to one.
16. Combined standard deviation data layer created by
scaling standard deviation layers for each synthetic toxin to a
0-100 scale, combining into a mean layer using grid mosaic
in Surfer and reclassifying the data into four quantiles in
ArcGIS. Data where the mean error is below 50% are
assumed to represent a good model (without validation).
Data where the mean error is above 50% are assumed to
represent a poor model / interpolation, cells with sample
data are included as being highly reliable.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony:
There are a number of key limitations users should be aware of when using this dataset: 1) Data collected by SGU after 2010 were not available to be included in this model. This includes data from fiberbank surveys undertaken by SGU in Northern Sweden between 2010 and 2016. The impact of this limitation has been limited by incorporating an additional modelled layer into Symphony consisting of known / surveyed fiberbanks and fibre rich sediments as toxic areas (scoring 100) with a linear decrease within 10km distance however this is known to highly simplistic (in some areas there is very little heavy metal increase with distance) - it
also ignores fiberbanks that have not been mapped.
2) The geostatistical interpolation method used does not take into account that land will act
as a barrier.
3) The data is a historical average for all records in the ICES Dome and SGU databases and
as such this may not reflect current sediment conditions.
4) There is a lack of offshore samples so in general offshore areas have a much higher
uncertainty.
5) Data are combined based on their historical concentration and not their toxicity.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Produce an update to this model with data from SGU post 2010. Model with a tool that can handle land as a barrier. Determine if specific time frame is more appropriate than a historical average or if a max level is more appropriate. Determine if a toxicity based index is more appropriate.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has several fundamental limitations that significantly impact its accuracy and relevance. These include reliance on historical data (1984-2014) that may not reflect current conditions, lack of offshore samples leading to high uncertainty, and a geostatistical interpolation method that doesn't account for land as a barrier. The recommendations explicitly call for updating the model with post-2010 data, using a tool that handles land as a barrier, and potentially shifting from historical averages to more current or toxicity-based indices. These are not minor tweaks but require substantial re-modeling and data integration, pushing it towards a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: While the improvements are substantial, the recommendations suggest using existing data sources (SGU post-2010) and known modeling techniques (e.g., geostatistical tools that handle barriers). The complexity lies in integrating new data, re-running sophisticated interpolation, and potentially re-evaluating the index (concentration vs. toxicity). This requires significant technical expertise and coordination but doesn't necessarily involve entirely new data collection programs or unproven methodologies, placing it in the 'medium' difficulty category.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: This layer focuses on organic toxin concentrations in marine benthic substrates (sediments). Satellite remote sensing primarily observes surface phenomena (e.g., sea surface temperature, chlorophyll, suspended sediments, surface oil spills). While some satellite data can infer water quality or habitat types, directly measuring or inferring benthic sediment toxin concentrations from space is not currently feasible. These measurements require in-situ sediment sampling and laboratory analysis.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, with its Sentinel-2 and national land cover data, is primarily focused on terrestrial and shallow coastal land use, vegetation, and land cover changes. It does not provide capabilities for directly measuring or inferring organic toxin concentrations in marine benthic sediments, especially in offshore areas. The data required for this layer (historical sediment samples, chemical analysis) are not available through DigitalEarthSweden's offerings.

name: Synthetic toxins harbor
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show areas with potential synthetic toxin contamination associated with harbours in Swedish coastal waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to low potential water contamination (> 1000 m from harbour) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to potential water contamination (≤ 1000 m from harbour). Underlying data consists of harbour site presence data in the form of shapefiles. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa hamnområden i svenska kustvatten som potentiellt är förorenade med syntetiska miljögifter. Underlagsdata består av hamnförekomstdata i form av shape-filer. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg
potentiell vattenförorening (> 1000 m från hamn), och ett
cellvärde av 100 motsvarar potentiell vattenförorening (≤
1000 m från hamn). Denna data skapades som ett data input
layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för
havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV).
Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den
kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska
vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av
denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter
vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: This dataset was created using point data showing harbours which were sourced from Helcom and which in turn are based on Automatic Identification System (AIS) data, the Baltic Port List 2012, and maps available in Port's official websites. The derived dataset was created based on the following process: 1. Ports inside Symphony land boundary were moved to the coastline using a nearest neighbour join. 2. All sites within the marine area were selected and a 1000 buffer was applied. 3. A value of 100 was applied to the buffer polygons. 4. The data were converted to a raster and with the Symphony grid specification.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The 1000 buffer this is a simplistic risk estimate. There is no definition of what constitutes a 'harbour' in this dataset and at present this dataset does not include small scale docks (brygga) which might constitute a cumulative impact similar (or larger) than small harbours.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Define what a 'habour' means. Scale habours based on size. Develop a clear rationale for applying any buffer. Represent larger harbours as buffered polygon features rather than buffered points (they are much larger areas). Use a graduated reduction in impact risk with distance (rather than a binary high/no impact. Gather empirical data and information (e.g. from SEPA/County Admin monitoring) which can be used to develop and validate a better model of spatial risk of organic toxin pollution. Gather attribute information on for example the area, number of vessel berths, type of shipping etc that could be used to modify the risk levels) and environmental criteria such as data on currents / sediments to model risk depending on site location.

data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Synthetic toxins harbor" dataset is a derived from source data provided by Swedish County Administration Boards (Länsstyrelse). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to DHI Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The recommendations suggest a fundamental overhaul of the methodology, moving from a simplistic binary buffer to a graduated risk model, incorporating empirical data, and considering environmental criteria like currents and sediments. This requires a complete re-conceptualization of the risk assessment, moving beyond simple proximity to a more sophisticated predictive model, which constitutes a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations involves defining 'harbour' comprehensively, scaling harbours by size, developing a clear rationale for buffers, potentially representing harbours as polygons, and crucially, gathering empirical data (e.g., from SEPA/County Admin monitoring) and attribute information (area, berths, shipping type). Furthermore, integrating environmental criteria like currents and sediments to model risk depending on site location requires advanced modeling techniques and significant data acquisition and integration, making it 'high' difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can contribute significantly. For instance, high-resolution optical imagery (e.g., from Sentinel-2 or commercial satellites) can help in defining and scaling 'harbours' by mapping their physical extent, number of berths, and associated infrastructure. Satellite-derived bathymetry could inform shallow water characteristics. While direct 'synthetic toxin' detection is not feasible, proxies like suspended sediment plumes (indicating dredging or discharge) or unusual water discoloration could be monitored. Coastal development and land use changes around harbours, which might influence runoff, can also be tracked. However, direct toxin concentration or current data at the fine scale needed would still require in-situ measurements.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, with its Sentinel-2 Level-2A data, can directly support several recommendations. Sentinel-2 imagery can be used to map the physical extent of harbours, identify and potentially classify different types of 'harbours' (e.g., based on size of infrastructure, number of visible berths), and monitor coastal development around them. This helps in 'scaling harbours based on size' and 'representing larger harbours as buffered polygon features'. The national land cover data could also provide context for surrounding land use. While it cannot provide empirical toxin data or detailed current models, it can significantly improve the spatial definition and characterization of the 'harbour' input, which is a key limitation.

summary: This raster intends to show areas with potential synthetic toxin contamination associated with industrial sites in Swedish coastal waters. Underlying data consists of water industrial site presence data in the form of shapefiles. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to low potential water contamination (> 1000 m from industrial site) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to potential water contamination (≤ 1000 m from industrial site). These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa industriområden i svenska kustvatten som potentiellt är förorenade med syntetiska miljögifter. Underlagsdata består av industriförekomstdata i form av shape-filer. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg potentiell vattenförorening (> 1000 m från industri), och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar potentiell vattenförorening (≤ 1000 m från industri). Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
This dataset is based on vector data sourced from the Swedish County Administration Boards known as "SE.US Miljöförvaltningsanläggningar" which is published as an open INSPIRE compliant dataset on Sweden's INSPIRE geodata portal: www.geodata.se. This data shows permitted environmentally hazardous activities. This data includes wastewater treatment plants and other industrial activities and their operational status. This dataset was last compiled in 2013. All licenced industrial activities within 500m of the coast (identified with a spatial query) were extracted and these selected point records were buffered with a 1000m buffer.
This buffered dataset was then converted to a raster format.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The 1000 buffer is a simplistic risk estimate. The data includes only sites within 500m of the coast and does not therefore include the influence of upstream effluent releases.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Use a spatially graduated reduction in impact risk with distance (rather than a binary high/no impact. Model the influence of upstream effluent release locations (for example by scaling river mouth locations depending on number of upstream sites). Gather empirical data and information (e.g. from SEPA/County Admin monitoring) which can be used to develop and validate a better model of spatial risk of organic/synthetic toxin pollution. Water quality monitoring data can be downloaded from http://viss.lansstyrelsen.se and sediment pollution data is available from SGU https://www.sgu.se/produkter/geologiska-data/oppna-data/maringeologi-oppna- data/marina-data-i-atomfloden/ Gather attribute information on for example from the county admin boards that could be used to modify risk levels (based on data such as volumes permitted to be released) and environmental criteria (such as data on currents / sediments).
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: chemical pollution , industrial pollution, environmental impact
other_restrictions:
This "Synthetic toxins industry" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish County Administration Boards (Länsstyrelse). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is
attributed to DHI Sverige AB and was produced on
behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water
Management (SwAM). Data sources should be
acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from
it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer's limitations highlight fundamental issues: a simplistic binary risk estimate (1000m buffer), exclusion of upstream effluent releases, and lack of empirical validation. The recommendations suggest a spatially graduated risk model, modeling upstream effluent, gathering empirical monitoring data (water quality, sediment pollution), and incorporating attribute information (e.g., permitted release volumes, environmental criteria like currents/sediments). These are not minor updates but require a complete re-conceptualization of the risk model, integration of diverse new data sources, and potentially advanced hydrological/dispersion modeling, indicating a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements would be 'high' difficulty. It requires developing a new, spatially graduated risk model (not just a buffer), integrating complex hydrological models for upstream effluent, acquiring and integrating extensive empirical monitoring data from multiple sources (VISS, SGU), and incorporating dynamic environmental criteria like currents and sediment types. This involves significant data acquisition, advanced spatial analysis, potentially new modeling techniques, and extensive coordination across different data providers and scientific disciplines. It goes beyond simple data updates or minor methodological tweaks.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can help improve this layer. While direct measurement of synthetic toxins is not feasible, satellite data can provide crucial environmental criteria that influence toxin dispersion and impact. For example, satellite-derived sea surface temperature and currents (from altimetry, radiometers) can inform dispersion models. Coastal land use and development (from optical imagery like Sentinel-2) can help identify potential industrial sites or areas of high human activity not captured by the 500m coastal buffer. Water quality indicators (e.g., turbidity, chlorophyll-a as proxies for general water health or potential eutrophication linked to industrial discharge) can be monitored by ocean color sensors, providing data for validation or as input to a more sophisticated risk model. While not directly measuring toxins, these parameters are critical for understanding their fate and transport.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden data, specifically Sentinel-2 Level-2A products, can help improve this layer. Sentinel-2 can be used for detailed coastal land use mapping to identify industrial sites or changes in coastal infrastructure that might be sources of pollution, potentially refining the initial selection of sites within 500m of the coast. While not directly measuring toxins, Sentinel-2's multi-spectral bands can provide insights into water turbidity or suspended sediment concentrations in coastal waters, which can be indicators of discharge or altered water quality. The national land cover data can also provide context for land-based industrial activities near the coast. However, its utility is limited by its optical nature (cloud cover, shallow water penetration) and lack of specialized oceanographic sensors for parameters like currents or specific water chemistry.

name: Habitat loss sand extraction
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster intends to show areas where potential habitat loss can occur from the presence of mining (sand extraction) in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. Underlying data consists of the polygon data detailing the extent of mining (sand extraction) licenced areas and is in the form of a shapefile. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no risk of habitat loss due to of mining (sand extraction) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to a risk habitat loss due to mining (sand extraction). These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in
Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at
plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is
only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data
sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa områden där habitatförlust potentiellt kan förekomma på grund av förekomst av sandutvinning i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Underlagsdata består av polygondata som specificerar utbredningen av licensierade områden för sandutvinning i form av en shape-fil. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen risk för habitatförlust på grund av sandutvinning, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar risk för habitatförlust på grund av sandutvinning. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: This dataset is based on a polygon dataset showing licenced sand and gravel extraction sites in Swedish waters. These data were provided by the Geological Survey of Sweden. The vector data in shapefile format were converted to were converted to binary raster format using SAGA GIS.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: No information is included which details the sediment type or volume of material extracted and the precise location of material removed.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Gather more precise footprint information on the location and volume of aggregates extracted that can be included as source data attribution. These data would allow impact scaling.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Habitat loss sand extraction" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Geological Survey of Sweden. This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to DHI Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states limitations regarding the lack of information on sediment type, volume extracted, and precise location of material removed. The recommendation is to 'Gather more precise footprint information on the location and volume of aggregates extracted that can be included as source data attribution. These data would allow impact scaling.' This goes beyond simple updates and requires integrating new, more detailed data (precise footprints, volumes) which would significantly enhance the layer's utility for impact assessment. This is a moderate improvement as it refines the core data rather than a complete overhaul.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations would require obtaining more granular data from the Geological Survey of Sweden or other sources, which might involve new data agreements, processing more complex spatial data (precise footprints instead of just licensed areas), and potentially developing methods for 'impact scaling' based on volume. This is more than a 'low' difficulty as it involves data integration and methodological refinement, but not a 'high' difficulty as it builds upon existing data sources and concepts.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing is generally not suitable for directly monitoring sub-surface sand extraction volumes or precise extraction footprints in the marine environment. While some very shallow water changes might be detectable with high-resolution optical imagery, the primary data needed (volume, precise sub-surface extraction locations) are not directly observable from space. Satellite-derived bathymetry might show changes in very shallow areas, but not the detailed information on extraction volumes or sediment types required here.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 data and national land cover, is not directly applicable to monitoring sub-surface marine sand extraction. Sentinel-2's optical capabilities are limited in water depth and cannot provide information on extraction volumes or precise sub-surface footprints. The national land cover data is terrestrial focused and not relevant for marine sand extraction.

name: Turbidity sand extraction
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster intends to show areas where potential habitat loss can occur from the presence of mining (extraction) in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. Underlying data consists of mining (sand extraction) licensed site data in the form of a polygon shapefile. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to no presence of mining (extraction) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to presence of mining (extraction). Underlying
data consists of mining (extraction) presence data in the
form of shape files. These data were created as a data input
layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning
unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water
Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess
the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in
Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at
plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is
only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data
sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa områden där habitatförlust potentiellt kan förekomma på grund av förekomst av gruvdrift (extraktion) i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Underlagsdata består av sandextraktionsdata för licensierade områden i form av en polygonshape-fil. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen förekomst av extraktion, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar förekomst av extraktion. Underlagsdata består av extraktionsförekomstdata i form av shape-filer. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage: This dataset is based on the location of the only licensed sand extraction site in Swedish waters. The source data was provided by the Geological Survey of Sweden. No attribution is available detailing the precise location, volume or type of material extracted so this model makes the simplistic assumption that impact within the site is high (i.e. 100). and everywhere else there is no impact. In reality the spatial footprint of the impact is more than likely to be lower than predicted.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This model does not take into account the influence of currents on the dispersal of sediments. No information is included which details the sediment type or volume of material extracted and the precise location of material removed.
recommendations_for_data_improvement:
Include data on dominant current strength and direction to improve the spatial impact model. If data on the sediment type, volume and location of material extracted are available the impact model could be made more sophisticated. Data detailing dominant currents in the Symphony region are publically available for
example data from SMHI: http://cmems-resources.cls.fr/documents/PUM/CMEMS-BAL-
PUM-003-008.pdf
and data from the 2006 Balance project http://helcom.fi/baltic-sea-trends/data-
maps/biodiversity/balance
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Turbidity sand extraction" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU). This derived dataset is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to DHI Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer's limitations explicitly state that it does not account for current influence on sediment dispersal, sediment type, volume, or precise location of material extracted. The recommendations suggest including data on dominant current strength and direction, and if available, sediment type, volume, and location. The lineage also states a simplistic assumption of high impact within the site and no impact elsewhere, noting that the spatial footprint is likely lower than predicted. Addressing these fundamental issues would require a significant overhaul of the impact model, moving from a binary presence/absence to a more sophisticated spatial impact model, which constitutes a 'large' improvement.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, such as integrating current data (publicly available from SMHI/CMEMS and Balance project) and potentially more detailed extraction data, would require moderate technical expertise for data integration and modeling. While the current data is available, incorporating it into a spatial impact model that accounts for dispersal would be a methodological change of moderate complexity. It doesn't require entirely new data collection programs but rather sophisticated use of existing and potentially new detailed extraction data, placing it at 'medium' difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can significantly help improve this layer. Turbidity, which is directly related to suspended sediments from sand extraction, can be monitored using ocean color sensors (e.g., Sentinel-2, although DigitalEarthSweden's Sentinel-2 is primarily for land, it can detect turbidity in coastal waters). While the layer is about 'potential habitat loss' from 'turbidity sand extraction', the core issue is the dispersal of sediments. Satellite imagery can provide data on suspended sediment concentrations and plumes, which are direct indicators of turbidity and sediment dispersal. This could help validate or refine the spatial footprint of impact, especially if combined with current data. Additionally, satellite-derived current data (e.g., from altimetry or sea surface temperature gradients) could potentially complement in-situ current measurements, though the recommendations point to existing model outputs.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 Level-2A data and national land cover, has limited direct applicability for improving this specific layer. While Sentinel-2 can detect suspended sediments in coastal waters, its primary focus and the limitations of optical sensors (cloud cover, water depth penetration) mean it cannot provide the comprehensive current data or detailed extraction volume/type information needed. The national land cover data is irrelevant to offshore sand extraction impacts. Therefore, while Sentinel-2 might offer some supplementary visual evidence of turbidity plumes, it cannot fundamentally address the core limitations or provide the recommended data for current strength/direction or detailed extraction parameters. The recommended current data sources are from dedicated oceanographic models (SMHI/CMEMS, Balance project), not DigitalEarthSweden.

name: Bird hunt
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show the intensity of bird hunting in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. The source data details statistics for two bird species (the Common Eider, Goldeneye) killed in various regions in 2015 in the form of an excel spreadsheet. This data was combined with spatial data for coastal regions assuming hunting occurs all the way to the edge of the territorial limits and these spatial data were used to transform the data to number of individuals killed per hectare. The data were adjusted to be proportional to the whole population for each species, then aggregated and transformed. A cell value of zero represents no individual birds hunted and a cell value of 100 represents the equivalent of 0.001 individuals killed per hectare. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa intensiteten av fågeljakt i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Källdata visar statistik för två fågelarter (ejder, knipa) skjutna i olika regioner under 2015 i form av ett Excel-ark. Denna data kombinerades med rumslig data för kustregioner och gör antagandet att jakt förekommer hela vägen ut till territorialhavets gräns, och dessa rumsliga data användes för att transformera data till antal individer skjutna per hektar. Data justerades för att bli proportionell till hela populationen för varje art, sedan aggregerad och
transformerad.
Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar inga enskilda fåglar skjutna, och
ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar 0,001 enskilda fåglar skjutna
per hektar.
Detta data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’
verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs-
och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV
för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av
mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid
havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra
ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning
av datakällorna.
lineage: The source data for this data product consist of two data layers. Bird hunting data for two species (Eider and Knipa) were downloaded from the Swedish Hunting Association's website: https://rapport.viltdata.se and detail hunting activity for 2015. Boundaries data are open data (overview maps) downloaded from the Swedish land registration authority (Lantmäteriet). The data were normalised to the 2015 national population level for each species determined by the 2016 report "ORNIS SVECICA 26:3–54, 2016" thereby producing a proportion of the national population depleted by hunting activity. The species data were applied to the boundary polygons from Lantmäteriet according to the location described in the hunting data. The surface area of the polygons was determined using geometry calculator and the normalised value for hunting was divided by the surface area of the relevant polygon in order to produce a proportion of the population killed per hectare. A linear min-max stretch was then applied to these normalised data and based on a 0-100 scale. More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The most significant limitation of these data is the lack of spatial resolution. The data assumes that bird hunting is occurring right out the EEZ in some instances - which is perhaps unlikely. The data is also limited to two reported species and the level of reporting is unknown.
recommendations_for_data_improvement:
Gather participatory information from the hunters association to highlight areas where they
are operational or through environmental preferences (do hunters generally hunt from
shore or boats for example?).
Identify if there are additional species that are hunted which are not recorded.
Determine what the quality (e.g. requirement for reporting) are of hunting data in general.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
other_restrictions: This "Bird hunt" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish hunters association (Svenska Jägareförbundet) and the Swedish mapping, cadastral and land registration authority (Lantmäteriet). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has significant limitations regarding spatial resolution, species coverage, and data reporting quality. The recommendations suggest gathering participatory information from hunters, identifying additional species, and determining the quality of hunting data. These improvements require new data collection (e.g., surveys, direct engagement with hunters) and a fundamental re-evaluation of the spatial distribution assumption, moving beyond the current 'all the way to the EEZ' approach. This constitutes a major overhaul of the data source and methodology for spatial allocation.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommendations involves engaging with hunter associations, potentially designing and conducting surveys, and integrating new, more spatially explicit data. While not requiring entirely new, unproven technologies, it does demand significant coordination, data acquisition from non-traditional sources, and methodological adjustments to incorporate more precise spatial information. This is more than just updating existing data or minor methodological tweaks.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly measure bird hunting activity or the number of birds killed. While satellites can provide data on habitat characteristics (e.g., coastal land cover, water bodies) that might be relevant to where hunting occurs, they cannot provide the core data on hunting intensity or species-specific kill counts. The primary data needed (hunting statistics, hunter locations) are in-situ human activity data.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 imagery and national land cover data, is not directly applicable to improving this layer. Its data focuses on land use, vegetation, and coastal morphology, which are not the primary limitations of this 'Bird hunt' layer. The core issues are the lack of accurate spatial distribution of hunting effort, the limited species coverage, and the quality of reported hunting data, none of which can be addressed by optical satellite imagery or land cover maps.

name: Pollution boating
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster data intends to show predicted pollution associated with recreational boating activity in Swedish inshore and offshore waters. The source data are voluntarily transmitted automatic identification system (AIS B) beacon data and locations and size of recreational boat harbours from 2009. A cell value of zero represents no noise from recreational vessels based on the absence of boat traffic and a cell value of 100 represents maximum vessel activity and therefore pollution impact. The actual pollution level has not been estimated and this data assumes a linear relationship (between activity and pollution levels). These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad förorening associerad med fritidsbåtaktivitet i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Källdata är från frivilligt utsänd AIS B (Automatic Identification System) data, samt data över plats och storlek på fritidsbåtshamnar (2009). Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar ingen förorening från fritidsbåtar, baserat på ingen förekomst av båttrafik, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar maximal fartygsaktivitet och därmed föroreningspåverkan. De faktiska föroreningsnivåerna har inte uppskattats och denna data antar ett linjärt förhållande (mellan aktivitet och föroreningsnivå). Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa
miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används
vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra
ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av
datakällorna.
lineage: 1. 2009 AIS recreational boating density data for the busy summer period (June and July) and point data detailing the position of recreational boat harbours and nature harbours were sourced from the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency (see report - https://www.naturvardsverket.se/Documents/publikationer/978- 91-620-6376-4.pdf.) 2. AIS polygon data were classed 1-5 within 10 nautical miles from coast. 2. Buffer polygons around ”guest harbours” according to berths and distance, and natural harbours according to distance. Classed 1-5 to approximately correspond to the classes used for the AIS data. 3. Merge 1 and 2 “highest value wins” (1+5 = 5, 5+5 =5, 3+4=5 etc.) More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This data includes an element of expert assessment so in the absence of relevant data and the results should therefore be interpreted with caution. Recreational boat traffic far from the coast has been excluded from data. 18.52 km = 10 distance minutes (Nautical miles). Data were selected to remove bad input. The impact of ports has been classified based on the size of the port and the distance to the port. The actual pollution level has not been estimated and this data assumes a linear relationship between boating activity and pollution levels. There is no legal requirement for boats to carry an AIS B beacon so the traffic data outside of ports is very likely a underestimate (perhaps a significant underestimate).
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Use AIS data over a longer time period and produce an average layer to allow for variability in data quality. Attempt to validate the number of vessels carrying AIS B using external observations (e.g. SAR satellite data), additional data (e.g. insurance company reports). Look for data or studies which can validate the link between recreational vessel activity to pollution impacts.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has fundamental limitations, including a significant underestimate of traffic due to voluntary AIS B data, exclusion of traffic far from the coast, and an unvalidated assumption of a linear relationship between activity and pollution. The actual pollution level has not been estimated. Addressing these requires new data collection, validation of assumptions, and potentially a re-conceptualization of the pollution impact model, moving beyond a simple activity proxy.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements, such as validating AIS B coverage using external observations (e.g., SAR satellite data), integrating additional data (e.g., insurance reports), and finding studies to validate the link between activity and pollution, requires significant resources, advanced technical expertise (e.g., SAR data processing, statistical modeling for validation), and extensive coordination across different data sources and research domains. Estimating actual pollution levels would be a major undertaking.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing, particularly Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR), can be instrumental in validating the number of vessels carrying AIS B, as recommended. SAR can detect vessels regardless of whether they transmit AIS, providing an independent means to assess the completeness of the AIS B dataset. While direct pollution measurement from satellites is challenging for recreational boating, SAR can help improve the foundational activity data. Other satellite data (e.g., optical for coastal mapping) could potentially aid in refining harbor classifications or understanding coastal usage patterns, but SAR is the most direct application for addressing the AIS data limitation.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover, is not directly applicable to improving this layer. The core issues are related to vessel traffic detection (which Sentinel-2 cannot do effectively for individual boats) and the estimation of marine pollution from recreational vessels. Sentinel-2's capabilities are more suited for terrestrial and shallow coastal mapping, not for monitoring vessel activity or marine pollution in the open water or from individual recreational boats. The land cover data might help in understanding the context of harbors, but it won't address the fundamental data gaps or methodological issues of the pollution layer itself.

name: Noise boating
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster data intends to show predicted noise associated with recreational boating activity in Swedish inshore and offshore waters. The source data are voluntarily transmitted automatic identification system (AIS B) beacon data and locations and size of recreational boat harbours from 2009. A cell value of zero represents no noise from recreational vessels based on the absence of boat traffic and a cell value of 100 represents maximum vessel activity and therefore noise impact. The actual noise level has not been estimated and this data assumes a linear relationship (between activity and noise levels). These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa ljud i samband med fritidsbåtaktivitet i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Källdata är från frivilligt utsänd AIS B (Automatic Identification System) data, samt data över plats och storlek på fritidsbåtshamnar (2009). Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar inget ljud från fritidsbåtar, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar maximal fartygsaktivitet och därmed ljudpåverkan. De faktiska ljudnivåerna har inte uppskattats och denna data antar ett linjärt förhållande (mellan aktivitet och ljudnivåer). Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
1. 2009 AIS recreational boating density data for the busy summer period (June and July) and point data detailing the position of recreational boat harbours and nature harbours were sourced from the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency (see report - https://www.naturvardsverket.se/Documents/publikationer/978- 91-620-6376-4.pdf.) 2. AIS polygon data were classed 1-5 within 10 nautical miles from coast. 2. Buffer polygons around ”guest harbours” according to berths
and distance, and natural harbours according to distance. Classed
1-5 to approximately correspond to the classes used for the AIS
data.
3. Merge 1 and 2 “highest value wins” (1+5 = 5, 5+5 =5, 3+4=5
etc.)
More detailed information on the lineage and methodology is
available and can be supplied on request to the data owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: This data includes an element of expert assessment, or best guess, in the absence of relevant data and the results should therefore be interpreted with caution. Recreational boat traffic far from the coast has been excluded from data. 18.52 km = 10 distance minutes (Nautical miles). Data were selected to remove bad input. The impact of ports has been classified based on the size of the port and the distance to the port. The actual noise level has not been estimated and this data assumes a linear relationship between boating activity and noise levels. There is no legal requirement for boats to carry an AIS B beacon so the traffic data outside of ports is very likely a underestimate (perhaps a significant underestimate).
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Use AIS data over a longer time period and produce an average layer to allow for variability in data quality. Attempt to validate the number of vessels carrying AIS B using external observations (e.g. SAR satellite data), additional data (e.g. insurance company reports). Look for data or studies which can validate the link between recreational vessel activity to noise impacts.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has fundamental issues that require substantial new data collection and methodological overhauls. The primary data source (AIS B) is acknowledged as a significant underestimate, and the core assumption of a linear relationship between activity and noise is unvalidated. The exclusion of recreational boat traffic far from the coast also represents a significant data gap. Addressing these requires new data streams (e.g., validating AIS B coverage, finding alternative traffic data) and potentially advanced modeling to estimate actual noise levels and their impact, moving beyond a simple linear assumption.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the necessary improvements would be highly difficult. Validating AIS B coverage would require extensive field observations or integration of diverse, potentially proprietary, datasets (e.g., insurance reports). Estimating actual noise levels from vessel activity is a complex acoustical modeling task, requiring specialized expertise and potentially new data collection (e.g., underwater acoustic measurements). Integrating these disparate data sources and developing a robust noise model would require significant resources, advanced technical expertise, and extensive coordination.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can significantly help improve this layer. Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) satellites can detect vessels regardless of AIS transmission, providing a means to validate the number of vessels carrying AIS B and potentially estimate overall vessel density, especially in areas where AIS B is sparse. While SAR cannot directly measure noise, it can provide a more accurate representation of vessel activity, which is the basis for the noise estimation. Optical satellites (e.g., Sentinel-2) could potentially assist in mapping recreational harbors and coastal infrastructure, which are inputs to the model, though their primary utility here is less direct than SAR for vessel detection.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden's primary offerings (Sentinel-2 Level-2A and national land cover data) have limited direct applicability to improving this specific marine noise layer. Sentinel-2 is an optical sensor and cannot detect vessels at sea effectively, especially small recreational boats, nor can it directly measure underwater noise or vessel activity. While it could map coastal features like harbors, this is a minor component of the overall improvement needed. The core issues of underestimation of vessel traffic and the lack of actual noise level estimation are beyond the capabilities of DigitalEarthSweden's current datasets.

name: Turbidity shipping
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
This raster intends to show the predicted effect of erosion as a consequence of shipping in Swedish inshore and offshore waters. The dataset is modelled and is based on combined annual 2015 AIS shipping intensity and depth data from the Swedish Maritime Administration and the probability of soft bottom substrate occurrence from the Geological Survey of Sweden. The data is based on a range of simplifications and assumptions which will introduce errors and uncertainty into the data product. The model is not validated however observational data in the form of publically available multibeam survey data in harbour areas predicted to have high levels of erosion around Skåne in southern Sweden does provide some data to support the model prediction in heavy traffic areas. These data were created as a data input layer
for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit
at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
(SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the
cumulative environmental impact of human activity in
Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at
plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is
only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data
sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad effekt av erosion på grund av fartygstrafik i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Detta rasterskikt är modellerat och är baserat på kombinerat årlig AIS data (2015), djupdata från Sjöfartsverket och data över trolig förekomst av mjukbottnar från Sveriges geologiska undersökning. Denna data är baserad på en rad förenklingar och antaganden vilket ger felkällor och osäkerhet. Modellen är inte validerad, dock finns observationsdata i form av offentligt tillgänglig mulitbeam- data från undersökningar i hamnområden som förutspås ha höga nivåer av erosion runt Skåne i södra Sverige, vilket ger viss data som stöd till modellen i tungt trafikerade områden. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
The dataset is based on combined annual 2015 AIS vessel tracking data created by WSP for SWaM's Symphony project. Calculation of induced flow rate at the bottom is based on [Fuehrer M. and Romisch K. 1987. Propeller jet erosion and stability criteria for bottom protection of various constructions. PIANC, Bulletin No. 58.] Erosion has been assumed to occur at current velocities> = 0.3 m / s. Above the critical erosion level (0.3 m / s), erosion has been assumed linearly following the increasing induced flow velocity (closer to deeper propellers). Furthermore, a simplified assumption has been made where erosion increases linearly to the soft bottom / transport bottom portion within each cell of 250 x 250 m. Also, erosion increases linearly to the annual vessel frequency within each corresponding cell. Processing steps are as follows: 1. The combined proportion of the transport base and
softbottom was calculated from the SGU basis
SUBSTRATKARTOR_V1_SYMPHONY_20160919.
2. AIS data on the vessel classes of tankers, passenger ships,
cargo vessels in 2015 were pooled into one layer with the
total vessel intensity per 250 x 250 m grid cell.
3. Max speed (Vdmax) at a certain depth (d) was calculated
with the equation Vdmax = 10.565 * d-1. Where depth values
were collected from SGU
DJUP_SYMPHONY_V2_20160919.
4: The equation is based on a power function matched to the
results of calculations of Vdmax using the relationship set by
Fuehrer & Romisch (Fuehrer M. and Romisch K. 1987.
Propeller jet erosion and stability criteria for bottom
protection of various constructions. PIANC, Bulletin No.
58.).
When calculating Vdmax, a standard vessel has been used
for which the following assumptions have been made:
Propeller diameter: 7.5 m (no rudder).,Propeller location:
4.15 m below water level, Rotation speed: 80 rpm
(equivalent to about 14.5 knots), Vessel size: L 330 m, W
50m, D 15 m, E (constant): 0.21 (applicable to ships without
rudders), Thrust coefficient: 0.45 (chart for advance no J
0.45) (MAN, Basic Principles of Ship Propulsion)
According to Hjulströms diagram, flow rates above 5 m / s
can move all types of sediments (up to blocks). Values above
5 m / s are not relevant why a threshold was applied at 5 m /
s (all values above the threshold were given value 5 m / s.
Erosion on semi-finite sediment bottoms can occur at
induced current velocities of about 0.3 m / s (wheel flow
diagram), why a lower threshold was placed at this flow rate.
4. All components in the model affect the degree of erosion
of bottom sediment, i.e.: intensity of vessel traffic,
proportion of fine / half-sediment and deep-specific
potential flow rate were pooled by multiplying.
5. The final grid was normalized linearly between min 0 and
max 100
"
limitations_for_use_in_symphony:
The model is constructed to predict vessel thrust velocities that are likely to cause erosion and this calculation is based on a set of simple assumptions. The first is that all vessels have the same characteristics, the second, that erosion is assumed to occur at current velocities> = 0.3 m / s. Thirdly, that above the critical erosion level (0.3 m / s), erosion linearly decreases with depth (i.e. increasing induced flow velocity closer to deeper propellers). Furthermore,
a simplified assumption has been made whereby erosion increases as the probability of soft
bottom substrate increases and erosion increases linearly to the annual vessel frequency
within each corresponding cell.
The substrate and depth datasets used are also subject to limitations which should be
investigated in further detail.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: The model could be further refined by adding addition criteria on vessel dimensions. Additional observational data could be collected to validate the model assumptions. The substrate dataset could be refined (for example consideration of the morphology of the substrate and compaction of sediments). Data on currents and exposure could be introduced (however it is assumed that the sediment data would be collinear). A more advanced form of modelling based (e.g. a GAM) might prove a different relationship between the different variables so this might be valuable to test.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has significant limitations, including a lack of model validation, simplified assumptions (e.g., all vessels have same characteristics, linear erosion with depth/frequency), and potential issues with underlying substrate and depth datasets. The recommendations suggest fundamental changes like adding vessel dimensions, collecting new observational data for validation, refining substrate data (morphology, compaction), introducing currents/exposure data, and exploring advanced modeling (e.g., GAM). These are not minor tweaks but require substantial methodological overhauls and new data integration, indicating a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements would be 'high' difficulty. It involves collecting new observational data for validation (which can be costly and time-consuming), refining complex substrate datasets (morphology, compaction), integrating dynamic environmental variables like currents and exposure, and potentially re-developing the core model using advanced statistical techniques (GAM). These tasks require significant resources, advanced technical expertise in marine geology, hydrodynamics, and statistical modeling, and extensive coordination.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can help improve this layer. While direct measurement of propeller-induced erosion is not possible, satellites can contribute to improving the input data and potentially validating aspects of the model. For instance, satellite-derived bathymetry (SDB) could refine depth data in some areas, and satellite imagery (e.g., Sentinel-2 for turbidity/suspended sediment) could potentially provide observational data on areas of high turbidity, which might correlate with erosion, especially in shallow, coastal areas. This could aid in model validation or refinement of the erosion prediction. However, it's important to note that satellite data alone cannot fully replace in-situ measurements for model validation or detailed substrate characterization.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 data and national land cover, has limited direct applicability for improving this specific marine layer. While Sentinel-2 can detect suspended sediments in shallow, clear waters, its utility for validating propeller-induced erosion in deeper, potentially turbid shipping lanes is limited. The land cover data is not directly relevant. The core data needs (detailed bathymetry, substrate compaction, vessel-specific characteristics, in-situ current measurements) are beyond the scope of DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings. Therefore, it's 'false' that DigitalEarthSweden data can significantly help generate or improve this layer.

name: Noise 125Hz shipping
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary: This raster intends to show predicted sound level exposure at a frequency of 125 Hertz from shipping (i.e. passenger, cargo, and tanker) in Swedish coastal and offshore waters. A cell value of 0 is equivalent to low exposure (<100 dB re 1 uPa) and a cell value of 100 is equivalent to high exposure (>150 dB re 1 uPa). Underlying data are from several sources and consist of shipping traffic data, bottom substrate data, and depth data that have been combined and modelled. These data were created as a data input layer for 'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the cumulative environmental impact of human activity in Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data sources.
summary_swedish:
Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad ljudexponering från fartygstrafik (dvs. passagerar-, frakt- och tankfartyg) i frekvensområdet 125 Hertz i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg exponering (<100 dB re 1 uPa), , och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög exponering (>150 dB re 1 uPa). Underlagsdata härrör från flera olika
källor och består av trafikdata, bottensubstratsdata och
djupdata som har kombinerats och modellerats. Denna data
skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget
utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och
vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för
bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig
aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering.
Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast
lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
With the assistance of a generalised spreading model (RL = SL – TL) the Received Level (RL) of sound was calculated for all cells in the SYMPHONY area at two frequencies (125 Hz and 2000 Hz). SL = Source level. Transmission loss (TL) was calculated as a function of the distance from the source (distance) as well as bottom substrate character at the source. For shallow (<30m) bottoms with hard sediment character the function 15 × log(distance) was used and for deep (>30m) bottom or soft sediment character the function 20 × log(distance) was used. Bottom substrate classification was based on maps of bottom substrate purpose produced by the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU) for SYMPHONY. Bottom substrates where the proportion of soft bottom was > 50% were defined as having soft sediment character. The aggregated sound from all ships within a particular ship class over a year were combined and converted to sound intensity. The yearly average was calculated and then converted to sound volume expressed in average decibels (dBavg), which was calculated as follows: dBavg = 10 × log10(∑∆t/T×(10)^((RL intensity/10)) summed over all ∆t under the whole time period T (1 year alternatively 6 months). Source sound volumes that were applied for different ship classes were as follows: 125 Hz Passenger ships – 150 dB 125 Hz Cargo ships – 180 dB 125 Hz Tanker ships – 185 dB 2000 Hz Passenger ships – 150 dB 2000 Hz Cargo ships – 153 dB 2000 Hz Tanker ships – 160 dB Data were linear normalized between 100 and 150 dB yearly average. Schematic source strengths for different ship types and frequency ranges have been determined by a literature study. In cases where source strengths of 1/3 octave band at 125 and 2000 Hz have not been identified, the closest value
found in the literature is used.
More detailed information on the lineage and methodology
is available and can be supplied on request to the data
owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The generalized sound propagation model is not externally validated so the results of the modelling should be interpreted with caution. Attention should be paid to the underlying quality and accuracy of the sediment substrate data. In particular the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU) provided data on the probability of occurrence of soft sediment substrates for these modelling, these data are based on both on dominant grain size and categorical maps based on hydroacoustic data. The model does not include information on sediment compaction and morphology which will certainly affect sound propagation. This model should therefore be used with caution and should not be used for detailed studies of smaller areas.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Produce data on seabed geomorphology (e.g. depth metrics) and sediment compaction may be useful for improvement of the model At present little data is available for model validation so identification of additional sources of acoustic monitoring data would be useful.

It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine
and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should
be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived

purposes.
