improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer has fundamental limitations in its underlying model and data quality. The 'generalized sound propagation model is not externally validated' and 'should be interpreted with caution'. There are significant concerns about the 'underlying quality and accuracy of the sediment substrate data', specifically regarding the lack of 'sediment compaction and morphology' information which 'will certainly affect sound propagation'. The model 'should not be used for detailed studies of smaller areas'. The recommendations explicitly call for 'producing data on seabed geomorphology (e.g. depth metrics) and sediment compaction' and 'identification of additional sources of acoustic monitoring data' for validation, indicating a need for substantial new data collection and a fundamental overhaul of the model's input parameters and validation process.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: Implementing the recommended improvements would be highly difficult. Producing new data on 'seabed geomorphology' and 'sediment compaction' for the entire study area would require extensive, specialized marine surveys (e.g., high-resolution multibeam bathymetry, sub-bottom profiling, core sampling). Identifying and integrating 'additional sources of acoustic monitoring data' for validation would involve significant coordination, data harmonization, and potentially new in-situ deployments. The current model's generalized nature suggests that incorporating these detailed physical parameters would necessitate a more complex, physics-based sound propagation model, requiring advanced technical expertise and significant computational resources. This goes beyond simple updates or integration of existing datasets.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing cannot directly generate or significantly improve this layer. The core data needs are 'sediment compaction', 'seabed geomorphology' (beyond basic depth, requiring detailed morphology), and 'acoustic monitoring data' for validation. While satellite-derived bathymetry (SDB) can provide some depth information in clear, shallow waters, it cannot provide sediment compaction or detailed geomorphology at the resolution and accuracy likely needed for sound propagation modeling. Acoustic monitoring data is inherently in-situ. Satellite observations are primarily for surface phenomena or broad-scale seafloor mapping, not sub-surface sediment properties or direct acoustic measurements.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden's primary offerings (Sentinel-2 Level-2A and national land cover data) are not suitable for generating or improving this layer. Sentinel-2 is an optical sensor primarily for land and very shallow, clear coastal waters. It cannot penetrate deep enough to map seabed geomorphology or sediment compaction in the offshore and deeper coastal waters relevant to shipping noise. It also cannot provide acoustic monitoring data. The national land cover data is terrestrial and not relevant to marine sound propagation modeling.

summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa beräknad ljudexponering från fartygstrafik (dvs. passagerar-, frakt- och tankfartyg) i frekvensområdet 2000 Hertz i svenska kust- och havsvatten. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg exponering (<100 dB re 1 uPa), och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög exponering (>150 dB re 1 uPa). Underlagsdata härrör från flera olika källor och består av trafikdata (AIS 2015), bottensubstratsdata, och djupdata som har kombinerats och modellerats. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Lineage: With the assistance of a generalised spreading model (RL = SL – TL) the Received Level (RL) of sound was calculated for all cells in the SYMPHONY area at two frequencies (125 Hz and 2000 Hz). SL = Source level. Transmission loss (TL) was calculated as a function of the distance from the source (distance) as well as bottom substrate character at the source. For shallow (<30m) bottoms with hard sediment character the function 15 × log(distance) was used and for deep (>30m) bottom or soft sediment character the function 20 × log(distance) was used. Bottom substrate classification was based on maps of bottom substrate purpose produced by the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU) for SYMPHONY. Bottom substrates where the proportion of soft bottom was > 50% were defined as having soft sediment character. The aggregated sound from all ships within a particular ship class over a year were combined and converted to sound intensity. The yearly average was calculated and then converted to sound volume expressed in average decibels (dBavg), which was calculated as follows: dBavg = 10 × log10(∑∆t/T×(10)^((RL intensity/10)) summed over all ∆t under the whole time period T (1 year alternatively 6 months). Source sound volumes that were applied for different ship classes were as follows: 125 Hz Passenger ships – 150 dB 125 Hz Cargo ships – 180 dB
125 Hz Tanker ships – 185 dB
2000 Hz Passenger ships – 150 dB
2000 Hz Cargo ships – 153 dB
2000 Hz Tanker ships – 160 dB
Data were linear normalized between 100 and 150 dB yearly
average. Schematic source strengths for different ship types
and frequency ranges have been determined by a literature
study. In cases where source strengths of 1/3 octave band at
125 and 2000 Hz have not been identified, the closest value
found in the literature is used.
More detailed information on the lineage and methodology
is available and can be supplied on request to the data
owner.
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The generalized sound propagation model is not externally validated so the results of the modelling should be interpreted with caution. Attention should be paid to the underlying quality and accuracy of the sediment substrate data. In particular the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU) provided data on the probability of occurrence of soft sediment substrates for these modelling, these data are based on both on dominant grain size and categorical maps based on hydroacoustic data. The model does not include information on sediment compaction and morphology which will certainly affect sound propagation. This model should therefore be used with caution and should not be used for detailed studies of smaller areas.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: Produce data on seabed geomorphology (e.g. depth metrics) and sediment compaction may be useful for improvement of the model At present little data is available for model validation so identification of fadditional sources of acoustic monitoring data would be useful.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: merchant shipping, environmental impact , noise pollution
other_restrictions: This "Noise 2000Hz shipping" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Geological Survey of Sweden (SGU), the Swedish Maritime Authority (SMA). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived from it are not to be used for safety or navigation purposes.
metadata_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states that the generalized sound propagation model is not externally validated and should be interpreted with caution. It also highlights the need for better data on sediment compaction and morphology, which 'will certainly affect sound propagation'. The recommendations suggest producing data on seabed geomorphology (e.g., depth metrics) and sediment compaction, and identifying additional sources of acoustic monitoring data for validation. These are fundamental issues with the model's accuracy and underlying data, requiring significant new data collection and potentially a re-evaluation of the propagation model itself, thus indicating a 'large' improvement potential.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: The recommendations involve producing new data on seabed geomorphology and sediment compaction, which are complex and resource-intensive undertakings. Furthermore, identifying and integrating 'additional sources of acoustic monitoring data' for model validation implies a significant effort in data acquisition, standardization, and integration. The current model's lack of external validation and its sensitivity to unmodeled factors (sediment compaction/morphology) suggest that addressing these issues would require advanced technical expertise, extensive coordination, and substantial resources, making it 'high' difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: Satellite remote sensing can contribute to improving this layer, particularly regarding seabed geomorphology and potentially validating aspects of the model. Satellite-derived bathymetry (SDB) can provide depth metrics, especially in shallower coastal areas, which is a recommended improvement. While satellites cannot directly measure sound propagation or sediment compaction, they can provide valuable input data (like bathymetry) that influences sound propagation models. Additionally, satellite imagery could potentially assist in mapping broad sediment types in very shallow, clear waters, though this is less direct for the specific needs of compaction and morphology.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden, primarily offering Sentinel-2 Level-2A data and national land cover, has limited direct applicability for improving this specific marine noise layer. While Sentinel-2 can provide some information on coastal land use and very shallow water features, it lacks the specialized sensors for deep-water bathymetry, sediment compaction, or direct acoustic monitoring. The core needs for this layer are detailed seabed characteristics (geomorphology, compaction) and acoustic validation data, which are beyond the capabilities of the current DigitalEarthSweden offerings. Its focus is more on terrestrial and coastal land cover/change detection rather than detailed marine physical parameters relevant to sound propagation.

name: Oilspill shipping
data_format: 32-bit floating point Tagged Image File Format
coordinate_reference_system: European Terrestrial Reference System 1989 - Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area http://epsg.io/3035
summary:
The raster layer intends to show the probability of exposure to an oil spill from shipping over the course of a year in Swedish coastal and offshore waters under meteorological
conditions equivalent to a drift speed of 0.2 knots. A cell
value of 0 is equivalent to low probability of exposure and a
cell value of 100 is equivalent to a high probability of
exposure. Underlying data are from two sources and consist
of shipping traffic data (AIS 2015) and illegal oil discharge
data (HELCOM, 2015) that have been combined and
modelled. These data were created as a data input layer for
'Symphony' tool developed by the marine planning unit at
the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
(SwAM). Symphony is used by SwAM to assess the
cumulative environmental impact of human activity in
Swedish waters and this informs the formulation of policy at
plan area scales. Re-use of these data for other purposes is
only advisable with the guidance and advice of the data
sources.
summary_swedish: Detta rasterskikt avser att visa sannolikheten att drabbas av oljespill från fartyg under ett år, under meteorlogiska förhållanden som motsvarar en drifthastighet av 0,2 knop. Ett cellvärde av 0 motsvarar låg sannolikhet för oljespill, och ett cellvärde av 100 motsvarar hög sannolikhet. Underlagsdata härrör från två källor och består av trafikdata (AIS, 2015) och data över illegala oljeutsläpp (HELCOM, 2015) som har kombinerats och modellerats. Denna data skapades som ett data input layer för ’Symphony’ verktyget utvecklat av enheten för havsplaneringen på Havs- och vattenmyndigheten (HaV). Symphony används av HaV för bedömning av den kumulativa miljöpåverkan av mänsklig aktivitet i svenska vatten och används vid havsplanering. Återanvändning av denna data för andra ändamål är endast lämpligt efter vägledning och rådgivning av datakällorna.
lineage:
Based on data of ship traffic (AIS 2015) and detected oil spills (HELCOM, 2015, http://helcom.fi/baltic-sea- trends/data-maps/) the likelihood that an oil spill would occur in an area with a certain level of ship traffic intensity was established. The likelihood of an oil spill was calculated for 10 classes of ship traffic intensity. A focal statistics filter was applied on the generated raster to simulate areas that could be impacted by a spill. The impact area was estimated for an oil spill with a residence time of 24 h and a spreading distance equivalent to the distance that a spill can travel with a speed of 0.2 or 0.5 knots (i.e. two spreading scenarios with wind speeds of approx. 4.5 m/s and 8.5 m/s, in accordance with the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute’s (SMHI) report 2007-8, Fairways in the Baltic Sea, Oil spill risk assessment). A sensitivity analysis was undertaken whereby detected spills moved a distance equivalent to that of the drift speed under 12h in a random direction. The sensitivity analysis indicated high sensitivity for the spills reported location. To simulate the oil spill weathering (i.e.
dissolution, dilution, dispersion, sedimentation and
evaporation) a linear decrease with respect to increasing
distance from the source cell was applied. Discussion on the
method occurred between WSP (consultant) and SwAM
(client) as well as Linnaeus University (expert).
limitations_for_use_in_symphony: The model used requires a connection between vessel intensity and likelihood of an oil spill but there are a number of other explanatory factors with great or greater relevance with are currently omitted. The sensitivity analysis indicated high sensitivity to the spill's reported location. The spill may have moved in the period between occurrence of the spill to the Coast Guard's discovery which introduces major uncertainties in the model. Data on seabirds killed by oil spills indicates that the actual amount of spills that are happening are likely to be greater than reported. This gives further uncertainty and implies that the model probably underestimates the likelihood. The probability that a spill enters the surrounding grid cell has been calculated by assuming a linear decrease with probability 0 at the distance reached during 24 h with a wind speed of 0.2 knots. The results should be interpreted as standard estimates.
recommendations_for_data_improvement: There are insufficient data on actual spill occurrences so the model results should be interpreted with caution. These model could be significantly improved with higher rates of detection. It is unclear if reporting to the maritime authority is based on real time satellite data. Surface Aperture Radar (SAR) equipped satellite sensors are becoming increasingly capable of detecting spills. Further investigations should be undertaken to identify potential data gathering opportunities.
contact_organisation: Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
data_owner: Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management (Hav och Vattenmyndighten)
gemet_keywords: merchant shipping , environmental impact , oil pollution
other_restrictions:
This "Oilspill shipping" dataset is a derived from source data provided by the Swedish Maritime Authority (SMA). This derived dataset is licenced under a Creative
Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY
4.0). It is attributed to WSP Sverige AB and was
produced on behalf of the Swedish Agency for Marine
and Water Management (SwAM). Data sources should
be acknowledged. This data set and any data derived
from it are not to be used for safety or navigation
purposes.

improvement_reasoning.improvement_justification: The layer explicitly states 'insufficient data on actual spill occurrences' and that the model 'probably underestimates the likelihood' due to underreporting. It also notes 'major uncertainties' due to sensitivity to reported spill location and movement. Addressing these fundamental data gaps and model uncertainties requires a 'major improvement' involving new data collection (better detection) and potentially a 'fundamental methodological overhaul' to account for actual spill frequency and location accuracy.
improvement_reasoning.difficulty_justification: The recommendations suggest 'higher rates of detection' and 'further investigations...to identify potential data gathering opportunities', implying a need for new data collection protocols or integration of advanced detection technologies (like SAR satellites). This is a 'major infrastructure' and 'advanced technical expertise' undertaking, especially if it involves real-time satellite data integration and validation, making it 'high' difficulty.
improvement_reasoning.satellite_justification: The recommendations explicitly mention 'Surface Aperture Radar (SAR) equipped satellite sensors are becoming increasingly capable of detecting spills' and question if reporting is 'based on real time satellite data'. This directly indicates that satellite remote sensing, particularly SAR, can significantly help in generating or improving this layer by providing more accurate and comprehensive data on actual spill occurrences, addressing the core limitation of 'insufficient data'.
improvement_reasoning.digital_earth_sweden_justification: DigitalEarthSweden primarily offers Sentinel-2 optical data and national land cover data. While Sentinel-2 can detect large, visible oil spills in clear waters, its primary utility is for land and shallow water applications. It lacks the all-weather, day/night capabilities of SAR for oil spill detection, which is specifically highlighted as a key improvement area. Therefore, DigitalEarthSweden's current offerings are not directly suitable for generating or significantly improving the core 'oil spill detection' aspect of this marine layer.
